Title: Bengaluru in shutdown mode amid COVID-19 scare
Content: Over the last few days in Bengaluru, the city’s dreaded traffic congestion has eased out, given that more employees are working from home, and schools have suspended classes for children up to standard 5. The government has issued guidelines to district authorities to handle a worst-case scenario, with all public gatherings being cancelled. But with confirmed cases of COVID-19 being reported in Bengaluru, there is no denying that a large chunk of the city’s populace is in panic mode. Tech park employees are being checked for temperature spikes; sanitisers and masks are in short-supply and those who are still selling these items are making a killing on them and the University of WhatsApp is not helping matters.Shopping establishments are, no doubt, affected by people shunning public places were large numbers usually gather. “Online shopping is still operational and thriving, as are home deliveries,” says Aijaz Ahmed*, a supermarket owner. But the same cannot be said for cinema halls, both at malls and stand alone. In fact, while a few new films have hit theatres today, the next few weeks seem bleak, with makers pushing their release date. Filmmaker Vikyaath, who was all set to release his Prajwal Devaraj-starrer Inspector Vikram by the month-end, is now looking at a date sometime in May. “I am an exhibitor as well and have been seeing the steady decline in the footfalls in theatres. People are scared and right now, it really does not make sense for films to be released, when collections do not even cover basic electricity costs,” he says.The team of Thurthu Nirgamana was looking at a window just after the release of Duniya Vijay’s Salaga and targetting early April. But the present scenario has thrown their plans haywire. “A final call on our release plans will be firmed up only by the end of the week. We are still analysing the situation,” says Sharath BS, from the film’s team. Ramesh Aravind is also in a dilemma about when to set a date for the release of his next directorial, 100. “The film has been censored, but we are monitoring the situation to determine a release. We were targetting April 10, because it coincides with the 50th day of my film Shivaji Surathkal, but that looks unlikely,” says Ramesh.A distributor, on condition of anonymity, adds, “There has, no doubt, been a drop in the footfalls in theatres.” A decision on closing movie halls, though, is pending and will be taken only if there is a government directive to this effect. A few single-screen halls have, however, already downed shutters as a precautionary measure.Following the government directive, schools across the state have suspended classes for kids up to class five, while the rest either have exams or have begun summer school for the next academic year. This, of course, has driven parents into a tizzy, worried about the safety of older children. “Incubation period ranges from five days to two weeks, and a child can be asymptomatic yet, be a carrier and pose risk to other children. Also, unlike offices and tech parks, where employees are being scanned for temperature variations and other symptoms, children remain in a closed environment for hours without such monitoring. It would be ideal not to expose children to such uncertain conditions for a few days until the situation improves,” says Denet Pradeep, whose daughter is currently attending summer school for Class 10.Another parent and medical professional, though, says that stopping children from attending school does not entirely solve the problem. “You can stop them from going to school, tuition and other extra-curricular activities, but as long as the parents and other caretakers continue to be out and about, the risk of bringing an infection home is still there. Instead of sequestering the kids, the focus should be on inculcating preventive measures, like increased hygiene and best practices to be followed when sneezing and coughing,” she says.Several music events and performances, including college fests have been cancelled or postponed indefinitely. Artistes from the city have taken to social media in the past few days to announce the cancellation of events. Bengaluru-based band Best Kept Secret had to cancel several gigs in the country, says frontman Behram Siganporia. “Around 7-8 shows that were scheduled to be held in different parts of the country have been postponed and in Bengaluru all our future shows have been put on hold as of now,” says Behram.Similarly, convocations and fests at several colleges across the city have been cancelled or pushed until further notice. A statement put up by students, on their website, reads, “In view of the COVID-19 Corona Virus outbreak and the advisories by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, and the World Health Organisation to avoid large gatherings, IIM Bangalore has decided to postpone the Convocation 2020 scheduled for Friday, March 20.” Students of Dayanand Sagar University, too, postponed their cultural fest until further notice. “We have been asked to postpone the fest until further notice,” says Aldrich Shawn Lewis, a student and a member of the Centre for Performing Arts, which was handling the fest.Bangalore Open Air, a rock and heavy metal festival that features local and international bands, scheduled for March 19 and 20 has been pushed, with fresh dates to be announced later. Several international artistes, who were to perform in the city, have postponed their performances. Aman Chainani, owner of a restaurant that was hosting international artiste Jody Wisternoff, said that the performance was pushed due to the COVID-19 scare. “Since Jody had a history of traveling to South Korea, the event scheduled in our restaurant was pushed,” says Aman. Singer Khalid’s Free Spirit tour to India has also been pushed until further notice.

Title: Will movie buffs be deprived of new films from this month end?
Content: On Tuesday, film distributors belonging to various associations in Tamil Nadu came together for a press meet to announce their decision of refraining from distributing new films from March 27 as a mark of protest against the TDS levied on them and the Local Body Entertainment Tax (LBET) on movie tickets.T Rajhendherr, president of the Chennai Kanchipuram Tiruvallur District Film Distributors Association , says, “We have decided not to release new films from March 27 as it has become difficult to afford the TDS. Our Prime Minister had informed us that there will be a uniform tax across the country. But there is 8% LBET levied in addition to the 12% GST here, and hence, it should be revised by the government. This decision has been taken after discussions with all the distributors’ associations in the state.”Meanwhile, the exhibitors are on a wait- and-watch mode. They want to look at the developments before making their move. CT Valliappan, owner of a movie theatre in Vadapalani, says that he’s yet to receive any intimation regarding the protest. “I can’t talk much about this now as I haven’t received any information pertaining to it. Let them sort it out first,” he says.Rakesh, who owns a theatre complex in Chromepet, informs that a decision on this issue will be known only after a meeting of exhibitors, which they are planning to conduct soon. T Mannan, secretary of the Chennai Kanchipuram Tiruvallur District Film Distributors Association , says he is waiting for the exhibitors to take a decision on this. “We have expressed our concern — the difficulty of coping with additional taxes. There may be a chance that theatres, too, will be willing to shut down in order to get this issue resolved.”

Title: Radhika and I love following traditions and this was one of them: Yash
Content: On Wednesday morning, the crowd outside the Nanjundeshwara temple in Najangud, Karnataka, swelled more than the usual. Besides the presiding deity, they were also waiting to get a glimpse of their favourite stars, Yash and Radhika , who were on a private visit to the temple along with their family. The actors were at the historic temple for the traditional head tonsuring ceremony of their daughter, Ayra . The couple, dressed in a traditional silk panche and shirt and a green Kanjeevaram sari respectively, performed an abhisheka, followed by another set of pujas. They also sponsored the anna dasoha (the day’s meals) for the devotees. Ayra, we hear, quite enjoyed her brief tonsuring ceremony, while her parents kept her entertained throughout with rhymes. Yash, say sources close to the actor, had been working non-stop for the past two months and had taken time off to be with his family.Speaking about the experience, Yash says, “Nanjundeshwara is our family deity and I remember my parents taking me there when I was a child, for my first tonsuring ritual. So, it was a sentimental moment when I sat there with my wife and kids for the same ceremony. Radhika and I love following traditions and it was very special moment for all of us.”

Title: Vainidhi Jagdish next sees her play an introvert
Content: Actress Vainidhi Jagdish , the daughter of actor Jai Jagdish and filmmaker Vijayalakshmi Singh , who was introduced in Sandalwood by her mother in Yaana, has signed up for her next. Called Bengaluru Boys, the film directed by Raj Surya is an exploration of the life of modern-day youngsters, and will have Vainidhi in a role that is in stark contrast to that in her debut movie.Speaking to us, Vainidhi says, “This is my first movie outside my home banner, so, in a sense, it feels like a debut,as I get to work with completely different actors. Bengaluru Boys has actors Sri Mahadev , Chandan Achar and Sachin on board. The real test begins for me now, as people from the industry will get to see how I am as an artiste on the set itself and it won't be like the protected environment that I had on Yaana. I have to prove myself from the word go. After Yaana, I was looking for an out-of-the-box character, which I got with Bengaluru Boys. I play an introverted middle-class traditional girl, who is kindhearted. Although she speaks very little, what she does has gravitas. I am excited to start my second project, which will go on floors by the end of the month.”

Title: Tracing the life of Kamali through the eyes of Anandhi
Content: She has proven her acting chops in films like Kayal and Pariyerum Perumal, and director Rajasekar Duraisamy believes that his film — Kamali From Nadukkaveri — is another movie that’s given Anandhi a platform to establish herself as a bankable actress. “The film traces the journey of a woman from when she’s 17 to when she turns 24. So, I was looking at someone who could fit the age group perfectly. Also, Anandhi has the potential to carry a film on her shoulders. I’m sure this will be her career best film,” says the debutant filmmaker.So, what’s the film about? “The story revolves around Kamali, a girl from a small town, and follows her journey from a Class 12 student to when she completes her college education. We trace her life, her love, what drives her and how she faces the challenges life throws at her,” says Rajasekar, “We always say — don’t shy away from setting your bar high. Think big so you’ll achieve big. There are people who have low self-esteem and that stops them from achieving what they want in life. Life-la jeyikkaradha vida nammala naame jeyikkaradhu mukkiyam. We’ve conveyed all this subtly without sounding preachy.”The film will also mark the Tamil debut of Bollywood actor Rohit Saraf . “He’s done some amazing movies in Hindi — Dear Zindagi, Hichki and The Sky Is Pink. In this film, he plays the person who inspires Kamali; he has a strong role,” he signs off.

Title: Bigg Boss fame Jazla Madasseri: From my third week onwards, I was always packed and ready to leave the Bigg Boss house
Content: Legendary actor Soumitra Chatterjee has been tested positive for COVID-19. He has been admitted to a private hospital this morning. The ace actor was not keeping well since past few days and underwent the necessary test today. Title: Bigg Boss fame Jazla Madasseri: From my third week onwards, I was always packed and ready to leave the Bigg Boss house
Content:
Photo by Ajilal

Jazla Madasseri has been a vibrant presence on social media for years, raising her voice for social issues. From the time Bigg Boss season 2 roped her in as a wildcard entry participant, to when she exited the house after five weeks, the 24-year-old firebrand was much discussed by the show's fans. Whether it was how she stood up to fellow contestant Rajith Kumar ’s conservative views or befriended Daya who was considered her nemesis, her fans have many reasons to laud the Malappuram girl. In conversation with Jazla:

How ready were you to be part of the Bigg Boss house?

I had never watched the show and when I first got the call for it, I didn’t say yes. But, when my friends and boss asked to give it a try, I decided to take it as an experiment. How did I prepared for it? The day before entering the show, in my hotel room, I saw a few one-minute videos.

And once you were in?

I entered the house on day 21. I had no strategy and was my natural self. Outside, I had seen support pouring in for certain participants but once in, I could see they aren’t the people they were made out to be. When I completed 20 days, locked in, seeing the same faces and only faraway views of high-rises or trees, I also understood the pressure of those within. Many were on complete game mode in the house. Our only outside connection was Lalettan. For a travel and freedom lover, it was tough.

Your verbal fights with certain contestants like Rajith Kumar won tremendous air time.

I got into arguments only when lines were crossed. As everyone knows, there are those who propagate baseless ideas in the house. Whenever possible, I have tried to get into healthy discussions with them. But they don’t listen to other’s views and just walks away while we speak! They also often spoke encroaching into my comfort zone, close to my face, which but wasn’t clear on TV. Arguments like autistic children are born to obstinate women were too much for to take for me. My own sister, married off at 15, has an autistic daughter. What kind of obstinate woman would she have been at 15?

However, when the proceedings of 24 hours get edited to just one, only my arguments were included. We are helpless, as the show agreement allows it. After all, that’s apparently what the audience want – a girl fighting, using harsh language, giving sharp expressions – which are easy to criticise. My own friends said I didn’t present many ideas well and restricted myself to pseudo science arguments, which isn’t the reality. As per rules, we aren’t even allowed to discuss religion or politics there. Social issues are my sphere of work and so, these topics would naturally come under its purview. And yet, I tried not to break show rules.

There was an instance in which my body was grabbed inappropriately from behind, during a task. I reacted strongly and even said I’m leaving. But it was projected as a planned move by Fukru and me, and it disappointed me. I couldn’t even sleep well from then and wanted to leave.

Daya, who was considered your nemesis, recently said she wants you back in the show. What changed between you two?

I knew her only as someone who posted numerous videos attacking my views, and as I used to feel she has a hidden agenda, I never took her name or reacted to her in my videos. After two days in the house, I could see she was a lonely, innocent soul who acts out of misunderstanding. I could even communicate certain views to her better.

Did you feel you were weak in tasks?

I couldn’t even pee for two days after getting kicked during a task and my legs still have scars. There are even those who were bleeding after tasks. Many from season one told me their tasks were simpler. But this time, Bigg Boss gives instructions on the lines of ‘regardless of whether you get hurt, do the tasks’. Hurting others in ‘game spirit’ and later applying medicine on their wounds didn’t excite me.

Were you expecting eviction after five weeks?

In fact, from my third week in the house, I was all packed and ready every weekend, to leave. After RJ Sooraj’s eviction was announced, I was praying they called my name too and I was glad Lalettan did. If I would have continued, I might have punched some people’s faces as I couldn’t take it anymore (laughs).

Do you miss anyone from the house?

I was attached to Fukru and Sandra. Fukru is a real entertainer and thanks to his lovely stories about his family, I am in touch with them a lot too.

How’s the response after you came out of the show?

I have gone for many programmes since then. Except for certain ‘armies’ who attack me and Manju online by morphing our photos and creating memes, others have been very good to me.

He is an all-rounder, who can bat anywhere in the order and can give the team you useful overs in the powerplay.That’s quite a mystery!His Chennai-ness, his lean-as-a-bean image and his attitude is a win-win among ladies!Though he made his debut in the female-centric Kanaa, Darshan did manage to wow the audiences with his easy performance. Title: Chennai Times Most Desirable Man 2019: Sivakarthikeyan
Content:
Rank 2019 HOTTIES GAINERS/LOSERS IN 2019 Rank 2018 1 Sivakarthikeyan Up 5 2 Anirudh Down 1 3 Dhanush Up 6 4 Atharvaa Down 2 5 Dhruv Vikram Up 13 6 Kavin New Entrant - 7 Arjun Das New Entrant - 8 Harish Kalyan Down 4 9 Hiphop Aadhi Up 11 10 Amitash Pradhan Re-Entry - 11 Mugen Rao New Entrant - 12 Sid Sriram Up 20 13 Aadhi Down 9 14 Aadhitya Baaskar New Entrant - 15 Vishnu Vishal Up 17 16 Jiiva Up 19 17 Simbu Down 7 18 Tharshan Thiyagarajah New Entrant - 19 Teejat Arunsalam New Entrant - 20 Vijay Shankar New Entrant - 21 Jayam Ravi Down 12 22 Ashok Selvan Up 28 23 Arya Down 18 24 Bharath Niwas Re-Entry - 25 Shanthnu Bhagyaraj New Entrant - 26 Kishore DS New Entrant - 27 Gautham Karthik Down 26 28 Kathir New Entrant - 29 Washington Sundar New Entrant - 30 Darshan New Entrant -









There’s something about Sivakarthikeyan (SK) —it could be his crazy bone, a sense of familiarity that engulfs you the minute you strike up a conversation with him, or that typical Tamizh paiyyan look which draws you instantly to him. And probably much more, which explains why he has been voted the Chennai Times Most Desirable Man of 2019 from a bunch of achievers, all under the age of 40. When we tell him this, he’s unsure if he’s heard us right. We reiterate, and he breaks into his trademark smile and goes, ‘Aiyyo, nambave mudiyala’. In a no-holds-barred conversation, SK talks to us about his concept of love, desirability and more…I didn’t quite believe my manager when he told me this. I even asked my friend Darshan (of Kanaa fame) to check again if it was true. I was very happy when Anirudh won this title last year. I had even texted him. I think I was at No 2 slot two or three years ago. Indha varusham naan dhan Most Desirable-nu sonnappa ennaku purilla (smiles). I don’t really know on what basis people have chosen me. I am sure ‘desirable’ has a lot to do with personality and looks. When it comes to looks, I am not someone who really dresses up well or carries off any style. Maybe people like the way I am. This is new for me, but I am very excited.I didn’t tell my wife at all! I want to surprise her when it comes out in print. I think she will be very excited when she sees the newspaper today. She saw me as a ‘hero’ before anyone else did. She’s always excited when it comes to anything that relates to me – she buys branded stuff for me, she chooses my clothes. She doesn’t spend on herself, but will not think twice if she has to buy anything costly for me. Ellarukkum naan comedian-a therinjappa, avangalukku naan hero-va therinjen. I am sure she will be thrilled to bits.I think you need to be yourself. For instance, if you get into a relationship, you will notice how the person looks only the first few days. Over time, you will only care about what kind of person they are. More than appearance, how beautiful you internally are matters the most. Also, desirability can be subjective. I might like a certain way of dressing, but it might be different for you. To each his own.Not really. Azhaga rasikkarathu thappu illa. But you should know where to draw the line. Men or women, avanga azhaga irundha, azhaga irrukaanga-nu mattum dhan paakkanum. Next ennanu yosikardu dhan thevailladha vela. But being married isn’t a deterrent. When we started Seemaraja, we knew that Samantha was going to get married. That didn’t even come as a point of discussion when we got her on board. I am married and I am working in this field. She was also going to get married (at that time). So what? Actors, actresses or models would like to be appreciated for the way they look/ carry themselves. It should be in the right meter.Actually, I have a Bollywood crush… Alia Bhatt. I find her very cute. She is cheerful and is always smiling. Maybe I get to see only those pictures in which she’s smiling (laughs). I like women who are very cute. I have seen her films, too. I loved 2 States… she played a south Indian in the film. I think I like her because of that, too, as that was the first film of hers I saw.(Checks the road through the window to see if women are queuing up to see him) See, I don’t have that kind of fans. Everyone is sweet to me. I get messages from female fans and I feel shy when I read them. People have made videos using scenes from my films, and I find these things amazing. But I’ve never had female fans landing up at my doorstep.I love that tag. That won’t change even when I get older (laughs). It is always good to have people call you ‘anna’. They will always be there with you. I never look at myself as a lover boy or a chocolate boy. I know my reality. If people like me, it is mostly for my sense of humour. I think that is my asset.It was a one-sided love. I was in college then and she didn’t know about how I felt. Today, I would call it more of an infatuation. But at that time, I felt very deeply about it. Appo adhu bayangaramana love. I studied in an all-boys school. So, I didn’t know how to speak to a girl. When I got into college, I was smitten by her. But I didn’t know how to express my feelings. Eventually, it fizzled out. She’s married today.It’s accepting someone in totality. Everyone has their own flaws, there are issues with everyone. But if you love them truly, you accept them for what they are. We all have minuses – ellathayum serthu accept pannradhudhan love.Comparisons — with others, as well as your past and present. I’ve seen this happen with my friends who’ve married the person they fell in love with. You were not like this when we were in a relationship – that’s a statement they often make. I think when you are in love, andha ponnu kedaikkamattalangra mentality-la you’ll do everything. But after marriage, andha ponnu kedachuttale-nu you change. That simply won’t do.Initially, I used to retort out of ego. Now, I’ve learnt that the trick is to stay quiet; we both do that, and use that silence to figure out whose mistake it is. I usually don’t say much that day, but the next day, I take her out. But you shouldn’t take them out because you have fought with them! That becomes their trump card (laughs).For her 30th birthday — it was in last November – I organised a treasure hunt that started at 8pm and ended at 12 midnight. I’d hidden 30 gifts at various places in our house, office and even at our friends’ places. She opened the last gift closer to midnight and then, I got her inside the house blindfolded. Her parents had also come home. Kanna thorandhu, kadhari kadhari azhudhuttanga. This surprise took a lot of planning, and there was a goof-up in the last gift’s location — instead of the guava tree, my friend placed it on the lemon tree! That’s the only surprise I have given her, though she surprises me often.It was in 2013 I think, and there were these reports that I was going to divorce Aarthi! She was seven months pregnant then and it had affected me deeply. More than the rumour, I think it was the timing that affected me. She was the one who brought me the clipping. Even if she was upset, she didn’t express it because she didn’t want me to get upset.Neengale nalladha ezhudunga!I only attend my friends’ birthday parties and success meets.No, not really.Yes, I would think so. See, there’s no use of inviting me to parties — koopta edhavadhu prayojanam irukkanum. Onnu correct-a company kudukkanum, illa at least neraya neramavadhu irukkunam. I don’t do both. I have played cricket with Suriya and Dhanush. That’s about it.No one has seen the real Sivakarthikeyan – neither on TV nor in cinema. I tease and pull people’s legs, but I realised that ellathulayum kalaicha kashtam dhan. It took a while for my wife to understand that I am like that! But friends kitta unleashed version dhan.I don’t think so. I work out like crazy for only three months, and do nothing for the next six-seven months. I put on weight and then, it’s back to work out. I eat a lot of sweets. I was shooting with Sunil (Vaibhav’s brother) recently and he got scared seeing me eat — Mysore pak and chocolates in the evening and brownie with ice-cream after dinner. Brownie with ice cream is my stress buster. So, six-pack na psych aayiduven.If a role demands, then I will avoid… that story and do another one (laughs). But on a serious note, if a story really needs me to look like that, then I’ll do it because it’s work for me. I’ll stop ice cream and brownie, reduce carbs and go on a fruits-vegetables-lean meat diet, work out and go on a proper routine. But maybe just for three months!

Title: Raj Deepak Shetty to play antagonist in Allu Arjun’s next
Content: Former TV actor Raj Deepak Shetty is well and truly extending his horizons, having just secured an antagonist role in Allu Arjun’s yet-to-be titled movie directed by Sukumar.Speaking to us, Raj says, “There are three different narratives in the movie. Actors Vijay Sethupathi, Jagapathi Babu and I are the three villains. All three of us share major screen space. This is a pucca commercial mass entertainer that will go on floors in a month's time.” The actor, who is will also be seen in Narappa, the Telugu remake of Tamil film Asuran, adds, “My character, Dorai Swamy, has been rewritten for the Telugu version and gets a lot more relevance in the narrative. The shoot is currently underway in Madurai .”Considering that he is just picking up the nuances of Telugu, Raj has been particular about learning his lines much in advance before shoots. “When I began my career in Telugu cinema , I didn't have a lot of lines. But once I proved my acting prowess, makers began giving me lengthier lines, which, honestly, I am not comfortable with. Having said that, I am a quick learner, so, hopefully I will soon speak Telugu without getting any prompts on the set.”Meanwhile, Raj is also Kollywood bound with Battery , in which he is playing a cop. “It is a medical thriller that revolves around the drug mafia. I play an honest and diligent cop; it is character that has different shades and will give me a new image,” sums up the actor, whose next Kannada cinema outing is Kotigobba

Title: My first shot: The minute the shot was done, they clapped for me, says Balasubramaniem
Content: I have assisted PC Sreeram sir for over seven years and as his assistant, I’ve worked on three films with Kamal Haasan sir. Thanks to that association, I got a chance to debut with a Kamal sir film, and that too, in Bollywood. I’d worked on the Hindi remake of Magalir Mattum — Ladies Only.PC sir solli Kamal kudutha vaaippu adhu. Usually, for a cameraman, shooting a movement is challenging. As luck would have it, my first shot in my first film was a movement scene that lasted for almost three minutes. The character that Nasser played (Randhir Kapoor played the role in the Hindi version) had to reach the office building, take the lift, enter the office, walk through its length and breadth, greet the staff and then finally sit on his chair in his room. I was a little scared because it’s the first time I was sitting in front of a camera on my own. Kamal sir asked me, ‘Mudiyuma?’, and I confidently told him I could.So, I followed the character continuously with my camera and finally switched off when he reached his room. The minute the shot was over, everyone on the set clapped for me. That was a difficult shot and I’ll never forget how excited I was when I pulled it off. Kamal sir had also acted in the film and he’d told me he didn’t want this film to look like the original one. So we could experiment with camera angles.

Title: Aishwarya Rao’s next is a sports drama
Content: Mysuru gal Aishwarya Rao, who made her Sandalwood debut with Baddi Magan Lifu, will next be seen in a female-centric sports drama, Sahara, written and directed by Manjesh Bhagwath Sahara traces the journey of a young girl, who aspires to make a mark in sports. The makers, however, refrain from divulging which sport, to avoid speculation about whether the story is inspired by a real-life tale. The movie also has Ankush Rajath and Achuth in lead roles.An excited Aishwarya says, “Girls living in metropolitan cities are following their dreams, whereas, in rural areas the scenario still has not changed, which we have tried to address in Sahara. I play Jayashree , who hails from a village and wants to make a mark in sports. But she doesn't get adequate support from her parents and friends. The interesting bit about working on this film is that while I play a regular girl in the first half, I need to tone up to sport the physique of a sportsperson. Considering that sports dramas are still rare in Kannada cinema, I am thrilled to be a part of a project like this."

Title: Delhi theatre lockdown more bad news for Bollywood, 'Sooryavanshi' pushed indefinitely
Content: The Delhi government on Thursday closed down all cinema halls in the city till March 31, the latest blow to the film industry reeling under the impact of the coronavirus outbreak with major releases getting pushed indefinitely and all promotional activities at a halt.With hundreds of screens in Delhi, a major entertainment hub and a vital source of profits for the industry, Chief Minister Arvind Kejriwal's announcement led to consternation in Bollywood The release of the much-awaited " Sooryavanshi ", starring Akshay Kumar with extended cameos by Ajay Devgn and Ranveer Singh , has been postponed, Rohit Shetty Picturez said in a statement without specifying another date.The filmmakers said they had taken the decision to postpone the release due to the recent outbreak of COVID-19 "keeping in mind the health and safety" of its "beloved audience"."Sooryavanshi", which was supposed to release on March 24, would be back when "the time is right", the filmmakers said in a statement shared on Twitter by Akshay.Apart from Akshay's "Sooryavanshi", the release of Rohena Gera's love story "Sir" has also been pushed.The film, starring Tillotama Shome and Vivek Gomber, was scheduled for release on March 20.Shiladiya Bora, whose Platoon One Films along with PVR Pictures, was releasing the film in India, shared the news on Twitter."Bearing in mind public health concerns and the advisory from the Health Ministry, we have decided to postpone the release of Sir. We look forward to sharing our film with our home audience in India and will announce an updated release date as soon as possible," Bora said.The release of Hollywood film "A Quiet Place 2", scheduled in April, has also been put on hold. Its director John Krasinski announced Thursday that they will not go ahead with the release now."One of the things I'm most proud of is that people have said our movie is one you have to see all together. Well due to the ever-changing circumstances of what's going on in the world around us, now is clearly not the right time to do that. As insanely excited as we are for all of you to see this movie... I'm gonna wait to release the film till we can all see it gother! So here's to our group movie date. See you soon," Krasinski said.Trade analyst Taran Adarsh said the postponement of "Sooryavanshi" will have a ripple effect on Bollywood's carefully planned release calendar."The impact of coronavirus will not only be here but also in international markets. It's already there to see. Our films release on a wide scale across Australia, UK, Europe and all those markets are severely affected. There is huge cause of concern," Adarsh told ."If 'Sooryavanshi' gets pushed, there will be a ripple effect. Everyone's just waiting and watching. There are huge stakes involved," he added."Sooryavanshi" is not the only casualty.The release of Southern star Mohanlal's "Marakkar Lion of the Arabian Sea" this month has been postponed and there is uncertainty around next month's releases such as the Tamil films "Master" and "Soorarai Pottru".As exhibitors began to assess their losses, industry sources said the release of Kabir Khan's "83" will also be delayed.The trailer release of "83", which has Ranveer Singh playing Kapil Dev, was scheduled for March 11 but it never happened. The film is scheduled for release on April 10 and this could also get pushed."The trailer event was planned but we didn't go ahead with it because of the current scenario. The team hasn't decided anything regarding the release date of '83'," a source said.Kejriwal's move to shut cinema halls, which follows the Jammu and Kashmir administration and the Kerala government's decisions to put theatres under lockdown, immediately affects Irrfan starrer "Angrezi Medium" that was supposed to release on Friday.The other films in the theatres included "Thappad", "Baaghi 3" and "Shubh Mangal Zyada Saavdhaan", which will all be impacted.Film exhibitor Akshay Rathi said Tiger Shroff starrer "Baaghi 3" was the first film to release amid the breakout of the virus and the panic around it has impacted the collections."'It has got good response in smaller towns but not much in metros," Rathi told in Mumbai."The state government of Kerala and Jammu and Kashmir have given directives to shut down theatres but nothing has been conveyed to us in Maharashtra. This is a very sensitive issue. The senior officials have to take a sensible approach in such a scenario as livelihood and money both will be affected," he added.PVR Pictures, the biggest theatre chain in India with 841 screens in 71 cities, said they respect the advisory issued by Kerala, Delhi and Jammu & Kashmir to shut down all cinema halls till March 31 to prevent spread of COVID-19."All of us at PVR have utmost concern for the safety and wellbeing of each of our guests, and in the same context, we fully respect the decision of respective state governments and UT administration. We believe that this is a temporary situation and remain buoyant about the film business in India, and our own growth prospects," their statement read.As the coronavirus scare spreads and fewer people go to halls to watch films, ticket aggregating website BookMyShow said the health and safety of customers is of paramount importance to them."We are closely monitoring the situation and request all consumers to stay safe. We will take all necessary precautions to upkeep consumers' safety and health across our entertainment offerings," a spokesperson for BookMyShow said in a statement.Among the major events postponed are FICCI Frames 2020, the India International Film Festival (IIFA) and the Lotus Makeup India Fashion Week (LMIFW)According to the Union Health Ministry, the number of coronavirus patients in the country has risen to 74.The World Health Organization on Wednesday declared a global coronavirus pandemic.The pandemic had a fallout in the West too.Hollywood star Tom Hanks on Wednesday confirmed that he and actor-wife Rita Wilson tested positive for the coronavirus in Australia where they had gone for the shooting of an untitled Elvis Presley biopic. The shooting of the film has been suspended.James Bond film "No Time to Die" has been pushed to November release from April while the production of "Mission Impossible 7" has been put on hold.The fate of the prestigious Cannes Film Festival hangs in balance with the organisers monitoring the situation.Festival president Pierre Lescure said he is "reasonably optimistic" about going ahead with the movie gala at present, according to The Guardian, which quoted French publication Le Figaro."We remain reasonably optimistic in the hope that the peak of the epidemic will be reached at the end of March and that we will breathe a little better in April," Lescure said."But we are not oblivious. If not, we will cancel," he added.Netflix sources this week said the global tour of their film "Extraction" was called off in the wake of the COVID-19 outbreak. JUR/KKP RDS BK MIN ZMN

Title: Won’t sell BSNL & MTNL, plan to revive them: Govt
Content:
NEW DELHI: At a time when the Narendra Modi government has announced a spree of disinvestment in major public sector companies including industry giants like BPCL, LIC, Air India and more, it has told Parliament on Thursday that it will not go in for selling out or disinvesting state-owned telephone companies BSNL (Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited) and MTNL Mahanagar Sanchar Nigam Limited) and instead has planned for a “revival” of both companies.

The government’s “plan to revive” the two major telecommunication companies will generate some hope in the minds of huge number of BSNL and MTNL employees who have been suffering for more than a year now, with many going without salaries for months.

With both companies reeling under financial crisis, salaries of employees have been delayed for months, leading to strikes by protesting workers. "The government has approved the revival plan for BSNL and MTNL in October 2019,” minister of state for communications Sanjay Dhotre said on Thursday in a written reply to a Rajya Sabha question raised by Trinamool Congress MP Manas Ranjan Bhunia.

The minister, in his reply to a question on “whether government has any plan to sell out or disinvest the BSNL and MTNL” said, “No Sir. Government has no plan to sell or disinvest BSNL and MTNL. The government has approved the revival plan for BSNL and MTNL on 23.10.2019.”

The minister also informed Rajya Sabha that, “78,569 employees of BSNL and 14,387 employees of MTNL have taken VRS (voluntary retirement),” replying to a related question specifically on the VRS scheme in the two companies.

Asked about “the reasons why the rest of the employees are not getting regular salary,” the minister admitted, “Salary of employees of BSNL/MTNL is delayed due to their poor financial condition resulting from revenue and liability mismatch.” He told the House that “BSNL and MTNL have informed that salary up to the month of December, 2019 has been paid.”

The suffering employees of both BSNL and MTNL have gone on strike to protest against the salaries being withheld and other issues in the companies, several times last year and BSNL employees were on a country-wide hunger strike on February 24.

Title: Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar TV show completes the milestone of 250 episodes
Content: There was a special reason for the cast of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar to celebrate this week. Appreciating the efforts of the entire team on the show and marking the completion of 250 episodes, the lead actor of the show decided to have a little celebration by posting a video of their entire episodes journey.Marathi TV series Mahamanavachi Gauravgatha based on the iconic life story of Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar is managing to hook viewers with its compelling storytelling.Starting from his childhood, the show is covering all the important life events and the inspirational qualities of Dr. Ambedkar. Earlier, the show premiered the special episode of Kalaram Mandir Satyagraha and got appreciation from the audience for its interesting screenplay and inspirational story.Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar was an Indian jurist, economist, politician, and social reformer. He was independent India's first law and justice minister and the architect of the Constitution of India as well.Actor Sagar Deshmukh is playing the onscreen character of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar in the series. In a recent interaction with media, Sagar expressed his happiness by saying that he has become rich by playing the onscreen character of Babasaheb. He said, 'It's going to be challenging for me to play the role of Babasaheb Ambedkar.Babasaheb's journey is really inspiring." Talking about the same, the show director, Satish Rajwade said, “Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar's journey from childhood to Mahamanava will be seen in the series. Since TV is a very effective medium, the views of Babasaheb Ambedkar will be deeply rooted.”

Title: Vithumauli to go off air soon; Ajinkya Raut gets emotional on the last day of shoot
Content: Vithumauli’, one of the most popular Marathi devotional daily soaps is going off-air. The show is going to telecast interesting scenes in the end. In the last episode, Vithumauli will disappear by promising his devotees to stand up behind them every time. Saint Pundalik , Dnyaneshwar, Tukaram, Namdev, Tukoba have continued the tradition of saints and the episode will end on this note. The last episode of Vithumauli will be aired soon.The star cast of the series has just finished shooting for the last episode. The lead actor of Vithumauli, Ajinkya Raut got emotional and thanked all his fans on the last day of the shoot. In a media interaction, Ajinkya said, “I will be forever indebted to our producer Mahesh Kothare who saw Vithumauli in me. This role has always been unforgettable for me and it is as precious as a pearl. Money can buy all things, but love can never be bought. This role gave me a huge success and popularity and love of the audience”.The storyline of the show is about Lord Vitthal , a beloved deity and an incarnation of Lord Vishnu transforms Pandharpur into one of the most revered pilgrimage sites in India through his devotee, Pundalik. Needless to say, the team members experienced a gamut of emotions on this occasion. Some felt nostalgic and some got emotional. Vithu Mauli stars Ajinkya Raut and Ekta Labde in the lead roles. The show launched in October 2017.

Title: Disha Patani, Aditya Roy Kapur attend ‘Malang’ success bash, Anil Kapoor snapped in a mask
Content: Team ‘Malang’ hosted a success bash for the film last night and the entire cast was in attendance. Leading lady Disha Patani looked ravishing in a maroon bodycon dress and dramatic eye make-up. Aditya Roy Kapur seemed to be twinning with his leading lady as he was snapped in a maroon casual t-shirt. Anil Kapoor seemed to be taking all the necessary precaution against the Coronavirus outbreak and arrived wearing a mask for safety. Director Mohit Suri ’s wife Udita Goswami and Kunal Kemmu were also snapped at the success party hosted in at a suburban hotel in Mumbai.‘Malang’ opened to a positive response at the box office and earned Rs 6 crore on its first day. In its second week the film managed to cross Rs 50 crore.In an exclusive chat with ETimes, Mohit Suri had revealed that a sequel to the thriller is in the pipeline. “Sequel to ‘Malang’ is definitely on the cards but I cannot confirm at the moment," he had said. Talking about the film's success, Mohit had added, “‘Malang’ is an off-beat film with an ensemble star cast. Despite many big films releasing around it, it is sustaining the weekend after the weekend. Most people had given up on it even before releasing it. So this film collecting Rs 50 crore is more in valuation than the film which does Rs 450+ business at the box-office. The film today has spoken for itself. "

Title: Despite coronavirus, the show must go on – digitally
Content: With hundreds of events, concerts and conferences being cancelled or postponed worldwide due to coronavirus outbreak, the online space has emerged as the safest option to keep the show going. In the last few weeks, many events were turned into ‘digital only’to avoid any health risks.Apart from business launches and conferences that went online to stay on schedule, the art and music world also went digital to reach out to fans despite the threat of coronavirus. Leading the way here was K-pop band BTS which decided to live stream a press conference promoting their new album. Keeping in mind the coronavirus outbreak, the band livestreamed the conference from an empty hall last month and urged fans to take care of themselves, the members waving and bowing to an empty hall and answering previously selected questions from journalists. "Health is always on our mind these days and our messages of facing your inner self and loving yourself is ultimately possible when you’re healthy. Especially since it is very risky outside these days, I hope you take care of your health," singer Jimin was quoted as saying. The K-pop megastars also cancelled four Seoul concerts due in April.As per reports, many K-pop celebrities are resorting to online fan meets and streaming concerts to communicate with their fans. Baek Ye-rin met fans through YouTube livestreaming after her performance in Head In The Clouds festival was cancelled in Jakarta recently and Taeyeon, a member of Girls Generation, decided to have an online fan meet for the release of her new songs.Determined to keep going after the coronavirus forced Venice's ornate opera house, La Fenice, to cancel its performances, recently, a string quartet gathered in the empty, eerily silent theater and played Beethoven, streaming the concert online and winning an ovation of handclap emojis.The outbreak also forced the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra to cancel all of its concerts in February and March, leaving its musicians working from home. They began posting master classes online, along with informal videos showing the players practicing at home and playlists designed to help people under quarantine "fight boredom at home." Closer home, Raja Kumari cancelled her "secret gigs" in Delhi and Mumbai and released her new single online. "For my first ever collaboration with NERVO and Krewella, I had planned a secret gig in Mumbai and Delhi but I opted to cancel it due to the coronavirus outbreak. Precaution is more important than promotion right now for all artists. Unfortunately the event business is getting affected, but I feel artists can opt for more innovative ways to promote their new releases and launches and test newer waters," she says.Raja Kumari who cancelled her gigs in Delhi and MumbaiThis year, the Canadian High Commission ’s annual Women’s Day event, Run For Her, was turned into a virtual run. A statement released a day before the event read, "In light of public health advice cautioning against mass gatherings, this year's Run For Her planned for Sunday, March 8 on the occasion of International Women’s Day will go ahead as a virtual Run for Her. Between now and Sunday, 15 March, we challenge all participants to put on your race kit, get out and do whatever kind of exercise you would like, when you finish, take a selfie or a short video of yourself in your Run for Her gear and post on social media with hashtags, like #RunForHer. To keep the momentum going on this exciting campaign, we will be following up with ongoing social media content." This event was one of the first in Delhi to be transformed into a digital one.Canadian High Commission’s annual Women’s Day event, Run For Her was turned into a virtual run, in which participants posted pictures of themselves with the event’s hashtagIndia Fashion Week, which was scheduled from March 11-15 in Delhi, was postponed last week. Nida Mahmood was one of the designers showcasing at the fashion week, but when the event was postponed, she decided to give a glimpse of her new collection online. "We did plan an event to showcase our new collection and I was also planning to put it on the ramp at the fashion week. But keeping in mind the health concerns, we decided to cancel the event and showcase our collection online. This will help us create a buzz till the time we actually get to showcase our collection. In the current scenario, online platforms seems like an ideal solution for promotions and to spread the word,” says Nida. DJ Sumit Sethi , who had planned an event to introduce his ‘video travel and music diary’, at a club in Delhi is now planning to introduce it on YouTube. “I don’t think delaying the launch is a good idea, so I have decided to first do an online launch and then host a party later," he says.— With inputs from NYT, AFP

Title: Restaurant Review: La Veggie
Content: It’s the acid test. Does the vegetarian, Jain diner approve of La Veggie’s Jain food? After all, the restaurant’s name itself is tightly focusses and targeted. And when my Jain-diner guest Arun Kumar Vyas is also a famous astrologer, face reader and a phenomenon emerging as one of India’s most followed astrologers on Instagram, our restaurant review becomes even more interesting. We eat our way through the menu. Over lunch with him and his family, we discuss his weekly zodiac sign ‘Vyas Card’ predictions on Instagram, which are popular worldwide. His wife Veena and children Rajvardhan and Parth have been vegetarian Jain diners since birth. Based in Malad, the family is very particular about the restaurants they dine in. And, La Veggie is just the perfect restaurant to get their views over an exciting lunch, peppered with fun facts about face reading and astrological predictions.Located in bustling Girgaum Chowpatty, next to a bunch of pure vegetarian eateries, La Veggie sprawls on two floors. The top floor is a banquet hall. Pleasant, cheerful, well-lit space, black and white flooring et al.The most unpredictable favourite? ‘Pao Bhaji Fondue’. That’s the Jain dish that meets with the Vyas family’s approval. We skewer and dip in the wedges of pao into the fondue of mashed bhaji. It’s amazing how flavoursome it is, in spite of being sans onion and garlic. The paobhaji masala infuses it with flavour. Delicious corn cheese balls, spongy deep-fried spheres, topped with salsa. Crisp butter khichiya, too. They offer non-Jain dishes as well. Like the creative and attractively presented nachos chaat. Triangles of nachos are vertically stacked with tangy chutneys and chaat. Chatpata Chinese, too. Non-Jain crisp lotus stem, sweet and spicy.Plenty of intensely flavoured and delicious mocktails, from frozen margarita and pina colada to the almost neon strawberry.An ambitious menu which zig zags all over the world and attempts to cook global classics in vegetarian and Jain avatars. Falters on many. Hard, biscuity crust pizza with lacklustre toppings. Gloopy overcooked pasta. Tasteless channa bhatura (we try the Jain and non-Jain versions and both are equally lacking in flavour). Overspiced chilli pepper paneer. Ditto for the vegetarian biryani. Oversweet desserts, No alcohol.Centrally located, this Chowpatty restaurant, serves up multi-cuisine global dishes in their Jain and vegetarian avatars. A few (like the ‘Pao Bhaji Fondue’) pass the taste test, others (especially the continental ones) flounder. La Veggie offers a huge menu of Jain options and that is its biggest USP. However, even my Jain-diner guests will not go back in a hurry. It’s not worth a second visit.LA VEGGIEGround Floor, Chowpatty View Building, Opposite Sukh Sagar, Girgaon Chowpatty Area, Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel RoadContact: 022 23619393Timing: 11.30 am – 11.30 pmAverage meal for two: Rs.1200

Title: Despite coronavirus, the show must go on – digitally
Content:
Livestreaming concerts and music shows

Raja Kumari who cancelled her gigs in Delhi and Mumbai

Raja Kumari who cancelled her gigs in Delhi and Mumbai

Social campaigns go digital

Canadian High Commission’s annual Women’s Day event, Run For Her was turned into a virtual run, in which participants posted pictures of themselves with the event’s hashtag

Canadian High Commission’s annual Women’s Day event, Run For Her was turned into a virtual run, in which participants posted pictures of themselves with the event’s hashtag

With events getting postponed, Online platforms are helping create a buzz

— With inputs from NYT, AFP

With hundreds of events, concerts and conferences being cancelled or postponed worldwide due to coronavirus outbreak, the online space has emerged as the safest option to keep the show going. In the last few weeks, many events were turned into ‘digital only’to avoid any health risks.Apart from business launches and conferences that went online to stay on schedule, the art and music world also went digital to reach out to fans despite the threat of coronavirus. Leading the way here was K-pop band BTS which decided to live stream a press conference promoting their new album. Keeping in mind the coronavirus outbreak, the band livestreamed the conference from an empty hall last month and urged fans to take care of themselves, the members waving and bowing to an empty hall and answering previously selected questions from journalists. "Health is always on our mind these days and our messages of facing your inner self and loving yourself is ultimately possible when you’re healthy. Especially since it is very risky outside these days, I hope you take care of your health," singer Jimin was quoted as saying. The K-pop megastars also cancelled four Seoul concerts due in April.As per reports, many K-pop celebrities are resorting to online fan meets and streaming concerts to communicate with their fans. Baek Ye-rin met fans through YouTube livestreaming after her performance in Head In The Clouds festival was cancelled in Jakarta recently and Taeyeon, a member of Girls Generation, decided to have an online fan meet for the release of her new songs.Determined to keep going after the coronavirus forced Venice's ornate opera house, La Fenice, to cancel its performances, recently, a string quartet gathered in the empty, eerily silent theater and played Beethoven, streaming the concert online and winning an ovation of handclap emojis.The outbreak also forced the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra to cancel all of its concerts in February and March, leaving its musicians working from home. They began posting master classes online, along with informal videos showing the players practicing at home and playlists designed to help people under quarantine "fight boredom at home."Closer home, Raja Kumari cancelled her "secret gigs" in Delhi and Mumbai and released her new single online. "For my first ever collaboration with NERVO and Krewella, I had planned a secret gig in Mumbai and Delhi but I opted to cancel it due to the coronavirus outbreak. Precaution is more important than promotion right now for all artists. Unfortunately the event business is getting affected, but I feel artists can opt for more innovative ways to promote their new releases and launches and test newer waters," she says.This year, the Canadian High Commission ’s annual Women’s Day event, Run For Her, was turned into a virtual run. A statement released a day before the event read, "In light of public health advice cautioning against mass gatherings, this year's Run For Her planned for Sunday, March 8 on the occasion of International Women’s Day will go ahead as a virtual Run for Her. Between now and Sunday, 15 March, we challenge all participants to put on your race kit, get out and do whatever kind of exercise you would like, when you finish, take a selfie or a short video of yourself in your Run for Her gear and post on social media with hashtags, like #RunForHer. To keep the momentum going on this exciting campaign, we will be following up with ongoing social media content." This event was one of the first in Delhi to be transformed into a digital one.India Fashion Week, which was scheduled from March 11-15 in Delhi, was postponed last week. Nida Mahmood was one of the designers showcasing at the fashion week, but when the event was postponed, she decided to give a glimpse of her new collection online. "We did plan an event to showcase our new collection and I was also planning to put it on the ramp at the fashion week. But keeping in mind the health concerns, we decided to cancel the event and showcase our collection online. This will help us create a buzz till the time we actually get to showcase our collection. In the current scenario, online platforms seems like an ideal solution for promotions and to spread the word,” says Nida. DJ Sumit Sethi , who had planned an event to introduce his ‘video travel and music diary’, at a club in Delhi is now planning to introduce it on YouTube. “I don’t think delaying the launch is a good idea, so I have decided to first do an online launch and then host a party later," he says.

Title: Foods that help boost your immune system
Content: With coronavirus Covid-19 being the talk of the day, much is being said about staying as safe and healthy as possible. While washing your hands, keeping a safe distance from others etc may all be steps to reduce the risk, eating right plays a major role in keeping well, too. One cannot avoid a risk of being affected by the virus, but the right diet is said to support the immune system, so that it is ready to take on anything. Here are a few immune boosting-remedies to load up on...There are several nutrients that you can include in your eating plan and protein ranks high among them at this time. Affirms dietician Sheela Tanna, “Most Mumbaikars are avoiding non-veg because of Corona virus scare and heat. Asian vegetarian food lacks in proteins, which play the role of immunity booster and unfortunately are ignored, too. Every meal must include a protein like dals, pulses (sprouted), paneer, curd, nuts and seeds.”She shares tips to make them. “Make cutlets by mixing paneer with boiled vegetables and spices. It doubles its protein value and can be eaten in burger, sandwich or a roll. Also, mix all the dals and soak, grind and make dosas, chillas, dhoklas or uttapams. You get complete protein (all nine essential amino acids) from vegetarian meals.”The culinary cabinet has a variety of spices that have significant antibacterial and anti-fungal advantages — such as ginger, garlic, cloves, cinnamon, turmeric and cumin, says clinical dietician Zainab Gulamhusein. She gives tips on each:It’s a good idea to include ginger in your milk tea. You can also take lukewarm water and add juliennes of ginger and honey to it. Add ginger to khichdi as well. Ginger plays a powerful role as an antioxoidant. It also reducesbloating and colic pain, too.Brownish cloves or lavang pods are a major part of Ayurvedic medicine. Cloves help treat nausea and flu. Clove oil combats sore gums. To use cloves in the diet, add some to your pulaos and other rice dishes.Haldi or turmeric is almost a super spice having powerful medicinal properties. It is said to increase the body’s antioxidant capacity. Curcumin, its main ingredient has an anti-inflammatory effect. Add it to milk and have it before sleeping. Add it to warm water to reduce itching. Ginger-haldi tea is a remedy for flu. You can use raw turmeric in a pickle form, too.Cinnamon has strong anti-inflammatory properties and can be added to warm water, coffee and desserts. Cinnamon oil reduces aches, joint pains and improves circulation.A popular remedy for colds, it also reduces the risk of blood pressure and heart disease. Raw garlic can be added to juices or as a topping on soups and stews. Mash garlic with olive oil and salt and use it as a dressing.Star anise has antibacterial properties that can keep you away from flu and infections. To make tea, add the pods to hot water, steep, strain and drink. It boosts immunity.Elaborates nutritionist Gunjan Parekh, “Omega-3 fatty acids can reduce inflammation in the body. The lining of the cells is protected by this fatty acid. It thus keeps the immune system in check. It may not directly help with warding off a cold, but it bolsters the immune system, so when there is a viral attack the body is prepared. The omega-3-rich foods include flax seeds (unroasted, powdered) that can be added to soups and salads. Have walnuts and oily fish (such as mackerel and tuna).”One of the best ways to stay healthy is by purging toxins from the system. While eating the right foods helps, one can also optimise the liver functioning and aid the digestive system by drinking healthy detox juices. This in turn, bolsters the immune system. Try chugging down these juices today:Nutrient-dense kale provides one of the best ways to fortify the immune system.Aids blood clotting, boosts heart health and bone developmentHas powerful antioxidants that lower risk of heart disease and inflammationRich source of vitamin C. It also has calcium, which contributes to bone health.Offers antioxidant protection and lowers risk of heart disease and stroke

Title: #CoronavirusConcerns: Royalty, celebs ditch the handshake
Content:
The wave

Namaste

Wuhan shake

Elbow bump

Thai Wai

There’s a lot of dos and don’ts making the rounds as the fear of coronavirus — Covid-19 outbreak spread everywhere. While sanitising hands and sneezing etiquette is key, people are also being advised to avoid shaking hands with anyone as a form of greeting. This has led to several interesting alternatives to say hello cropping up around the world.It started earlier this month when a video surfaced from Wuhan (the Chinese city at the epicenter of the virus outbreak). It showed two men in masks greeting each other by tapping their feet instead of shaking hands and embracing. The video carried the caption: “I love how people can adapt and keep a sense of humour about stressful situations.” Since then, it’s gone viral with a vengeance, getting others to try it.John Magufuli, president of Tanzania, greeted a colleague with a foot-shake. A video also showed Russian energy minister Alexander Novak performing a ‘foot shake’ with an oil company head. It’s also sparking other cool, hands-free ways to greet someone.On the heels of the foot shake is the elbow bump. Bulgarian economist Kristalina Georgieva and World Bank Group President David Malpass bumped elbows at the end of a press briefing on COVID-19 in Washington. The England cricket team will be opting for fist-bumps instead of handshakes during their Sri Lanka tour, starting March 19. NBA players also chose to fist-bump over their signature high-fives to be safe in these times.A Canadian government site recommends an ‘elbow bump’ or a friendly wave as it is “less likely to expose you to respiratory viruses”. It got Hillary Clinton to dub the precautionary elbow bump as the ‘corona shake’. Taking a cue from it, Hollywood actress Sandra Bullock was seen greeting her friend with her elbow in LA, two days ago.Along with the Indian namaste, the gesture of ‘Thai Wai’ which entails a slight bow with the palms pressed together, is also being suggested as a way of greeting people.This March, there were no handshakes from the Queen as she held an audience at Buckingham Palace amid the coronavirus outbreak. Later at the Commonwealth service, the Prince of Wales opted for a namaste, while Harry bumped elbows with musician Craig David. “It’s very odd not shaking hands, I try my best to hold my hands like that,” Prince Wiliam was quoted as saying.Prince Charles also adopted the Indian gesture of namaste to greet guests at the Prince's Trust awards. Last week, Queen Maxima and King Willem-Alexander of The Netherlands, who visited Jakarta on a state visit to Indonesia, also did not shake hands because of coronavirus.

Title: Abir Chatterjee and Arpita come together for Abaar Bochhor Kuri Pore
Content:
Paran

Bandyopadhyay, Sumanta Mukhopadhyay , Anirban Bhattacharyya, and others. At some point in our childhood, we went outside with our friends to play together for the last time and we never knew about it — the film Abaar Bochhor Kuri Pore dives into the same pool of emotion.

Nila

is estranged in her own life of husband, kids, and household chores. Dutta is the only one currently based in Kolkata and perpetually planning for a long-pending reunion. “How these set of friends based in different cities beat all odds and come for the reunion is something special to look out for in the movie,” said the director.

Title: AR Rahman: Whenever we think that we know something new, that ‘something new’ stagnates
Content: Bombay Times caught up with music maestro AR Rahman at a recent event where he spoke about the need to keep reinventing oneself, his new fashion choices, the popularity of Korean music and his daughters, Khatija and Raheema, who have stepped into the music industry.Bidding adieu to his all-black attire, Rahman has been upping his fashion game. His latest music video saw him making an entry on the screen in shimmery silver shoes. The ace musician and composer credited his wife, Saira Banu, for his styling. He said, “She would complain a lot about my outfits and styling. So, these days, I just accept whatever she picks because it makes her happy. She has friends in New York and Los Angeles and suitcases full of clothes keep coming home (laughs!).”The Oscar-winning composer recently worked on a project where he had to mentor other musicians. Talking about the time when he was being mentored years ago, Rahman told us, “I have been mentored a thousand times. First, it was my Carnatic music teachers and my father (RK Shekhar). Then, there were people like Mani Ratnam and Shekhar Kapur. Also, there was Andrew Lloyd Webber (English composer), who believed that I could write music. The idea is to always keep learning. Whenever we think that we know something new, that ‘something new’ stagnates. Inquisitiveness and the constant search for knowledge are what keep you going; without that nothing exists.”Rahman says that since he started his training in music early in his life, he had a hard time as a student in school. “I was a bad student, because I was also working when I was studying in school. I would often get scolded for my poor attendance. I would work through the night, and in the morning, I would be at the studio,” he recalled.Rahman, who has won two Grammy Awards for Slumdog Millionaire (2008), said that the prestigious international music award is just the roof, and one should aim for the sky. Citing the example of the Korean music industry, he said, “There is this famous saying, ‘Aim for the sky and you will reach the ceiling. Aim for the ceiling, and you will stay on the floor.’ One should have high aspirations and be ambitions. Look at the way Koreans are spending millions on marketing their music, and today, their music is almost mainstream. Everybody is talking about BTS — the South Korean boy band! I don’t even understand that music, but it’s so popular. Now, they seem to have taken over the movies, too, what with Parasite winning big at the Oscars.”Like his son, AR Ameen, Rahman’s daughters, Khatija and Raheema, are also musically inclined. Last year, they performed on the stage for the first time with their father at the U2 concert in Mumbai. “They are taking music more seriously now. They never expected to be on stage along with me at the U2 concert. We are a musical family, and I believe that their musical education is very important. So, after me, they can take forward what I began,” he signed off.

Title: Theatre review: Even Mists Have Silver Linings
Content: Jeffrey Pufahl, Victor Thoudam, Will WeiglerLauren Robinson, Anmol Oberoi, Dipika Pandey100 minutesEnglish4 starsAddressing the societal stigma and discrimination against India’s LGBTHQIA+ (where the ‘H’ stands for HIV+ people) community, thought-provoking narratives run parallelly in this play, leaving you with a bucket full of emotions.They questioned themselves, more than anyone else. They died from within, everysingle moment of their lives. And then, they rose together, louder than before, gracefully fighting to rekindle the dwindling light of hope. ‘ Even Mists Have Silver Linings ’ encapsulates this struggle of the LGBTQIA+ community, and it does so beautifully through a series of emotionally-charged vignettes.A dark, minimalistic set awaits the audience. And on the misty stage, sitting upright, are seven powerful actors who effortlessly don multiple hats, one after the other. Using symbolism as a tool, the gender non-conforming adventurists drive the plot with their heart-wrenching monologues. There’s confusion looming in their minds, for they struggle to comprehend their own emotions. What makes this play painfully inspiring is how they come to terms with everything despite the chaos.The collaborative efforts of Jeffrey Pufahl, Victor Thoudam, Will Weigler and Vikram Phukan yields great results in terms of how they have hand-picked multiple stories and weaved them together into this one sharply executed play. Music and lighting have been used effectively to transition from one scene to another. Among the series of tales, there is one that traces the journey of a transgender parent who is shunned by his family. A woman, in another scene, shares an intimate moment with her neighbour, and begins to question her sexual orientation. Then, there’s a husband who loses his wife to another woman. Amid all these episodes, the charmingly humourous characters discuss mythology, gender fluidity, emotional unavailability and a lot more. Overall, ‘Even Mists Have Silver Linings’ is a play that touches every aspect that divides and confines thecommunity.This 100-minute long drama is an Indo-US collaborative project, aiming to sensitise people towards the LGBTQIA+ community, and it is promising enough to start a relevant dialogue, and hopefully, bring about a positive change in the society.

Title: Bollywood actresses talk about their super-dads!
Content:
Director Homi Adajania’s Angrezi Medium , as the film’s trailer shows, revolves around the herat-warming bond between a father and daughter. Champak Bansal (Irrfan), a doting dad, goes all out to fulfil his ambitious daughter Tarika’s (Radhika Madan) dreams while dodging the hurdles that come along the way.While the trailer has received a thumbs up from viewers, it also seems to have grabbed the attention of the doting daughters of Bollywood. Ahead of the film’s release, Anushka Sharma Kriti Sanon , Kiara Advani, Ananya Panday and Radhika Madan talk about their bond with their dads and tell us why they think of their fathers as super-dads!

Anushka Sharma: I can cry at the drop of a hat when I am talking about my father, that’s the kind of love I feel for him. He has always let me be. The only advice he gave me was to do the right thing in life. He didn’t put any boundaries around me. I hope every girl can have the same kind of relationship that I share with my dad.

Alia Bhatt: My super-dad moment happens every day. My father makes it a point to send me a message every morning; it is always something that he’s read — a quote or a picture that he has come across. It makes me realise how fantastic my father is and how he cares to pass on these little words of wisdom.

Kiara Advani: My dad’s my superhero. He’s the reason I am in the film industry; without his support, I wouldn’t have had the confidence to be who I am. So, thank you, dad. Thank you for helping me fly and being the wind beneath my wings. Love you always.

Kriti Sanon: I don’t think that there is any one incident that I can pinpoint. My father was scared when I came to Mumbai to try my luck in films, but he still supported me like a rock. To this day, even for a small issue like my WiFi not working, the first thing I do is call my dad. He sorts all my problems out and that’s why he is my super-dad.

Ananya Panday: My dad is a super-dad. Throughout my growing-up years, he has done more than I could ever imagine, for both my younger sister and me. He is constantly smiling and joking and is an inspiration because he has always been himself and lets me be, too. Whenever people say that I’m like my father, I feel that it’s the best compliment somebody can give me.

Radhika Madan: When I first received a call from Mumbai, asking me to give an audition, my mother was skeptical. It was my father who supported the idea and came along with me. He stood outside production houses whenever I gave auditions. His only concern was if acting would make me happy. Once he realised that it would, he supported me unconditionally and that’s what makes him a super-dad.

Title: Not just creative, now go eco-friendly with sustainable gift-wrapping
Content: As people are increasingly leaning towards a more eco-friendly lifestyle, sustainable gift-wrapping is another green practice that some have adopted. Last year, before Diwali and Christmas, sustainable gift markets were organised in multiple cities wherein workshops were conducted to teach people to reuse material for wrapping gifts. Chintan, an environmental research and action group based in Delhi, states that plastic – the fastest growing industry in India – accounts for 49% of all packaging material, becoming the single largest packaging material. Therefore, it is important to go for sustainable gift-wrapping not just during festivals but for birthdays and anniversaries as well. Wondering what materials you can use? Here’s your guide to sustainable gift-wrapping:Those who encourage and organise sustainable practices in their societies say that in the last two years, the trend in gift-wrapping has shifted towards sustainable options. Ruby Makhija, a 47-year-old opthalmologist and resident of Navjeevan Vihar, who teaches her society members to use household items for gift wraps, says, "Not just individuals, but even corporates prefer eco-friendly options for gift wraps. Just by looking around at home, one can find several gift-wrapping options. Extra items at our homes can also make for beautiful customised wraps." She adds, "We advise people to use newspapers for packaging because they are the best gift-wrapping alternative. Additionally, pages from discarded books and music sheets can also be used as gift wraps. Colourful washi tapes can also be used to add some colour."Brown paper, baskets, mason jars can also be used for wrapping gifts. Sarthak, a 35-year-old software developer, who volunteers for such workshops, says, "Now, a number of shops use brown papers for grocery packaging, and they can be decorated with ribbons for gift wraps. Also, baskets are a sustainable option for gifts because these can be re-used. Rather than buying ribbons, look for washi tapes as these decorative washi tapes come in a wide range of patterns, colours and are a sustainable alternative to ribbons. Cartons and cardboard boxes can also be reused and decorated instead of using a wrapping paper. If the box is plain, it can be embellished with decorative items."28-year-old Chhavi Pandey, who works for a company that provides customised gifts and gift wrap options shares, "There are numerous gift-wrappingalternatives. For instance, Furoshiki is a Japanese wrapping cloth used for packing, and it has become quite popular in India recently. For Lohri and Diwali, we had several requests to wrap gifts using cloth. If one is doing it at home, they can use scarves because they make for pretty options."- Newspapers are the best choice for gift-wrapping. You can also use red threads and ribbons to make it look fancy. One can also use jute threads.- Discarded music sheets and pages from old books also make forsimple yet creative and sustainable packaging.- Old clothes and scarves can also be cut to make gift wraps. You can even get multiple gift wraps from the same piece of clothing.- Unused paper cups can be creatively cut and used as add-ons.- Brown paper bags used for buying groceries are also an alternative.
