Both were discharged on Thursday night.In another development, health officials shifted the nine suspected patients of Covid-19 from Yavatmal to the lone isolation ward in Yavatmal Government Medical College on Thursday afternoon. Their swab samples were dispatched to Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH or Mayo) and reached there by evening.Sources said that the German tourist is from Munich. She landed in New Delhi and went on to visit Agra and Jaipur (Rajasthan). She was on her way to Tadoba jungle safari when she developed fever, cough and cold.A woman from city who travelled to Italy in February had admitted herself to GMCH on Wednesday evening. She was also tested negative. By Thursday evening, samples of nine suspects from Yavatmal reached IGGMCH.Ten persons from Yavatmal were in the group of 40 tourists that included the Pune couple which tested positive after returning from Dubai. One tourist from Yavatmal who had left for Pune after reaching India was tested positive. He is admitted at Pune’s Naidu Hospital.Following orders from principal secretary of health department, the remaining nine tourists were shifted to the isolation ward in Yavatmal GMC, informed district civil surgeon Tarangtushar Warey at a press conference which was attended by dean Dr Milind Kamble. District health officer (DHO) Balasaheb Chavan was conspicuous by his absence.Tarangtushar said that a 100-bed quarantine facility has been set up in the Minority Community Girls Hostel on Dhanangaon road.When asked if they have taken any details about people these nine tourists might have contacted, the civil surgeon said there is no need for it but added that the incubation period is 0-14 days.Yavatmal collector MD Singh has invoked the Crisis Management Act in the district from Wednesday. He has designated Warey and Chavan as the coordinators of the committee.Yavatmal GMC dean said that he has put on hold the the annual social gathering of the college.

Title: Telangana CM K Chandrasekhar Rao nominates Keshava Rao and Suresh Reddy for Rajya Sabha berth
Content:
CM K Chandrashekar Rao with former speaker KR Suresh Reddy on Thursday

HYDERABAD: Eighty-year-old K Keshava Rao got third-time lucky as TRS president and CM K Chandrasekhar Rao chose seniority and decided to send him to the Rajya Sabha again to fill one of the two vacancies from state. Former assembly speaker KR Suresh Reddy, who jumped into TRS from Congress just before the assembly polls, was the other nominee.

With this, speculation over KCR’s daughter, former Nizamabad MP Kalvakuntla Kavitha entering the Upper House as one of the TRS’s nominees has ended.

Three months shy of his 81st birthday, Keshava Rao, popularly known as KK, was a member of the Rajya Sabha twice from AP (2006-2012 and 2014-2020). KCR on Thursday handed over B-forms to KK and Suresh, who would file nominations on Friday. Since TRS has enough numbers to win both the seats, their unanimous election will be a mere formality.

KK joined TRS in 2013 after a long stint in Congress. He was PCC chief in the undivided AP and was made Rajya Sabha member on Congress ticket. In the second term, he became MP on TRS ticket in 2014 while continuing as party secretary general. “Taking his seniority into consideration, the party leadership (read KCR) has decided to give him another opportunity,” a senior party leader averred. KK served as a cabinet minister in three consecutive governments in undivided AP and held key portfolios like education, industry and labour.

On the other hand, Suresh, who was a four-time MLA from Balkonda constituency in Nizamabad, was initially fancied to get an MLC berth from Nizamabad.

Title: Congress caught in its own illusions, says Harish Rao
Content:
Hyderabad: Finance minister T Harish Rao on Thursday said Sunday’s budget broke the illusions of Congress in many ways.

The minister, who was caught in a war of words with CLP leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka while taking part in a debate on the Budget, said Congress had not learnt from its mistakes. “They thought that due to economic slowdown, the government may not be able to make big allocations in the budget, but chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao has told us not to cut even a single rupee. We have made more allocations for more beneficiaries,” he said.

He said the allegation that TRS extended benefits to people only during elections was false. “The CM introduced Rythu Bandhu and Kalyana Lakshmi which were not in our poll manifesto. During your (Congress) regime, it was ‘current bandh’ (power cuts) for farmers. But, in our time, the CM introduced Rythu Bandhu,” he thundered. People have been teaching Congress lessons in every election, but they do not understand,” he said.

The minister also said the state would continue to borrow and spend it on capital expenditure and not on revenue expenditure.

Title: CCTV shows 5 men breaking into iPhone shop in Bengaluru
Content:
The gang broke into a mobile phone shop and walked away with 54 iPhones worth 32 lakh

BENGALURU: A day after 54 iPhones were burgled from a store in Gandhi Bazaar , Basavanagudi , verification of CCTV footage from an adjacent building showed a gang of five men targeting the shop .

The gang decamped with 54 mobile phones worth Rs 32 lakh, Rs 2.1 lakh in cash and digital video recorder of CCTVs from iAstra, an authorised iPhone dealer, which is a part of Arjay Retail.

Complainant Dipesh HP, owner of the shop, and jurisdictional Basavanagudi police said iAstra is an authorised iPhone dealer. The TOI report on the burglary (March 12), mentioned iAstra as a resale shop, based on information provided by police. It has since been learnt that the store only sells boxed handsets that are new.

Two CCTV footage that run for 10.5 minutes and 8.2 minutes, respectively revealed the burglary took place between 4.30am and 5am on Tuesday. TOI has a copy of the videos. In the footage, the gang of five is seen wearing caps. While one of them stands guard on the road, four others carrying backpacks reach the store. They are seen carrying equipment needed to break into the store.

‘Gang made multiple attempts’

Of the four, three start breaking the lock, while the fourth one is seen bringing out a bedsheet. He holds it as a cover, preventing passersby from seeing what the other three are up to. The activity suddenly pauses and the men leave the spot only to return within minutes. “In 30 minutes, the gang made multiple attempts to enter the shop and succeeded only in the last try. One of them entered the shop and came out with the loot a few minutes later, after which they all fled the spot,” a police officer said.

The dog and fingerprint squads examined the crime scene on Tuesday morning. Shop owner Dipesh submitted to police a list of the stolen devices, the models and international mobile equipment identity (IMEI) numbers.

Police have formed a team to trace and nab the miscreants.

Title: Ganga task force using seed balls to raise forest cover
Content:
The team has been working for afforestation by using ‘seed balls’

PRAYAGRAJ: The Ganga Task Force (GTF), the Territorial Army team of 137 Composite Ecological Task Force (CETF) Bn (TA) 39 Gorkha Rifles, entrusted with the mandate of conserving the Ganga basin is also working to rejuvenate the lost forest cover through afforestation and thereby minimising soil erosion. The team has been working for afforestation by using ‘seed balls ’ — soil along with equal amount of clay, humus and ash in the shape of a ball and having two-four seeds of some indigenous trees at the centre. The seed ball is around two inches in diameter.

Since its raising on May 2019, the task force has manufactured over seven lakhs seed balls out of which 6.4 lakhs have already been scattered on the fallow land. The seed balls are distributed among pilgrims, farmers, students, organisations, army units etc. in Prayagraj, Kanpur and Varanasi.

Colonel Amit Pande, in-charge GTF said, “We have four machines at our unit, each having the capacity of manufacturing 10,000 seed balls per day. About 2-4 seeds of indigenous trees are kept in the mix of soil, clay, humus and ash and given shape of a ball, which is then dried.”

“Each seed ball has a survival period of 11 months. As soon as it gets get some moisture, the seed starts sprouting, drawing nutrition from the enclosing mix of soil, humus and ash and germinates into a plant,” said Col Pande, who has been decorated with Nau Sena medal. The unit has used seeds of 26 different indigenous species, including jackfruit, guava, bel, arjun, aaonla, blackberry, in these balls to ensure a variety of flora.

Title: Govt inks pact to develop responsible tourism in MP
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: The Kerala model of Responsible Tourism , which changed the face of state tourism and strengthened the local community involvement in tourism, is expected to make an impact in other states as well in the near future.

In spite of the Covid-19 outbreak, which is causing havoc in the sector worldwide, an agreement has been signed between the state tourism departments of Kerala and Madhya Pradesh for developing responsible tourism in the ‘central province’ of the country. And, considering the international recognitions and accolades the Kerala RT (Responsible Tourism) Mission has been receiving over the last couple of years for its activities, more states are expected to follow suit, say state tourism officials.

Tourism minister Kadakampally Surendran has already announced in the Assembly about the pact, which is aimed to implement RT in Madhya Pradesh. “Activities of RT Mission in Kerala is the best example of participatory approach in tourism sector. It is a proud moment that Madhya Pradesh is starting RT with the guidance and support of Kerala Tourism,” the minister said.

Pact was signed between state tourism secretary Rani George and Faiz Ahmed Kidwai, the principal secretary to CM and tourism department of Madhya Pradesh. State RT Mission coordinator Rupesh Kumar K will be the nodal officer for Kerala while Manoj Kumar Singh, the director Madhya Pradesh tourism board will be the nodal officer for the state. The agreement is valid up to 2022.

Title: Barring a few questions, maths turns to be simple
Content:
Nagpur: The students of Maharashtra state board solved maths I paper with ease on Thursday. The questions were entirely based on textbook and related to the course. Students who had enough practice did not find difficulty in solving the exam, while it gave a tough time to a few.

Speaking to TOI, students said that the exam was fairly moderate. Harshita Kokode, a student of St. Ursula School, said, “I found the exam to be tougher than I expected. I solved all the questions, but found question no. 5 to be the most difficult. As the fifth question was difficult, it consumed a lot of my time.”

Her batchmate Krutika Markam said, “Though I finished the exam before the time limit, I found question no. 5 difficult. Rest of the questions were comparatively easier and I’m expecting good results.”

Another student from St. Ursula Samiksha Mahajan said the exam was neither too difficult not extremely easy. She said, “Excluding the last two questions (including the 5th one), other ones were much simpler. Each question was from the textbook or related to the concepts that we had done before, which made it easier.”

While Aaaif Hussain from Anjuman High School had trouble solving many questions, his batchmate Arman Khan could solve the exam without any problem and way before the time limit.

Hussain said, “I found the question on quadratic equations difficult. Lengthwise, the paper was appropriate and I managed to finish it on time.”

Khan said, “It was very easy. I managed to complete it 15 minutes earlier. Everything was from the syllabus and all the questions were very easy.”

Expressing joy after solving the exam well, Kritika Gupta from St. Joseph’s Convent said, “I finished my paper before time. I did a quick recap of the formulas before the paper which helped me a lot. Every question was easy from the syllabus.”

Paper rating

Toughness: Easy

Questions’ relevance: Based on textbook

Length: Appropriate

Title: City-based man still stranded in Rome
Content:
Coimbatore: With the Indian embassy in Italy shutting down its consular services on Thursday, city-based software developed Srinithin Jayabal is left with no other option but to stay put in Rome for some more days.

Jayabal with 14 other Indians were stopped from taking a flight on March 10 from Rome to India after the Indian government wanted to ensure that all the passengers carry a Covid-19 negative certificate to board the flight.

Jayabal says they have nearly become refugees in Italy because neither the Indian government is allowing them to return nor it is ensuring that they are taken care of.

The businessman says that the hotline offered for emergencies by the embassy does not work and people must dial 20 to 30 times to even reach them. “The only reply given by the embassy to us is that they have taken up the issue with the health ministry to get us an exemption or that we just have to spend more time in Italy. Why can’t the government quarantine us for 14 days or more after we reach home?” He says there are more than 45 Indians stranded like him in Rome. tnn

Title: We don’t want ‘thieves’ tag any more: Telangana Rashtra Samithi MLA
Content:
HYDERABAD: What’s in a name? But, a 24-year wait yearning for a change in the name of their village was more than enough to raise the hackles of the villagers and the MLA representing them.

TRS’s Parkal MLA Challa Dharma Reddy had the assembly in splits on Thursday when he said they have had enough of the endless wait for officials to change the name of Dongala Singaram village to Pragati Singaram. Dongala in Telugu is an offensive word meaning thieves and Dharma Reddy hails from the village.

Raising the issue during the zero hour, Dharma Reddy, a two-time MLA, said the village panchayat had passed a resolution in 1996, which was later approved by the then district collector of Warangal . “But, the new name is not reflecting in the official records since the government has not issued a gazette notification. And it has been 24 years since a resolution was passed,” he said.

The MLA, who won the first term on a TDP ticket, said locals feel shy to even utter the name of the village since they consider it as a stigma. Imploring chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao , the TRS legislator said: “The chief minister should take a call on our plea and resolve the issue immediately,” he said. The chief minister was not present in the house when Dharma Reddy was making an impassionate plea.

He said he had raised the issue in the assembly thrice but no corrective action had been taken. “While for communication and non-official purposes, locals have been using the name of Pragati Singaram, for government records such as pattadar passbooks, revenue records and other communication Dongala Singaram name is still being used by the officials concerned,” Dharma Reddy told TOI later.

He further said thanks to confusion over the village name , there have been instances of passport applications getting rejected by the authorities. “A government notification is mandatory for making any changes in the names of villages,” he explained.

The village now falls under Bhupalpally constituency after the delimitation exercise. Former speaker S Madhusudhana Chary represents the seat. “Even I brought the issue to the notice of Chary, but the name of our village has not been changed in the official records,” Dharma Reddy rued.

Title: Sree Chitra hosp introduces curbs
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute for Medical Sciences and Technology (SCTIMST) will implement a series of measures with immediate effect to minimize the risk to the patients, staff and visitors to the hospital in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak in the state.The number of surgeries and procedures in the hospital shall be reduced till the end of the public health issue. The appointments for elective visits (non-emergency cases) shall be rescheduled.The intimation of the new dates shall be sent to the registered mobile number of patients. These measures are essential to reduce the crowd in the hospital and to channelize the infection control mechanisms in the best possible manner.Entry of visitors to the hospital (OPD as well as inpatient areas) will be restricted to one person per patient.All visitors are requested not to bring children to the outpatient department or to the ward, unless they require treatment in the hospital.All entry points to the hospital shall have thermal detectors to screen patients and visitors for fever.Any visitor or bystander with symptoms of fever, cough, running nose, breathlessness or sore throat shall not visit the hospital in order to minimize the risk of transmission.Any patient referred for treatment in SCTIMST from other hospitals should report any symptom mentioned above to the information centre near the entrance, immediately upon arrival.There is a shortage of blood and blood products in the hospital. The hospital authorities have appealed to voluntary donors who do not have history of travel to Covid-19-affected areas and do not have contact with affected patients to donate blood to the hospital.

Title: Tall tribute: G+12 tower to house teachers at MNNIT
Content:
Prayagraj: Without teachers our lives would have no class. So, in a towering tribute to mentors who fire imagination of students and instil in them a love for learning, Motilal Nehru National Institute of Technology (MNNIT) will raise arguably the region’s tallest building to house teachers on its campus.

The Union HRD ministry has already sanctioned a corpus of Rs 40 crore for the G+12 building with a total 48 flats, which will boast all modern amenities.

“The ambitious project has received the Centre’s go-ahead and funds. The central public works department (CPWD) will complete construction within the next 30 months,” said MNNIT director Rajeev Tripathi.

The new building will come up on a swathe of land on the campus that already houses a hostel for students, living quarters for teachers and the NIT guest house, among others. “Each of the 48 flats will boast a 3BHK floor plan while the tower will be equipped with a wide stairway, elevators and firefighting arrangements,” the director said.

Professor Tripathi maintained that the institute had long been facing an accommodation crunch for teachers because of which a detailed project report was prepared and sent to the Union ministry for approval and sanction of funds. “We received the nod recently. Construction will begin at the earliest,” he said.

Currently, the MNNIT has 223 teachers against 362 sanctioned posts of professors, associate professors and assistant professors. A recruitment process is underway to fill up the 108 vacant posts.

“We must hence overcome the accommodation crisis to ensure both old and new teachers are allotted quarters as per their entitlement,” Tripathi added.

Title: Museum, zoo and tourist spots shut down
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The city switched to shutdown mode with events being postponed and temporary closure of tourist spots in the wake of Covid-19 alert. Public entry will be blocked to museum and zoo following a directive issued by district collector K Gopalakrishnan to close down museum and zoo till March 31.The authorities said that no restrictions will be imposed on joggers who come to museum premises in the morning and evening, however, there has been a significant dip in the number of people turning up for morning walk. The sitting scheduled by district police complaint authority for March 21 and 28 has been postponed. Planetarium will also be shut down till March 31.Prayer and public preaching timings at Vazhuthacaud juma masjid will be revised from 12.45pm to 1.10pm starting from Friday.APJ Abdul Kalam Technological University has postponed the Tech Fest 2020, scheduled to be held from March 27 to 29 at College of Engineering, Trivandrum. The new date will be informed later, said a statement from the university.Following state government order on restriction on public gathering Queerythm LGBTIQ community cancelled its future monthly meeting until further notice. Community members, volunteers and allies are strictly restricted to gather and meeting public places on behalf of Queerythm and are also advised to avoid Queerythm representations in events.Indus Cycling Embassy, a collective of cyclists based in the city, has cancelled all its night ride for next two weeks till March 31.Tourist entry won’t be allowed at Peppara and Aruvikkara dams, Siva park and water treatment plants till March 31.

Title: Komatireddy wants TPCC chief post
Content: Hyderabad: Congress MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy on Thursday fancied his chances to succeed Uttam Kumar Reddy as new TPCC chief. He met Congress president Sonia Gandhi in Delhi and said Congress in state needs a new leadership to fight KCR and his family. tnn

Title: Nine-year-old Unnao girl who was raped, strangled, cremated amid rage and grief
Content:
KANPUR: The body of the nine-year-old girl who died after being sexually assaulted in the fields of a village in Unnao while villagers were celebrating Holi, was cremated on Thursday afternoon amidst an outpouring of anger and grief by family members and locals, who demanded the severest punishment for the perpetrator.

On Thursday morning, the victim’s family refused to cremate her till chief minister Yogi Adityanath came and assured them of strict and swift action against the guilty. They also demanded compensation for girl’s parents. The child’s body was brought home from the mortuary late Wednesday.

The girl had died on Tuesday night at Lala Lajpat Rai Hospital after excessive bleeding from her private parts. The girl had gone to attend the ‘phaag’ singing programme on Tuesday afternoon, when she was raped by an unidentified man.

Senior government officers, including district magistrate Ravindra Singh and superintendent of police Vikrant Veer visited the girl’s home in Bihar police station area to pacify the family.

The family agreed to perform the last rites after negotiations with the DM and senior police officials. The DM handed over a cheque of Rs 5 lakh as ex-gratia compensation to the kin. “We have assured support to the family and promised that the accused will be arrested soon,” he said. The autopsy report confirmed death due to excessive bleeding.

The last rites were performed at the girl’s ancestral farm, 300m off the village amid tight security. Leaders of Samajwadi Party, including MLC Sunil Sajan, were present.

The girl’s kin said the accused responsible for her death should either be hanged or ‘chased and gunned down’ like the Telangana case, where four rape accused were shot by Hyderabad Police.

Talking to TOI, ASP (North) Unnao Vinod Kumar Pandey said, “Four teams are working for an early breakthrough. We have picked up a few suspects for questioning to ascertain the identity of the perpetrator. An FIR under relevant Sections of IPC, including rape, murder and sections of Pocso Act has been registered.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: State to form panel to help turmeric ryots
Content: Hyderabad: Agriculture minister Singireddy Niranjan Reddy conducted a review meet with MLAs on Thursday to review measures taken to support turmeric farmers. He said that the state government will appoint a committee to prepare a report on measures to help the farmers. “The Centre has failed to provide market facilities to the farmers and the committee will submit the report to the CM soon,” the minister said. tnn

Title: Be in Haridwar on March 20 to save Ganga, says India’s waterman
Content:
Dehradun: Environmental activist Rajendra Singh, also known as the ‘waterman’ of the country for his work in water conservation, reached Matri Sadan ashram in Haridwar on Thursday and met ashram head Swami Shivanand Saraswati, who is on a fast-unto-death since past 72 hours to protect the river.

After meeting the seer, Singh urged environmentalists from across the world to reach Matri Sadan on March 20 “to formulate a strategy to save the river from mining mafias, hydropower plants and pollution.”

Addressing mediapersons, Singh said, “We want everyone to participate in Ganga satyagraha that will be started by Swami Shivanand Saraswati on March 20. We will also commence the task of formulating a strategy to save the river which is struggling to save itself from immense anthropogenic pressure. In spite of ban on construction of dams on upper reaches of Ganga, the government is going ahead with its plans. This is a threat to the existence of one of the largest water resource of the nation.”

Meanwhile, seer Padmavati who had been fasting for over 90 days for the Ganga cause, continues to be in the ICU of AIIMS-Delhi. Sources at the ashram said she is suffering from neurological problems and is unable to speak or move.

Title: T releases Rs 93 crore as devpt fund
Content:
Hyderabad: After making a budget provision for the constituency development fund (CDF) for 2020-21, the state government on Thursday released Rs 93 crore CDF for 140 MLAs and MLCs.

The amount was released for the works which had been sanctioned and taken up during 2018-19. After December 2018 assembly elections, the government had not released CDF for 2019-20. In Thursday order, the government said the funds cannot be used for new works. tnn

Title: 3 Mumbai-bound trains affected by block: SCR
Content:
Aurangabad: Rajya Rani Express and Nandigram Express stand cancelled due to traffic block to be undertaken in the Kalyan-Kasara section for various infrastructural works, an official release by South Central Railway (SCR) said on Thursday.

Nanded-Mumbai CST (Train No. 17611) Rajya Rani Express and Nagpur-Mumbai CST (No. 11402) Nandigram Express will not ply on Friday. The return journeys of these two trains for Saturday also stand cancelled.

Also, Secunderabad-Mumbai CST (No. 17058) Devgiri Express will be regulated in Bhusaval division on Friday. Expressing regret over inconvenience to be caused to the passengers, SCR authorities said passengers who have booked their tickets for trains to be cancelled will get their refunds.

The announcement of cancellation, which has allegedly come on a short-notice, has irked railway activists.

“The railway authorities are communicating about cancellation of trains barely before 48 to 72 hours. The traffic block is planned well in advance and therefore it makes no sense to announce cancellation of trains on such a short-notice. The poor communication is bound to cause huge inconvenience to the passengers as all cancelled trains witness huge crowd every day,” railway activist Raj Somani said.

When contacted, SCR officials blamed the Central Railway over the issue. “The Central Railway did not communicate us about the traffic block in advance,” a senior SCR official said.

Meanwhile, the SCR has announced permanent augmentation of Purna-Patna-Purna Express (Nos. 17610/17609) with one AC III Tier coach and two sleeper class coaches.

Title: Awareness about menstrual hygiene
Content:
A session on menstrual health and hygiene in progress

On the occasion of International Women’s Day, NGO Sahyog Foundation , in association with the civic response team, a private organisation and Canpack Pvt Ltd., conducted menstrual health and hygiene session in corporate offices and colleges.

More than 300 women were benefited by this drive, said Sanveer Chhabda, founder of Sahyog Foundation. “In the awareness session, we sensitised the women attendees on keeping personal hygiene and also about eco-friendly sanitary products which are safe for users and for environment,” she said.

Title: CORONAVIRUS SCARE: AIR TRAVEL TAKES A BIG HIT
Content: Nagpur: The coronavirus scare has affected international traffic at the Nagpur airport. Sources in the airport said the passenger traffic has come down by 36% as compared to normal times.Two international carriers — Air Arabia and Qatar Airways — operate from Nagpur.A senior official in the airport management said Air Arabia has cut down its operations to two flights a week from the earlier four. Even as Qatar Airways continues to maintain its seven-day-a-week frequency, its passengers have come down to an average of 40 to 45 in a single flight as against 60 to 65 earlier.“The overall decline in terms of passengers through international flights comes to around 36%,” said the official.Screening of passengers continues at the airport. Special measures have been taken for the CISF personnel too who are at risk of direct exposure to the passengers while frisking and carrying out other security procedures.“The personnel have been provided with safety equipment like sanitisers, gloves and masks according to the safety guidelines issued to us,” said a senior official in the CISF.

Title: Lieutenant governor does not have unfettered discretion:CM
Content:
Puducherry: The Madras high court has directed the Centre, the administrator (lieutenant governor) and Puducherry government to work within the framework of the Constitution of India, the Government of Union territories’ act, 1963 and Rules of Business of the Government of Pondicherry, 1963, said chief minister V Narayanasamy. Narayanasamy while commenting on the order at a press conference on Thursday said the high court has directed all authorities (the Centre, the lieutenant governor and the Puducherry government) to exercise their powers under the Constitution to fulfil ‘sovereign will’ of the people.

Narayanasamy claimed that as per the existing rules and regulations, the administrator can act only as per the aid and advice of the council of ministers and cannot outrightly reject any proposal or direct the authorities to act otherwise. But the administrator can call for clarifications on the proposals from the secretaries concerned, who can submit information to the administrator through the chief minister. If differences of opinion persist between the administrator and council of ministers, the administrator can refer the issue to the President, said Narayanasamy.

He said the high court while observing Centre’s comments declared that ‘discretion’ of the administrator does not mean ‘unfettered discretion’. “The word, ‘discretion’ does not mean unfettered discretion and rather should be read as ‘judicious discretion’ to eliminate any sense of misunderstanding about the word, ‘discretion’, he quoted the order.

Narayanasamy said the high court also cautioned the Centre to act within the limitations of the Constitution and not beyond the same, subject to the laws made by the Parliament. “…the popularly elected government headed by the chief minister and the administrator/lieutenant governor of Puducherry shall work in unison and not in division,” he said quoting the order.

He said the bench also cited relevant portions of the Supreme Court judgment in the case between NCT of Delhi and Union of India.

“if a well-deliberated legitimate decision of the council of ministers is not given effect due to an attitude to differ on the part of the lieutenant governor, then the concept of collective responsibility would stand negated,” Narayanasamy said quoting the Supreme Court order.

He said the high court declared that the ‘will of the people is the only legitimate foundation of any government and to protect its free expression should be our first object’.

He claimed that the high court declared that the popularly-elected government of Puducherry, no doubt, represents the will of the people as Edmund Burke said, ‘In all forms of government, people are the true legislators’.

Title: Coronavirus in Rajasthan: Rajasthan health department declares Covid-19 an epidemic
Content: JAIPUR: The health department declared coronavirus an epidemic in the state and issued the Rajasthan Epidemic Disease, Covid-19 Regulations (REDCR), 2020, on Thursday.The notification has been issued two days after an 85-year-old citizen, who returned from Dubai, was allegedly refused treatment by three private hospitals on March 8. He later tested positive for Covid-19 on March 10 at Sawai Man Singh (SMS) Hospital.A private family doctor of the patient too failed to report the case to health authorities. He had gone to the doctor’s clinic for treatment on March 2 and March 8, increasing the risk of infecting others in the city.Taking it as a major lapse, the health department has declared Covid-19 an epidemic and made it mandatory for each doctor in the state to report such cases immediately to health authorities. “It is mandatory for government and private hospitals and registered private medical practitioners , including Ayush practitioners, to notify such persons to concerned district surveillance units along with duly filled self-declaration forms about those patients in their knowledge having a travel history of Covid-19 affected countries,” the REDCR says.

Title: Surprisingly easy maths exam boosts students’ confidence
Content:
Nagpur: Maths is generally one of the most daunting subjects and students prepare throughout the entire year for the exam. However, the exam held on Thursday provided a huge sigh of relief to the Std X CBSE students . They said that the exam was easy, to the point and 100% from the prescribed NCERT syllabus.

Bhavesh Choudhary from St Pauls School said the paper was indeed easy. “I had opted for standard maths. Section C was the easiest but section D was a little bit of a challenge. Thankfully, the time was sufficient to complete the exam.”

Shujat Qureshi, a maths teacher at Central India Public School (CIPS), also agreed that the exam was easy. “Everything was from the NCERT book. If the students studied it, they should have been able to crack the exam. The exam was a confident booster. Some of the students also told me that they could finish the exam in just two hours. They are all expecting to pass with flying colours.”

Rishabh Chandak from BVM said he was able to finish the exam an hour before the stipulated time. “All the sections were pretty easy and straightforward. I am quite optimistic and expecting high marks this time.”

Shruti Anchalwar, also from BVM, said the final section was a tough nut to crack. “Apart from that, the exam was very simple and easy, especially the MCQs in section A.”

It was completely opposite for Anchalwar’s batchmate Shrushti Joshi. “Section D was the easiest and the MCQs in section A were challenging. However, I was able to finish the exam in time.”

Himanshu Lalwani from Delhi Public School found section B tough. “Other sections were relatively easy and I am confident that I will score good marks.”

Paper rating

Toughness | Easy

Questions’ relevance | Straightforward

Length | Appropriate

Title: Pon Radhakrishnan welcomes Rajini’s move to enter politics
Content:
Salem: Former Union minister Pon Radhakrishnan on Thursday said actor Rajinikanth was always welcome to make his entry into politics. “Everyone expected and wished that he would join the BJP. But he announced that he will float a new party of his own. So, it wasn’t appropriate for us to ask him to join us,” he said.

The BJP leader, however, said Rajini had made a blunder by helping the DMK to come to power in the state in 1996. “But he proved in that election that he has enough influence among the masses to help one grab the chief minister’s post.”

Pon Radhakrishnan was in the city to attend the wedding reception of BJP functionary ‘auditior’ V Ramesh’s daughter Smirithi, who got married to Harish alias Adiya Janardhanan, recently.

He also used the occasion to appeal the Muslims not to believe the DMK on the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) issue. “It won’t affect the Muslims. The Congress and the DMK are gearing up to create riots among the Hindus and Muslims. They are still using the 1967 election formula today.”

Earlier, Telangana governor Dr Tamilisai Soundarrajan had on Wednesday said talks were on between Tamil Nadu and Telangana regarding the Cauvery-Godavari river linking project and tourism related development works. “I will act as a bridge between the two states in all the development projects and schemes.”

She was also in the city to attend the wedding reception. Tamilisai said she was proud to read out Thirukkural during the assembly session in Telangana, recently. “While I am the governor of Telangana, I am still a daughter of Tamil Nadu.”

State BJP general secretary Vanathi Srinivasan, meanwhile, said the party had proved its guts by appointing L Murugan, a scheduled caste, as the state president. “None of the political party will do like this. The BJP has given respect to scheduled caste people by appointing Murugan the party state president.”

Title: HC interventions upheld justice for Puducherry: Bedi
Content:
Puducherry: The intervention of the Madras high court has upheld the justice for the Union territory of Puducherry on several occasions, said lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi.

Bedi while listing out the occasions said the high court in the last two years intervened and fixed the fees charged by the private medical colleges, and granted voting rights for nominated MLAs and facilitated the direct transfer of funds in the bank accounts of the beneficiaries' besides upholding the mode of appointment of state election commissioner (SEC).

The latest order of the bench of Madras high court on Wednesday asserted the role of the lieutenant governor as a bridge between the Union territory and the Centre, she said.

"The first judicial intervention was of capping of exorbitant fees being charged by private medical colleges. This intervention ensured relief to aspiring and deserving students and parents from run-away fees which were being charged by private medical colleges. (This decision is leading to systems change around the country. It's a process)," she said.

Bedi said nominated MLAs secured a judicial order with voting rights to exercise their rights and responsibilities as members of the legislative assembly. "This makes them active members of the assembly to represent the people," she said.

The judiciary again directed the Union territory to comply with the directions of the Centre to implement the free rice scheme under direct bank transfer (DBT) mode transferring the cash equivalent of rice to the bank accounts of the beneficiaries. The high court order also confirmed the Union territory status of Puducherry.

Similarly, in another order, the judiciary has affirmed the fairness in the open process to select the SEC. "The selection of SEC to be by open selection and not the nomination. This ensures professionalism in the open selection of the commissioner for conducting local body elections. (Being held after a gap of 10 years). This affirms fairness in all selection process," she said.

The latest judicial intervention reaffirmed the supremacy of the Parliament-enacted Union territory act and the Business rules with clarity in their applicability and accountability. The order overturned Madras high court single judge verdict, which led to divergent interpretations.

"...judiciary interventions arrived at a considerable time-energy of the Central government, Puducherry administration, eminent legal luminaries and precious time of the honourable courts. We thank them all," she said.

Bedi expressed optimism that the reiterated judicial clarity will help the administration to take decisions expeditiously based on existing procedures to serve the Union territory better.

Title: Corporator starts covering half-built nullah
Content:
Aurangabad: Corporator Kailash Gaikwad on Wednesday initiated the work of laying covers over the constructed part of a nullah in the Jai Bhawani Nagar area of the city. The work of construction wall of the nullah was stopped due to lack of funds.

Incidentally, the work of construction of nullah in the Jai Bhawani Nagar area was taken up by the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) in 2016. However, the work was delayed due to various reasons in the last three years.

In June 2018, the nullah had started overflowing after a spell of heavy rainfall. A local resident lost his life after falling into the nullah.

According to AMC engineers, the construction of retaining wall of 570 metre stretch of nullah has been completed. The stretch of the nullah in lane number 8 and 9, totalling 150 metres length, is still pending. The contractor awarded the project has stopped the work for the last one year as his payment has been stalled by the municipal corporation.

The nullah becomes a virtual death trap during every monsoon when it overflows due to rainwater. People residing in houses closely constructed on both sides of the nullah fear falling into it as it is left open.

On Wednesday, Gaikwad, an independent corporator from the Bharat Nagar ward, initiated the work of laying covers over the open end of the nullah. When asked, Gaikwad said that everyone knows about the financial situation of the AMC. “Hardly a fortnight ago, a child had fallen into the open stretch of the nullah. Locals of the area sought help and, therefore, I am spending from my pocket to cover the nullah instead of endlessly waiting for the civic body to do something about it,” he said.

Rahul Ingle, an activist of Shahar Parivartan Aghadi, said that the municipal commissioner should release money for the project. “The AMC has received money in property tax and it should not wait until next monsoon causes mayhem in the area,” Ingle said.

AMC executive engineer Hemant Kolhe said that he will visit the site on Thursday and will take necessary action.

Title: College comes up with low-cost sanitizer
Content: T’puram: Amid the helter-skelter dash for sanitizers in the city, a hand sanitizer developed by college of pharmaceutical science in the medical college campus has become an instant hit.The low-cost sanitizer, which has been distributed to various departments of medical college hospital, is made as per standards of World Health Organization. A statement issued by the medical college said that the sanitizer is made of alcohol, hydrogen peroxide and glycerin. The 80% alcohol content makes it more efficient that those commonly available in the market, it said.The pharmaceutical college had earlier brought out such sanitizers during the spread of SARS, bird flu and floods.The teachers, headed by Prof Mary Mathew, decided to make hand sanitizers in the wake of spread of Covid-19 . The production is more significant at a time when hand washing is suggested as the most efficient measure to prevent the spread of the virus.The sanitizers available in market would cost Rs 300 per 100ml. The college made a new set of sanitizers from the remaining alcohol provided by excise department during the floods last year to make sanitizers. As the alcohol was available free of cost, the cost of productions was reduced to just Rs 35 per 100ml. The teachers contributed for the remaining expense.The college has taken steps to increase production of sanitizers. It has submitted a proposal in this regard to the Kerala Medical Services Corporation. If approved and alcohol is made available from excise department, the college hopes that it could venture into mass production.Washing hands frequently using soap or sanitizer is considered as the most effective measure to check spread of Covid-19. Medical experts advise use of sanitizers which has minimum 60% alcohol content.

Title: Court orders police to release man arrested in serial murder case
Content:
Salem: Judicial magistrate K S Siva on Thursday directed police to release M Andisamy, 22, of Sitheriyur village in Dindigul district, from three murder cases that triggered shock waves in the city in the first week of February.

The JM also directed police to admit him to a de-addiction centre.

Pudukottai-based Rajesh Kumar recently gave a confession statement to the Pudukottai police while he was interrogated for a robbery case on March 6, that he had murdered three persons in Salem and had stolen money from them to buy ganja.

Based on his confession statement, the Salem city police went to Pudukottai and arrested Rajesh Kumar on March 7 and took him to Salem on the next day. They also lodged him at Salem central prison under judicial custody. Meanwhile, they had approached the JM’s court seeking its direction to remove Andisamy from the murder cases.

The court after reading the petition, directed the commissioner of Salem city police T Senthil Kumar to release Andisamy from the cases.

“We will keep Andisamy under police custody for two days to check the reason for admitting the crimes,” a senior police official, who was part of the investigation team said, adding that after two days of custody, the police official will admit him to a de-addiction centre in the city.

Title: Isolation wards set up in all 8 districts of Marathwada
Content: Aurangabad: In wake of coronavirus outbreak in the country, all eight districts of Marathwada have reserved isolation wards for any suspected or positive cases. The guidelines regarding the same have been issued by the state public health department.According to divisional commissioner Sunil Kendrekar, patients are being quarantined if they show symptoms and their swabs are immediately sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune for testing. “The arrangements for quarantine and isolation wards are made at the GMCH, municipal bodies and at private hospitals. All district collectors have reserved funds in case of emergency for purchasing equipment or other machinery. Municipal commissioners are also advised to be on high alert and they are also co-ordinating with the health machinery,” Kendrekar said.In Aurangabad , a 22-bed isolation/ treatment ward with two ventilators has been set up in the Cardio Vascular Thorasic Surgery (CVTS) building at the GMCH. The tertiary care institute has been asked to increase the number of beds to 100. GMCH dean Kanan Yelikar said that the hospital is considering using nephrology building in the GMCH premises for setting up additional isolation wards.Aurangabad district health officer Amol Gite said that quarantine wards have been set up at Chikalthana-based health centre of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) and the district civil hospital at Chikalthana.In Beed, isolation wards have been set up at the GMCH, Ambajogai, and at the district civil hospital, district civil surgeon Ashok Thorat said. In Jalna, 25 isolation beds have been set up at government and private health facilities, district health officer Vivek Khatgaonkar said. “20 rooms in vacant ITI hostel building are being turned into isolation wards. Nanded district collector Vipin Itankar said that isolation wards have been set up at GMCH, women hospital and civil hospital in the district. Enough N-95 masks and PPE are available, he said.Latur GMCH dean Girish Thakur said that 37-bed isolation ward with two ventilators is ready at GMCH Latur along with 100 sets of PPE, 1000 N-95 masks.

Title: Be thorough with NCERT book, solve bio paper easily
Content:
Biology is a descriptive subject. Nevertheless, it is possible to get high scores just by following some easy steps. It is extremely important for students to be thorough with the NCERT textbook to be able to answer questions with ease. Revise the contents of each and every topic and sub-topics thoroughly from the NCERT text, diagrams and flow charts.

Students should lay more stress on the seventh, sixth and tenth units which have high weightage of marks, followed by the other units. Students should be calm and composed and use the reading time to get themselves acquainted with the paper and plan the answers which will help them manage time.

According to the latest CBSE sample paper, there will be 27 questions in all, divided into five sections. All questions are compulsory. There is no overall choice in the paper. However, internal choices are provided.

Students must be particular about spellings of key terms and names of biological species being underlined. They must use diagrams wherever required to highlight concepts. Diagrams should be drawn with correct proportions; overlapping or cross labelling should be avoided.

They should use examples and flow charts wherever necessary to help the examiner get a better overview of the concepts. Number the questions and their sub-parts correctly. Descriptive answers should be written in bullet points, using a simple language with the key words underlined.

I wish each of them good luck for their exam.

(The writer is a teacher at Centre Point School, Katol Road)

Paper snapshot

Subject: Biology

Board: CBSE, Std XII

Date of exam: March 14

Duration: 3 hours

Total theory marks: 70

Last-minute revision tips

Pay attention to the details of diagrams

Focus on spellings of key terms

Revise topics and sub-topics from NCERT thoroughly

Title: Indians from Iran to reach Jaisalmer Army stn today
Content: JAISALMER: Indians airlifted from Iran will be brought to Jaisalmer military station in the first phase of evacuation and quarantined at the base here, according to defence sources.The Air India flight with approximately 120 Indians evacuated from Iran will reach the military base on Friday.The military has started preparations to help the administration to deal with the threat of coronavirus epidemic. An isolation ward has been set up at the military station. More Indian are expected to arrive from abroad on March 16. A team of Army doctors from Pune, Delhi, Jaipur have come to oversee the operation. A meeting was held by Army and Air Force officials to inspect the preparedness. A special screening for those who arrive will be held at the Jaisalmer civilian airport.

Title: Coronavirus: Ganga Mela to be held on March 15 amid precautions
Content: KANPUR: Despite the threat of coronavirus , Ganga Mela celebrations and Rangon Ka Thela will be carried out in the city as per the tradition on March 15, said Gyanendra Bishnoi one of the organisers of the event.He said, floral tributes would be paid to the revolutionaries on March 15 morning followed by ‘Rango ka Thela’ which would pass through various localities of the city.On drawing advisory issued by the sports ministry regarding one day international match at Ekana stadium in Lucknow slated to be held on the same day, he said that the evening functions of Ganga Mela would be held as per the schedule, however, he added that there would be no large gathering during the procession of ‘Rango Ka Thela’ as people throw water on it from roof tops. People will have to take precautions during evening function to be held on the banks of the Ganga, he said.“We are not issuing any appeal in that regard,” he added.DM Dr Brahmadev Ram Tiwari said the administration has not received any advisory from the state regarding the Ganga Mela function. Since it is a matter of tradition, the administration would not issue any appeal, he added. The administration, however, continues to creat awareness about the virus, he added.

Title: Condition of 16-yr-old boy continues to be serious
Content: Aurangabad: The condition of a 16-year-old boy — suspected of coronavirus infection and admitted in the isolation ward of Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) — continues to be serious, said GMCH medical superintendent Suresh Harbade.The patient had travelled to Uttar Pradesh and reached Aurangabad by train on Wednesday. With complains of breathlessness and fever the patient first reached to GMCH on Wednesday evening.After preliminary inspection, the patient was taken in an ambulance with a resident doctor to the Chikalthana district civil hospital where his swab sample was taken and sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune.Harbade said it takes around 72 hours for the reports to come. “The swab was sent on Wednesday evening and the report is likely to come on Friday evening or Saturday morning. The patient is serious but his condition has not deteriorated since yesterday. He is not on ventilator,” he said.“He is showing symptoms of pneumonitis and chest infection and considering his travel history, the hospital administration is considering him a Covid-19 suspect. The protocol issued by the state government on the management of suspect cases is being followed,” he added.

Title: Domestic air fares see a dip as wary travellers keep away on corona scare
Content:
Chennai: It is cheaper to fly to Bengaluru from Chennai than take the Shatabdi Express as spot airfares crash to less than Rs 1,000 one way as scare of COVID 19 has driven away flyers. A Chennai-Bengaluru trip on Shatabdi costs Rs 845 on chair car and Rs 1,415 on executive chair car. A one-way trip on air for a spot travel to Bengaluru from Chennai is just Rs 999.

Similarly, a Mumbai-Delhi one way trip is just under Rs 2,500 or more than 20% less than rates from 2 weeks ago, going by data from travel portal ixigo. New Delhi-Bengaluru flights are 16.8% cheaper. “Some popular domestic routes have seen a 20%-25% decrease in last minute fares on account of falling oil prices. Airlines are also refraining from increasing prices at the moment as they pre-empt a weakening of demand on the domestic side,” said Aloke Bajpai, CEO, Ixigo. Delhi-Hyderabad is seeing a 30% drop while Chennai-Delhi is seeing a 22% dip. However, this drop in airfares has not improved the traveller sentiments. While until 2 weeks ago, travellers refrained from international vacations and made domestic bookings, the fresh scare of new infections in India has weakened domestic demand too. Travel companies are seeing a 20%-35% cancellation queries and a drop in bookings. Travel portal Cleartrip, whose airfares see an aggregate drop of 12% for domestic routes sees a dip in bookings. “Early trends of summer travel seem subdued, with bookings seeing a 15%-20% drop for domestic vacations. And it is not just to the destinations where there are higher number of infections, the overall caution is reflecting in a drop in bookings,” said Balu Ramachandran, senior vice president, Cleartrip.

Yatra.com sees airfares go down by upto 40% in the affected destinations. “Customers are wary of making fresh bookings to the affected locations and airfares to these destinations have dropped by over 40%. We have also received close to 35% cancellation queries from travelers planning their trips to foreign locations during the holiday season,” said Sabina Chopra, COO, Yatra.com.

Title: Extend 10% EWS reservation in civil posts, Centre to Pondy
Content:
Puducherry: The Union home ministry has directed the Puducherry government to extend 10% reservation to economically weaker sections in civil posts and services. The council of ministers in August 2019 rescinded the government order passed on March 5, 2019, by the department of personnel and administrative reforms extending 10% reservation for EWS.

However, lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi did not approve the council's decision and referred the issue to the Union home ministry. The ministry examined the matter and passed an order directing the chief secretary Ashwani Kumar to continue with 10% reservation for EWS.

Advisor to the Union territory (home) Jitendra Agrawal in an official communication to chief secretary directed the Puducherry government to continue with the 10% EWS reservation in civil posts and services as per the Union social justice and empowerment ministry's office memorandum dated January 17, 2019, and Union personnel, public grievances and pensions ministry's memorandum dated January 19, 2019.

Under-secretary to Puducherry government (personnel and administrative reforms) V Jaisankar in an official communication on Monday directed all secretariat departments and heads of the departments to follow the government order passed on March 5, 2019, reserving 10% for EWS in civil posts and services.

This is one of the several instances of the Union home ministry endorsing the views of Bedi. The ministry in December last year endorsed Bedi's suggestion to select the state election commissioner (SEC) through a transparent, competitive and fair process inviting applications through an all India advertisement.

The ministry said the selection of SEC must be made by a selection committee headed by the chief secretary. It said Bedi may finalize the composition and terms of reference of the selection committee. Bedi had referred the issue to the ministry following a difference in opinion with the council of ministers on the mode of selection of SEC.

Earlier, the ministry endorsed Bedi's suggestion and directed the Puducherry government to continue with direct benefit transfer (DBT) scheme of transferring cash equivalent of rice directly to the bank accounts of the beneficiaries instead of distributing rice free of cost to the ration cardholders through the fair price shops.

Bedi and council of ministers were on the loggerheads over the mode of implementing the free rice scheme. Bedi insisted DBT mode while the council preferred to distribute rice free of cost to the ration cardholders through fair price shops.

Title: 21 more under observation
Content: T’puram: The district health administration put 21 more people under observation as part of Covid-19 surveillance on Thursday. As many as 815 people were screened in the district till date and 160 people are under observation in homes.Two people are under observation in the isolation ward of General Hospital and three people are under observation in the isolation ward of Medical College Hospital.As many as 197 samples were sent for tests and 145 results were received and all results were negative. Results are pending for 52 samples. As many as 2,856 passengers, who arrived in the airport, were screened on Thursday. Eight persons who showed symptoms of disease were referred to medical care and 79 people were screened at the domestic airport.The district administration and health wing have been conducting awareness campaigns on social media. Those who were found to require mental support were contacted over phone and necessary instructions were given. It was also decided to keep all passengers coming from Italy in isolation wards. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Uttarakhand: All schools shut till March 31
Content:
Representative image

DEHRADUN: All schools, including primary and secondary ones in Uttarakhand would remain closed till March 31, in order to prevent the spread of Covid-19 among children.

A directive signed by R Meenakshi Sundaram, state school education secretary, late on Thursday, said,“All schools in the state will remain closed till March 31 in view of the coronavirus pandemic. The educational institutes where examinations are being held will however be open till the examinations are completed.”

Government sources said that the students who are scheduled to appear for their board exams can attend them in their designated examination centres as no change has been done in the schedules. Ranveer Singh, regional officer of the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE)told TOI,“The CBSE board exams will be conducted as scheduled. All our examination centres will operate as they were doing so. We have not yet received any orders to make any sort of changes due to the coronavirus threat. The students who are supposed to appear for the board exams can follow the schedule given to them.” Uttarakhand has become the second state after Delhi to announce the closure of schools due to the fear of the spread of the coronavirus. The Delhi government has also ordered shutting down of cinema halls and educational institutes. The number of affected patients in the country has risen to 74 with 14 fresh cases, including a foreign national. Recently, the World Health Organisation declared coronavirus a pandemic.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Kochi: Importers and exporters stare at Rs 15-22 crore loss in coming months
Content: KOCHI: As Covid-19 is disrupting the routine life of Malayalis and driving down the footfalls in local shops, away from the public eye, there is a serious crisis going to hit Kochi’s economy as the import-export business through Cochin Port has been severely affected due to the ongoing global pandemic.The import of commodities and goods from across the world through the port during January 2019 was 9,963 TEUs (twenty-foot equivalent units, that is, the unit of the capacity of a container ship), but came down to 8,684 TEUs in January 2020. Further, it came down to below 7,000 TEUs during February 2020.The current decline in imports through the Cochin Port and the expected fall in exports during the coming months will result in a loss of business of $2-3 million (Rs 15-22 crore) to exporters and importers (exim community) of Kochi, says the Cochin Chamber of Commerce and Industry (CCCI).“Exports haven’t been affected so far but it will be affected during the next month or so. The Kuwait port is already closed and Bahrain will be closed soon. As most of our exports are to the Middle East, it is going to affect us,” said V Venugopal, president, CCCI.Venugopal said the decline in imports is troubling as it is going to affect exports also. “Imports and exports are inter-linked. Unless containers from outside reach Kochi, we won’t be able to export from here. For example, there might be some thousand empty containers sitting in Dubai, which you couldn’t bring over here to export our products, because it will be an additional cost and such actions wouldn’t sustain in a competitive market,” he said.In fact, ports have started facing container shortages and freight rates have been going up. The surplus containers for the trade comes from China.“The major area to be affected in the current crisis is China and two thirds of our imports through Cochin Port are from that country. We know that Chinese imports are not going to come during the next month also. So, you may have goods to export and there might be demand also, but you will not be able to send them unless there is supply of containers,” Venugopal said.As much as 20,000 TEUs arrive a week to India from China and that has come down to almost 6,000 TEUs.During January 2019 Kochi received 2,806 TEUs, equivalent of 2,806 twenty-foot containers from China, which came down to 2,474 TEUs this January, a decline of 332 TEUs. It is the same case with other major import sources also.Similarly, South Korea had sent 378 TEUs in Jan 2019, which declined by 163 TEUs. Striking was the decline in imports from the UAE – the imports came down from 1,323 TEUs in January 2019 to 1,006 TEUs in January 2020, a decline of 317 TEUs.The impact of Covid-19 on the industries and businesses in India is yet to unfold fully, said Antony Thomas Kottaram, director, Kottaram Trading Company, Kochi. “We will not be spared from the global economic slowdown which is expected to hit us in near future,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan: Two Congress MLAs lambast Ashok Gehlot govt for ‘inaction’
Content:
Ashok Gehlot

JAIPUR/JAISALMER: Amid the political storm in Madhya Pradesh triggered by Jyotiraditya Scindia ’s move of quitting Congress and joining BJP, two Congress MLAs of Rajasthan lambasted the Ashok Gehlot-led government on Thursday. While Todabhim MLA Prithviraj Meena expressed his anger by saying Gehlot’s ministers were acting like “kings”, six-time legislator Hemaram Chaudhary , who now represents Gudhamalani, went on to threaten resignation as he was “losing his patience”.

Meena said no minister in the Gehlot government paid heed to issues and problems raised by him. He alleged that ministers were acting like “kings” and it was high time Gehlot took them to task.

Questioning the functioning of the government, Meena said, “The situation in Rajasthan is not any better compared to Madhya Pradesh as nobody listens to the MLAs. Crops have been badly damaged and the government has not yet announced any package. There are some ministers who consider themselves to be above the chief minister and act like kings.”

This is not the first time Meena has made statements against his own party and government.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Man stabbed to death, case lodged
Content:
Representative image

KANPUR: A 45-year-old farmer was stabbed to death while he was sleeping oustside his house in Chhibramau area of Kannauj district on late Wednesday night.

Police identified the deceased as Ram Veer Yadav of Natha Nagla village of the district.

According to police, the incident took place when Ram Veer was sleeping outside his house.

The farmer’s 16-year-old son Pradeep claimed the murder to be fallout of a brawl which took place between his father and a group of villagers in the evening on the same day, said an official privy to the investigation.

Police have sent the body to the district hospital for postmortem. “Based on the complaint, a case has been registered against unidentified persons. Raids are underway to arrest the accused,” said inspector Chhibramau Shailendra Kumar Mishra.

Title: Gang hacks Tasmac bar attender to death
Content:
Salem: A Tasmac bar attender was hacked to death and another was indiscriminately stabbed by a six-member gang near Edappadi here on Wednesday night following an altercation with a customer over damaging a partition wall in the bar. The Edappadi police have registered a case and launched a manhunt for the gang members.

A police officer identified the deceased as K Ramamurthy, 32, of Avathipalayam village. He was working as an attender with a local bar that was attached to the Tasmac outlet in Thanneerdasanur village.

“On Wednesday night, S Durairaj, 30, of Poomaniyur village and his friends came to the bar. As he was consuming liquor by leaning onto the partition wall, which was made of hollow bricks, that suddenly collapsed,” the officer said.

Ramamurthy, along with another bar attender P Annamalai, 30, of Avathipalayam, argued with Durairaj, who fought with the duo. “Meanwhile, other customers in the bar intervened and pacified the trio,” said T Thangavel, deputy superintendent of police, Sankari division.

Around 10.30pm, Durairaj, along with five accomplices, came to the bar again and hacked Ramamurthy and Annamalai indiscriminately. “Ramamurthy succumbed to his injuries on the spot, while Annamalai was critically injured,” the DSP said.

When alerted, the Edappadi police rushed Annamalai to the Government Mohan Kumaramangalam Medical College and Hospital in the city, where he is battling for life.

Police have registered a case and launched a search for the gang.

Title: Systematic study of chapters will do the trick
Content:
The most systematic manner of studying is to do it chapterwise. While doing so, I would suggest students to write all the important properties , statement of theorems and formulae in a separate paper and revise it often.

While solving the question paper, utmost attention should paid while writing the terms ‘similar’ and ‘congruent’. Similar is not congruent. While naming similar triangles, be careful of the correspondence.

Appollonius theorem is applicable to triangles only when the median is given. The chapter on circles has many properties and theorems. Learn the application to numerals.

For questions on construction, students should draw a rough figure with measurements first to get an idea about what kind of figure needs to be drawn. Sometimes, an analysis of problems also needs to be written.

In co-ordinate geometry, negative co-ordinates should be substituted carefully. Prepare well about properties of triangles and quadrilaterals.

In trigonometry, draw a neat labelled figure before attempting the questions. Identities and standard values should be learnt.

In the questions related to mensuration, read the questions carefully by checking the units and note down the data given for a better insight about the question. Students should keep in mind to use proper conversion scale before solving the problems.

You should be very careful while noting down the data given in the question paper. I would strictly suggest not to assume any data which is not given in the question paper while solving.

I wish all the students best of luck and hope they excel in exams.

(The writer is a teacher at St. Joseph’s Convent)

Paper snapshot

Subject: Maths 2

Board: SSC, state board

Date of exam: March 14

Theory marks: 40

Duration: 2 hours

Last-minute revision tips

Go through the points chapterwise

Organise your work while writing the paper

Attempt all the familiar questions first and then go for what is unfamiliar to you

Number the questions properly in your answersheet

Title: Hosur cut roses go waste as coronavirus hits exports
Content:
Krishnagiri: Once home to colourful and fragrant roses, what welcomes one to Hosur today is the sight of withered and dried up cut roses. Out of business for the past one month, the lives of cut rose exporters too are equally faded.

According to the cut rose exporters, they are facing a loss of nearly Rs 2 lakh a day as the Gulf and other foreign countries have banned the import of goods from India in the wake of coronavirus (Covid-19) outbreak. As there are no takers for the flowers, which can’t be preserved for long, they end up in garbage bins, instead of flying abroad to lit up the moods of several hundreds.

Famous for cut roses, Hosur grows varieties such as red giant, red horizon, red corvette, happy hour, passion royal class, red palace, bohemia, discovery, gold strike, rimini high society, tenga venga bugatti, king fisher, apricot kiwi and avalanche classic and duet across more than 1,000 acres. The main export markets are Gulf, Europe, Japan, Southeast Asia, Australia, Middle East and Russia.

N Ahmed, an exporter, said, “The roses grown here are in high demand abroad. The flowers will be sent to all these countries throughout the year. The demand is usually high during the Valentine’s Day, when the export crosses more than 1.5 crore cut roses.”

Pointing out that they usually export four lakh cut flowers a month abroad from Bengaluru, the exporters said they hadn’t clocked any business after February 14. “The business totally depends on exports. Following the ban imposed by the Gulf and other countries, the export has come to a standstill in the region,” an exporter said.

According to them, the demand for the flowers has taken a dig in the local markets too. “We will not get good rates as this is not a marriage season. Usually, we sell a bunch of 10 gerbera flowers at Rs 150 in the local market during the festival and marriage seasons. At present, it is priced at Rs 12. We are not even getting the production cost.”

Title: Bihar intensifies coronavirus vigil at Nepal border, 71 isolated
Content:
Representative image

PATNA: Even as the World Health Organization has declared Covid-19 a global pandemic, the state government has rolled out measures across Bihar to contain the virus threat, keeping a strict vigil at the airports and districts bordering Nepal.

Seven additional directors of the state health department have been given the charge of the districts bordering Nepal — Madhubani, Sitamarhi, East Champaran, West Champaran, Kishanganj, Araria and Supaul — which are under special surveillance owing to a positive case of the virus in Nepal.

As part of these measures, all 38 districts have been provided isolation facilities at the nearest medical college and hospital and altogether 144 suspected cases of novel coronavirus have kept in isolation so far. Of these, 73 people have completed their 14-day quarantine. The remaining cases are still being monitored by the state health department.

Four senior health department officials been given additional duties at isolation wards of medical colleges and hospitals in four cities, including Patna, Bhagalpur, Gaya and Darbhanga.

State health department officials have issued advisory that those who have arrived from Covid-19 affected countries should self-isolate at home. “They should not go out in public gatherings irrespective of their status of being symptomatic or asymptomatic. People with similar symptoms should immediately call 104 or visit nearest government healthcare centre,” state surveillance officer Dr Ragini Mishra said.

She added, “Since the symptoms of Covid-19 are quite similar to viral fever, people even with a normal cold or cough raise their queries on the helpline number that has been provided to them. A total number of 786 calls have been received regarding the enquiry of the virus from February 5.”

According to health officials, as many as 52 samples of Covid-19 suspected patients from the state have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune. Sample of a suspect, who was admitted in the isolation ward of Patna Medical College and Hospital (PMCH) was sent to NIV on Thursday. “As of now, we have received five suspected cases of Covid-19 at the PMCH. Of these, four have tested negative. Test result of the remaining case is awaited,” a senior doctor at the PMCH said.

Meanwhile, three more cases were detected in Bettiah on Thursday. “Of these, one suspect is from Lauria, Majhaulia and Narkatiaganj each. As of now, the Nakatiaganj native hasn’t reached Bettiah and the one from Majhaulia has been contacted and he will soon be kept in isolation,” said Bettiah civil surgeon Arun Kumar Sinha.

Altogether 10 people from Bettiah have completed isolation so far. “Nine people who completed 14-day quarantine in Manesar were kept in isolation for another 14 days. Even though no positive case has been detected, we are ensuring precautions,” Sinha said.

Title: Never wanted to be CM, want to create new leaders: Rajinikanth
Content:
Rajinikanth

CHENNAI: Disappointing legions of his fans who have been waiting for years to see their Superstar make his political entry and become chief minister of Tamil Nadu, actor Rajinikanth on Thursday said he never wanted to become CM .

“Had I wanted to be CM, I could have got it in 1996. This is not the first time I am saying this. On December 31, 2017, I said this (when he made the announcement that he would enter politics ). Do I want to have something now that I did not want at the age of 45?” Rajinikanth said.

“When I informed district secretaries about my decision to remain the party head and not the CM candidate, they cautioned me that people would not accept this and cited other parties. I am not interested in how it works with others. I want to usher in a change, create new leaders and bring hope to people,” Rajinikanth told a gathering of reporters in a city hotel. He, however, refused to take any question at the end of his 30-minute speech.

Citing the case of DMK founder and former chief minister C N Annadurai, Rajinikanth said Anna had created so many leaders.

“We need to create more leaders and for this 65% of representation (in his party) should be given to youngsters below 50 years of age to contest elections. A fair mix of experts from various fields should also be drafted in,” the actor said.

“In Tamil Nadu, there are two political giants who are well-established. On the one side is a party that has not been in power for almost 10 years, but is backed by a strong structure and resources. After the demise of Kalaignar, the successor (M K Stalin) is under pressure to prove his capabilities. On the other side is the ruling party with its hold over the treasury of Lord Kubera. Between these two giants, we have to make our entry. It will not be an easy task,” Rajinikanth said.

Title: Covid-19 exposes Kochi’s dependence on China
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

KOCHI: Whether it is Onam or Christmas, Kochi’s retail market depends on products manufactured in China and shipped from a handful of ports—nine of them—to Kochi. The electronic and electrical equipment flooding the markets during festivals invariably come from China or are assembled in India using critical components coming from that country. For Christmas or Vishu, even the crackers come from China. It doesn’t stop with goods stuffed in retail shops –furniture, auto parts and roof tiles too come from China.

Kochi-headquartered Kottaram Trading Company, which markets kitchenware and home décor products, sources products largely from China. “We import 600-700 containers of products from around the world, of which 60% comes from China,” said Antony Thomas Kottaram, director, Kottaram Trading Company.

The variety of products that an average Malayali uses in his daily life, which has origins in China, is astonishing. For instance, the January 2019 list of imports from China through Cochin Port runs up to 12 pages and includes goods like fans, furniture, sanitary wares, steel pipes, lightings, tea, polyester chips, steel sinks, DVD players, TVs, gift articles, induction cookers, gas stoves, LED lamps, tents, spare parts, wheel chairs, roof tiles, hair conditioner, bathroom cabinet – the list just goes on and on.

In China, there are towns or provinces specialized in certain products, said MK Ansari, chief executive officer of Kochi-headquartered Providence Exim India, that sells premium bath and sanitarywares under the brand Kriztle.

While Guangdong, a Southern coastal province, is famous for ceramic products, Zhejiang, another coastal town focuses on machinery, furniture and sanitarywares. On the other hand, Hubei is known for its furniture and tiles and Shenzhen is home to high-tech technology products – mainly mobiles. Once the document that provides information regarding the particulars of the goods to be delivered is sent to a Chinese company, it will take 45-60 days to complete production of kitchenware, said Kottaram. “It will take another 18-24 days for shipping them to Kochi. With Wan Hai, a shipping liner, running direct lines to Kochi, it will take only 14 days now,” he added.

Title: Liquor worth Rs 61cr consumed in city on Holi
Content:
Kanpur: Citizens of Kanpur consumed liquor to the tune of Rs 61 crore on the occasion of Holi this year. Foreign liquor remained on top in demand followed by country-made liquor while beer stood at the third place.

According to the excise department sources, liquor shops of the city witnessed 8 per cent rise in sale of liquor on Holi this year in comparison to last year. Strict vigil to check the sale of illicit liquor might be the cause behind rise in the sale.

District excise officer Arvind Maurya said that from March 8 to 9 shops sold liquor to the tune of Rs 61.10 crore. Around 1.98 lakh bottles worth Rs 48.60 crore of foreign liquor were sold while country-made liquor also remained in demand. Around 4.57 lakh litre country-made liquor worth Rs 10.74 crore and beer worth Rs. 2.30 crore was consumed in these two days, he said.

Maurya said that despite less number of liquor shops, sale broke the record of last year. License of 149 out of 221 foreign liquor shops were renewed in current financial year, he said adding that licences of 257 out of 341 country-made liquor shops were renewed while licences of 97 of 196 beer shops were renewed.

The department had sought online applications for renewal of remaining licences and applications online by March 16, said the official.

Title: Coronavirus: Telangana high court fumes over hoarding of masks, sanitisers
