Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court on Thursday directed the state government and drug control mechanism to keep pharmaceutical shops under check and ensure that masks and sanitisers are available at affordable rates.“The state must ensure that these stocks are not hoarded by the pharmacy shops. It should explore possibilities of distributing them for free through public distribution system,” said a bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy, while hearing PILs that sought adequate state measures to protect people from coronavirus , swine flu and other fevers. The bench, while appreciating the awareness programmes taken up by the state at the slums, wanted the authorities to educate the children going to schools and colleges situated near the slums. It also found fault with the authorities for not mentioning anything in their counter about the number of raids conducted by the drug controllers on illegal hoarders of masks and sanitisers.Advocate general BS Prasad informed the bench that they have set up five centres to conduct tests to ascertain whether patients are infected by coronavirus.“We will start the first testing centre at Osmania hospital on Friday. A testing centre will be set up by Fever hospital and another centre at the Warangal MGM hospital will start functioning from March 20. These testing centres will have the capacity to test and determine 100 cases daily,” the AG said.“Our medical team toured Kerala and studied their methods. We will follow suit here. In tune with the suggestions of amicus curiae S Niranjan Reddy, we are forming district level medical teams in addition to the state level rapid action teams,” he added.Assistant solicitor general N Rajeswara Rao informed the court that the Centre is taking all steps to ensure that the virus does not enter our country easily by imposing restrictions on inbound passengers.The bench posted the case to March 24.

Title: Forest dept resorts to drone to track, trap leopard on the prowl
Content:
Erode: Having failed to track the leopard that had been preying on the livestock of residents of Beemrajnagar, Thottaganjanur and Susaipuram hamlets in the Asanur forest division for the past four months, the district forest department officials on Thursday intensified their efforts to capture the big cat by deploying a drone.

K Sivakumar, ranger, Thalawadi forest range, said the leopard had killed more than 10 goats and 12 stray dogs in the three hamlets in the Asanur forest division since November 2019. “It had attacked three cows in the third week of February, despite our close watch.”

The forest officials had also set up two cages with bait in them to trap the leopard in as many places, but to no avail.

Initial inquiry revealed that the animal was staying at the abandoned stone quarries near Thottaganjanur hamlet. “Since we are afraid to go to the stone quarries, we have decided to use the drone to monitor the leopard’s movement,” the forest ranger said.

Four forest department teams and a team of Asanur police have been keeping high vigil in the area. They have extended the search for the big cat to nearby forest areas as well.

Title: Doctor: Wearing masks without reason risky
Content: Nagpur: Wearing a mask in an unscientific manner is fraught with dangers as bacteria carrying novel coronavirus stick to it and make people vulnerable to contracting the disease, said Dr Ajeet Saoji , professor and head of the department of community medicine at NKP Salve Institute of Medical Sciences, on Thursday.He was delivering a talk on ‘ Covid-19 : Facts and misconceptions’, organized by Rotary Club of Nagpur at Chitnavis Centre, Civil Lines, to create awareness about the disease.Saoji said, “Wearing a mask and changing it repeatedly while going out gives a false psychological confidence that one is safe from coronavirus. In fact, wearing it even if a person is not sick could be risky.”“Common people do not know how to wear or remove the mask. They are not supposed to touch the front side of the mask as it could make them prone to the disease. They should not wear the mask unless asked by a doctor,” he said.Tracing the history of the virus, Saoji quoted researchers as saying that the disease was transferred from animals to humans, mainly bats and cats. It is similar to diseases called SARS and MERS.He asked people to avoid large gatherings and travelling in the country or abroad. “If you think a person is not well, maintain a distance of at least 2 metres (6ft). The disease is mainly transferred if a person directly comes in contact with the infected one. Respiratory droplets are another reason of causing the disease,” he added.“The common signs of infections are fever, breathing difficulties, cough, diarrhoea and shortness of breath. In severe cases, there could be pneumonia, kidney failure and ARDS,” he said.According to researchers, he said, there are no vaccines or antiviral drugs available for Covid right now.Of the 1,25,000 reported cases of Covid globally, 60,000 people have been cured while 4,600 have lost lives. The disease has mainly attacked the elderly and young people. Coronavirus might vanish for some time, but could be back next year, Saoji said.President of Rotary Club of Nagpur Parag Paranjape and secretary Namita Sharma were present.(With inputs from Drishti Sharma)

Title: Screening of people at toll plazas, ST stands: Bhujbal
Content:
Nashik: District guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal on Thursday advocated screening of people at toll plazas and ST stands to keep a check on those crossing district borders without consulting the medical officers in order to curb spread of coronavirus.

“There are people coming to Nashik by public and private vehicles. In order to ensure people do not carry the infection home and mingle with the society, we will start screening of the people at toll plazas and at bus stands,” Bhujbal, who is also the state minister for civic supplies and consumer affairs, said.

Addressing the reporters after reviewing the system put in place to identify and contain the spread of virus among the common citizens, Bhujbal said the health department and district administration has taken up measures to ensure people infected with the virus were identified at the earliest.

The guardian minister further added that the administration has identified various buildings at various places to house 390 people in quarantine so that if and when the number of such patients and suspects shoots up, the administration would be able to take all necessary measures required to treat the people as well.

Bhujbal also warned that any quarantined person found loitering around without clearance from the administration would be forcibly picked up by police and quarantined again.

The minister also sounded an alert for people who were hiding information about those affected by Covid-19 saying they would face action if found guilty. “The citizens have to be alert and they can inform police and health machinery about such occupants. If found correct, action would be taken against the guilty,” Bhujbal said.

Bhujbal also warned the traders against profiteering. He also announced that biometric authentication for beneficiaries of public distribution system has been suspended till March 31 and also beneficiaries could take home food grains for the next two months.

Meanwhile, divisional commissioner Rajaram Mane said the government has ordered positioning of health teams at state borders to ensure Covid-19 suspects or patients do not cross the borders and mingle with people.

“The orders for health squads to go to the border posts and monitor every person coming inside Maharashtra have been issued. They will scan people with symptoms of Covid-19 and take action accordingly. Every foreigner has to go through compulsory quarantine from the date of arrival,” Mane said.

Title: Elephant tramples farmer to death
Content:
Erode: A 46-year-old man was trampled to death by a wild elephant at Ammapet near Andhiyur here in the early hours of Thursday when he came out to chase the animal that was wandering near his house.

Forest department officials identified the deceased as R Selvam alias Ponnusamy, of Konapuliyanthottam area near Ammapet. He was a farmer.

According to P Iswarya, 38, wife of the deceased, they woke up to the frantic cries of neighbours, who were shocked to find the wild elephant near their house, at 4am on Thursday. “My husband immediately opened the main door of the house. The elephant, which was standing near the door, suddenly pulled him outside and trampled him to death,” she said.

Iswarya alerted the forest officials, who recovered the body and sent that to the government hospital in Andhiyur for postmortem. The officials also issued a solatium of Rs25,000 as immediate relief to the victim’s family.

A forest official said, “We have registered a case and further investigations are on.”

The officials have, meanwhile, warned the villagers about the elephant movement in the area and advised them to take all the necessary precautions to avoid man-animal conflict.

Title: People with mild symptoms of Covid-19 needn't go for testing or treatment
Content: Kochi: Kerala government has advised patients with mild symptoms of Covid-19 not to come to hospitals for testing and treatment. It doesn’t matter whether they have returned to the state from Covid-19-affected country or are primary or secondary contacts of Covid-19 patients. This comes amid World Health Organisation (WHO) declaring Covid-19 a pandemic and scare of spread of the disease in the community in the state.“Testing is not going to change either the clinical course or management of the patient with mild symptoms,” said the revised guidelines for testing, quarantine, hospital admission and discharge for Covid-19 signed by principal secretary (health) Dr Rajan N Khobragade.The new revised guidelines issued on Thursday say the epidemiology of Covid-19 shows that 75% to 80% of the affected will develop only mild symptoms which do not require hospitalisation. Severe and infection and mortality are seen only in high-risk groups like elderly and those with chronic lung disease, heart disease, liver disease, renal disease, malignancies, immunocompromised, pregnancy, post-transplant, hematalogical disorders, HIV and those on chemotherapy or long-term steroids.Making it clear that the epidemiology of Covid-19, SARS and MERS clearly demonstrate that hospitals act as amplifying centres for the epidemic, the guidelines states, “This happens due to the mixing of patients with different risk categorization in the busy outpatient areas of designated Covid-19 centres”.“In majority of patients with mild symptoms, there is no need for hospitalisation or symptomatic management. Just like any viral infection, Covid-19 also will resolve by itself in majority of the patients,” the guidelines added.Health officials have already started implementing the revised guidelines from Thursday. “This will help stop the spread of the infection in the community and avoid unwanted rush at Covid-19 isolation wards. Many of the patients who arrived from Italy on Thursday and had mild or no symptoms were send to home quarantine in an ambulance,” said Dr Joseph Chacko, president, Kerala Government Medical Officers' Association (KGMOA).Further to ensure that there is no spread of Covid-19 in the local community, health officials said that it has been decided that in patients with viral pneumonia, Covid-19 testing maybe considered even if they are not from a country or area with local transmission of the corona virus and will be decided by the institution or district medical board.BOXCovid-19 has been categorised into:Category ASymptoms: Low grade fever, mild sore throat, cough, rhinitis (sneezing, stuffy nose) and diarrhoea*Patient will be assessed every 28 to 48 hours telephonically by a doctor from nearby PHC* No testing needed*No need to go to the designated Covid-19 nodal centres* Strict home isolation*Patients advised to have plenty of warm, nourishing oral fluids, balanced diet, adequate sleep and rest and saline gargle for sore throatCategory B*Symptoms: High grade fever, severe sore throat and cough*Should come to designated Covid-19 treatment centres*After clinical assessment, decision on testing to be taken*Patient to be started on symptomatic treatment* Maybe admitted at the treatment centre or sent back for home isolation* Patient will be assessed every 28 to 48 hours telephonically by a doctor from nearby PHC if send to home isolationCategory C*Symptoms: Breathlessness, chest pain, drowsiness, fall in blood pressure, cyanosis (red flag signs) etc, children with influenza like illness with red flag signs, high persistent fever with respiratory distress, worsening of underlying chronic condition*Patient will be admitted to designated Covid-19 treatment centres* Testing required#

Title: Bengaluru: Harassed by hubby over treatment cost, heart patient ends life
Content:
Representative image

BENGALURU: Upset over her husband’s insistence that expenses for her heart ailment be borne by her parents, a 26-year-old homemaker hanged herself at her residence in Manjunatha Nagar, near RT Nagar , on Tuesday midnight.

RT Nagar police said Lakshmi Sharma was also being harassed by her husband Dharmananda Sharma to divorce him. Dharmananda, his father Krishnakumar and mother Sharavati were arrested on Wednesday and remanded in judicial custody.

An investigating officer said Lakshmi had left a suicide note explaining the torture she underwent.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Two held for carrying country-made pistol on Agra court premises
Content:
Agra: Two men were nabbed from Agra district court premises on Thursday for carrying a country-made pistol and three cartridges.

The accused were identified as Brijesh Kumar Chauhan (23) of Farah, Mathura district. He was living at a rented accommodation in Itmad-ud-Daula area. While the second accused was Brijesh’s uncle, Manish Singh (25) of Sikandra area.

Station house officer of New Agra Umesh Chandra Tripathi said, “The two were caught while passing through the metal detector at gate number four of the court premises. They were carrying a bag. We found .315 bore country-made pistol and three cartridges in the bag.” Manish and his nephew have been arrested and booked under Arms Act.

“During interrogation, we found that Manish Singh had an ongoing trial in a molestation case. He was supposed to appear in the court on Thursday but he perhaps, had a different plan,” SHO said.

According to police records, Manish was booked in 2017 at Itmad-ud-Daula police station under IPC section 354B (assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to disrobe), 452 (house-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint), 504 (intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) and 506 (punishment for criminal intimidation).

Title: Chennai: Work on skywalk at Mambalam begins
Content:
The facility will be 600 metres long and four metres wide, allowing a considerable number of citizens to walk ... Read More

CHENNAI: The congestion around the busy T Nagar bus terminus could soon ease. More than seven years after coming up with a proposal, the city corporation has finally started work on a skywalk, Chennai’s first, that will link the terminus with the Mambalam railway station.

One leg of the facility, aimed at providing seamless connectivity to pedestrians using multiple modes of transport like suburban trains, long-distance trains, buses and taxis or autos, will drop on South Usman road. This is part of the smart city project’s area-based development (ABD).

A barricade has been put up at the entrance of Madley Road, beside the bus terminus, where work is on, senior officials said, adding that it is estimated to cost Rs 29 crore and is scheduled to be completed in 15 months. “However, we want to ensure the work is over in 12 months,” an official said.

It will be 600 metres long, and four metres wide, allowing a considerable number of citizens to walk through it at any given time. Solar panels on top will power both the lights and a safety alarm that will be provided, an official said.

All the three exits will have escalators that would make it easier for the differently abled and senior citizens, officials involved in the project said.

The columns would be of steel, the foundation will be of cement concrete and the sheets made of polycarbonate material.

Some of the pillars would be dug into the walls of the Madley Road subway itself, not impacting the width of the service road, an official said.

A section of residents in the area had raised concerns about reduction in the width of the road. People living along the service road, and on Thukkaram 1st, 2nd and 3rd streets claimed the service road was the only entry point for emergency vehicles like ambulances and fire tenders and that the project would result in the road shutting down. “Please shift it to neighbouring Natesan Street,’ they had said in a complaint sent to the chief minister’s cell.

A senior corporation official said the width of the service road would not be reduced as the skywalk was being erected at a height of six metres. “There is nothing to worry.”

The corporation plans to remove vendors from Station Border Road before construction begins and will rehabilitate them below it after the project is over, an official said.

Title: Tirupati-based milk manufacturer fined for illegally disposing expired milk packets and sachets
Content:
Chennai: Based on a National Green Tribunal (NGT) direction, a government joint committee has penalised a Tirupati-based milk manufacturing unit of Rs 1.85 lakh for illegally disposing expired milk packets and empty sachets along Kosasthalai River on the outskirts of the city.

The issue was first highlighted by a vernacular daily in January. The NGT’s Southern Zone took suo moto cognizance of it and formed the said committee.

During initial inspection, the committee found sachets and milk packets stored in polythene bags for disposal to waste recycler.

Further inspection at Tirupati revealed that the manufacturer did not obtain permission from Andhra Pradesh Pollution Control Board (APPCB) and operated from a small house. The unit did not pasteurise milk and simply packed cold milk in plastic packets.

On an average 1,000 packets were prepared daily and 400 litres of waste water gathered in the unit was let into nearby irrigation fields without any effluent treatment.

On enquiry, the owner of the unit admitted that they were illegally disposing of expired packets by a van driver at Kosasthalai near Kandigai in Tirutani for the past one and a half months.

APPCB issued a showcause notice and imposed an environmental compensation of Rs 1,85,000 on the unit.

NGT said APPCB should ensure that the compensation be collected without delay and take action if the unit continued to operate without government consent.

Title: Over 3 lakh disabled to get UDID
Content:
Chennai: Over three lakh persons with disabilities will get unique disability ID (UDID) by the end of March. It will help them avail benefits from various central and state governments schemes. The department for the welfare of differently abled has roped in 100 medical officers from every district primary health center to facilitate this process.

“We have so far generated over one lakh ID cards and we have 3.17 applications that need to be uploaded in the portal of the ministry of social justice to get the cards,” said a senior official from the department. The official explained that they are working with the health department to clear the backlog. “There are lakhs of applications that need to be checked by medical officers and later uploaded on the portal, but we only had 17 doctors in our department to carry out this task. Hence, the health department has deputed 100 more,” the official said.

This project was launched by the Centre in 2017 to create a national database for disabled falling under all 21 categories mentioned in the Persons with Disabilities Act. It is meant to ensure transparency, help beneficiaries avail all schemes and government benefits and streamline the tracking of the physical and financial progress of beneficiaries at all levels.

Tamil Nadu currently has around 13 lakh persons with disabilities. Officials from the department said that many do not come forward to apply for the ID, hence the low number. “The ID is not made compulsory yet. That is why people do not take it seriously,” the official said. To make the application process easier the department will soon launch a mobile app where beneficiaries can upload all documents and get the ID without going to the district offices.

Deepak Nathan, head of the December 3 Movement that works for the rights of persons with disabilities, lauded the department for taking steps to generate more IDs, but said, “There is a lot of confusion about the use of this ID. People already have many documents and cards and they still don’t know how one more card will benefit them,” he said.

Title: Edu minister promises Rs72L tax relief for Bamu
Content:
Aurangabad: State higher education minister Uday Samant has promised a relief of Rs72 lakh service tax for Dr Babasaheb Ambedkar Marathwada University ( Bamu ) as the university’s Osmanabad sub-centre is on an industrial land.

Samant, who visited the university on Thursday, said he would address the issue at the earliest by discussing the matter with state industries minister Subhash Desai.

“I assure that the university will not have to pay hefty tax every year and a necessary solution will be worked out soon. Once the tax exemption is received, the same money must be utilised for the students,” he said.

Earlier, Bamu vice-chancellor Pramod Yeole raised the issue of service tax levied by Maharashtra Industrial Development Corporation (MIDC) before Samant. “The university is paying a huge sum every year to the MIDC towards service tax. While MIDC has granted tax exemption to some of private institutions set up on industrial land in the area, the state university like ours is asked to pay Rs 72 lakh every year,” he said.

Among other demands raised by Bamu, Samant said recruitment of teachers on vacant posts would be carried out shortly along with other state universities.

Samant, who visited Bamu for the first time after becoming the education minister, said his department plans to visit every district in the state to address educational issues.

“We have decided to start the initiative from Gadchiroli district. As part of the initiative, senior officials from the education department would accompany me during visits at district headquarters where day-long meetings will be held with different stakeholders to resolve the pressing issues,” the minister said.

Title: A dozen couples tie the knot, ignore govt appeal
Content:
Nashik: Government appeals to avoid large gatherings and maintain social distance notwithstanding, at least a dozen weddings were solemnized in different parts of the city as Thursday.

There are over 40 wedding halls and lawns across the city. Though district collector Suraj Mandhare had appealed to the function halls and lawns to not allow any events, most were booked on Thursday as it was an auspicious day.

Parents of some of the brides said they had finalised the wedding months ago and had invested lakhs of rupees.

According to the sources in the wedding halls and lawns, though many weddings were scheduled on March 19, most families conducted the ceremonies a day before. A few parties deferred the ceremonies

“One group had already booked the venue two months ago. The groom had come from Aurangabad and had made all the arrangements. It was difficult for us to stop them. We had given them two hours and told them to invite as few people as possible. The party completed the wedding ceremony in the stipulated time,” said A Ahire, the owner of a marriage hall.

“We had invited 50 people from both the parties. We had taken all the measures like using sanitisers and face masks. We completed all the wedding rituals in two hours and left the hall,” said the groom’s father.

Owner of another wedding hall said that the party had spent a lot of money on the arrangements and had distributed over 1,200 wedding cards. But only 100 people turned up for the wedding.

“Moreover, we had also provided sanitizers and masks to the staff engaged in serving food to the guests,” said the owner.

R Patil, father of a bride, had planned for his daughter’s wedding around two-and-a-half months ago. He had spent over Rs 7 lakh and distributed 1,000 wedding cards. “How could I have cancelled the wedding at this point? Would the government have compensated what I had already spent?” said Patil.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Hyderabad: IT firms, staff told to work from home
Content: HYDERABAD: Even as state health authorities await reports of three Covid-19 suspects and another suspected case from Warangal came to light on Thursday, information technology firms asked employees to work from home and stepped up security measures in offices. Anyone with a body temperature of more than 99 degree Fahrenheit on the thermal check is being barred from entering offices and some companies are even actively checking with employees if they have any fever or cold.“I was turned away from office on Monday since I had a cold. Although, I do not have a recent travel history to any of the affected countries, our HR has asked anyone with mildest symptoms to work from home or avail off depending on their condition. This is in addition to other measures taken in our office like sanitation, distribution of masks and sanitisers,” B Shikhar, a software employee working at Hi-Tec City.While sanitation drives and advisories have become a regular feature in most IT offices, managements were struggling with charting out timelines and plans for managing work from home. “We have a workforce of less than 200 and despite all measures put in place, we are looking at having majority of the people work from home in the near future. The step will be essential to continue our services in case of the spread of the infection,” a CEO of a company said. IT services company Tetrasoft at Mindspace has gone ahead and placed a health desk with doctors and nurses in tow to ensure its employees are safe and sent back home if they display any symptoms.Meanwhile, the high-powered committee formed to monitor Covid-19 in Cyberabad area has already issued an advisory to firms to mandate all employees returning from foreign assignments to work from home for 14 days. “If returnees show symptoms, ask them to get tested at listed hospitals and work from home (WFH) for 14 days. Employee should join back only after producing a doctor’s certificate,” the advisory added.

Title: Kailash yatra preparatory meet delayed
Content:
Pithoragarh: The preparatory meeting of Kailash Mansarovar Yatra has been delayed in view of the coronavirus outbreak, official sources privy to the development said.

The preparatory meet is usually held in February or by early March.

The officials at Kumaon Mandal Vikas Nigam (KMVN), the nodal agency for the yatra in Uttarakhand, said they have not received any specific information about the delay in holding the meeting, but it is believed that the reason may be the Covid-19 threat.

Notably, a large part of the almost one-month long yatra involves travelling through Tibet.

The yatra starts from the first week of June and ends in mid-September.

“We have no specific information for the delay in the meeting. But hopefully, the meeting will be held within this month,” said Ashok Joshi, manager tourist of KMVN.

“Though the preparatory meeting is yet to be held, the nagar nigam workers have already started preparation for yatra,” he added.

When asked as to what would happen if Kailash yatra gets cancelled, Joshi said, “Then we will try to increase the number of groups for Adi Kailash Yatra.”

Title: Doon to get heavy shower today: Met
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

DEHRADUN: The city witnessed heavy rainfall on Thursday and places above 3000m witnessed snowfall. The regional meteorological department attributed the sudden change in weather to western disturbance over the neighbouring states. The department also predicted heavy rainfall on Friday.

Bikram Singh, director of the regional meteorological centre, said that more rains are predicted on Friday and Saturday and the weather will start clearing from Sunday onwards.

Title: 3 held for administering fake vaccines
Content: Jalna: Three women were arrested for allegedly administrating fake coronavirus vaccines to the residents of a village in Jalna district, police said on Thursday.The police on Wednesday arrested Beed residents Radha Ramnath Saamse, Seema Krishna Andhale and Sangeeta Rajendra Avhad, who allegedly posed as doctors and healthcare workers, an official said.The trio met the people of Pipalgoan in Ambad taluka, informed them about a vaccine that could protect them from coronavirus and administered it to gullible locals, he said.Some villagers informed Dr Mahadev Munde, a medical officer at a rural health centre, about this, after which a complaint was lodged, the official said.Fake vaccines and bottles, which were seized from the accused, have been sent to the state health department, he said, adding that a case of cheating has been registered against the trio. PTI

Title: Over a hundred villages cut off after landslide in Nainital
Content:
Nainital: After heavy rains and hailstorms on February 24, the lone motorable road to three blocks of Nainital District collapsed leaving around 120 villages with no access to the district headquarters. Residents of Bhimtal, Dhari and Okhalkanda block said that the road which connects their villages was completely damaged and as a result no car or motorcycle is able to leave the area and get necessary supplies. “The road was damaged more than a fortnight ago and since then there is no connectivity. All we can do is travel on foot because most of the road has collapsed. And due to this, thousands of villagers are facing shortage of food supplies,” said Umesh Singh, a local.

Meanwhile, Bharat Sambhal of Gairakhan village said that the locals now have to take a detour of almost 35 km to get necessary supplies. “The road was built almost four years ago and it was the major route to go to places such as Kathgodam and Haldwani. Now that it has been damaged we have to travel over 35 km extra via Dhanachuli to get even basic supplies. Though it is still possible for people with vehicles, there are hundreds of villagers who do not own a vehicle and therefore they are the worst affected,” he said.

Ravinder Sambhal of the same village added that no government official has visited them yet or even given them any help. “It’s been well over two weeks since we have been left stranded here. As the entire area falls in the hills, we have to spend almost three more hours to get anything. Yet no one has come forward to help,” he said.

The officials of the district administration, meanwhile, said that they are already in the process to repair the road and since the existing structure is not stable, the PWD will have to conduct a survey and then build the road accordingly. “We have released a fund of around Rs 2.5 lakh for the preliminary survey to the PWD. The gravel under the road is loose and that’s why it is not able to hold the weight. We are planning a permanent solution. After the survey, a detailed project report (DPR) will be finalised which will be sent to the government for release of money. The entire project will cost around Rs 1.5 crore to Rs 2 crore,” said Nainital district magistrate Savin Bansal.

Title: Don’t consider Centre’s move: AP IPS officer moves CAT
Content:
Hyderabad: Andhra Pradesh’s former intelligence chief AB Venkateswara Rao on Thursday filed a supplementary plea before Central Administrative Tribunal (CAT), asking the tribunal to not take into consideration the Centre’s confirmation of his suspension from service.

The suspension was effected by Andhra Pradesh and even before the Central Administrative Tribunal could determine the validity of this suspension, the Centre approved the action taken by Andhra Pradesh. The Centre also asked the state to file chargesheet against the suspended IPS officer for his alleged efforts to secure a drones procurement contract to an Israeli firm in contravention to the norms.

Now, Andhra Pradesh is asking the Central Administrative Tribunal to take the Centre’s decision into consideration because it agreed with the state’s conclusion that Rao’s actions constitute to misconduct.

Rao, in his plea, said the Centre’s decision came after CAT reserved its judgment and hence the matter should be adjudicated without looking at the Centre’s decision or its rationale. The case will come up for hearing at the tribunal on Monday.

Title: From stands to the middle, Thapa sees it all
Content:
Panaji: When Chennaiyin FC won their maiden Indian Super League ( ISL ) title in 2015, Anirudh Thapa was keenly watching from the stands of the Nehru Stadium at Fatorda. Even though FC Goa lost their grip on home soil after late drama in the 2-3 thriller, Thapa, who was with the AIFF Academy that time, was cheering for the visitors, thanks to friends at the club.

Next season, Thapa joined the club in a ‘dream move’ and made his debut at the same venue, a high-scoring and entertaining 4-5 loss. He had a role to play in Chennaiyin’s second triumph, but as the two-time champions prepare to face ATK in another final on Saturday, the midfielder should feel the weight on his shoulders.

“When I began, I wasn’t so experienced and never knew how far I would come because that time there were many players and I was happy playing alongside them and learning. Now, this is my fourth season and I’m doing well, but there is more to come,” Thapa told TOI on Thursday.

Chennaiyin were languishing at the bottom of the table in December and their rise to play-off qualification only began when Owen Coyle took over the reins from John Gregory in December. Since then, they have only improved in their last 14 matches under the Scottish coach which helped them secure a play-off berth. In the first leg semifinal at home, Thapa, 22, scored his only goal so far, but an important one in a 4-1 demolition of league toppers FC Goa. In the return leg they held on for a 2-4 loss and enter their third final.

“We knew Goa plays different kind of football and everyone was expecting them to qualify. We had the advantage when two of their main players were not playing and we scored as many goals in the first leg. We knew when we come to Goa, we can play our game because they will be under pressure,” said Thapa.

The international has the highest assists (6) for an Indian and has been the heartbeat of the side that doesn’t use any foreigners in midfield. He played 19 matches, missing only once against Bengaluru FC, when they failed to score. He has formed a strong partnership alongside former Minerva Punjab teammate Germanpreet Singh and, at times, Edwin Vanspaul.

Chennaiyin had lost by a solitary goal to ATK at home in the first leg but responded strongly in the return leg with a 3-1 victory in Kolkata. However, Thapa believes past records will count for nothing in the final.

“This season we were at the bottom and six matches without a win. Then the last eight matches we had to win, and we were playing under pressure in every match. It will be amazing to win and lift the title here,” said Thapa.

ATK and Chennaiyin are the most successful clubs in the history of ISL and share four titles between them, winning two each. Thapa already has one and now wants to see Chennaiyin win another one, this time not watching from the stands, but running the show in the middle at Fatorda.

Title: NITW student shifted to isolation ward
Content:
Warangal: A National Institute of Technology (NITW) Warangal student suffering from cold, cough and fever was initially admitted at a private hospital in Hanamkonda.

Private hospital authorities informed the patient details to DM&HO on Thursday. He was shifted to MGM hospital and is under observation.

According to the NITW registrar, the research scholar had gone to attend a conference in USA on March 1.

He returned to his hometown, Kurnool in Andhra Pradesh on March 8. On March 10, he was admitted in a private hospital as he was suffering from suffering from cold, cough and fever. Medical and health authorities shifted him to MGM hospital on Thursday and are keeping him in an isolated ward under observation.

A press release from NIT stated that the institute has taken all precautionary measures to conduct medical examinations of the students returning from outside Warangal and has advised faculty, staff and students to take all preventive measures.

Title: Hyderabad: CRPF men, who lost limbs while on duty, to undergo sports training
Content: HYDERABAD: The Central Reserve Police Force ( CRPF ) personnel, who lost their limbs in the line of duty, will get a new lease of life as a city-based foundation will train them in various sports and skill-development activities.The CRPF will ink a Memorandum of Understanding on Friday with Aditya Mehta Foundation (AMF), touted as the first-of-its-kind charitable national para-sports rehabilitation and training academy in Asia. Apart from civilians, the foundation provides training to personnel from Central Armed Forces such as CRPF, Border Security Force (BSF) and Indo-Tibetan Border Police (ITBP), who lost their limbs in attacks on international borders or Naxal areas.The foundation will screen the amputees to find out their interests in different sports and professionals will provide them training.CRPF IG, MR Naik, told TOI, “Around 189 personnel lost their limbs in exchange of fire, improvised explosive device blast and Moaist attacks in past 10 years across the country. CRPF Divyangjan Warriors will undergo training for sports and skill-development activities in Hyderabad in coordination with AMF. They will be encouraged to pursue para-sports and other activities.”Senior IPS officer AP Maheshwari, director general of CRPF, will inaugurate the CRPF Divyangjan Warriors skill-development initiative.As part of this initiative, AMF will train these personnel in 28 different sports, including para-cycling, para-archery, para-shooting, para-skating, para-powerlifting, rowing and canoeing, para-judo, para-badminton, para-boccia, para-table tennis, para-volleyball, paratriathlon, para-athletics and para-swimming. The initiative is aimed at rehabilitating and motivating the personnel to lead a better life.Aditya Mehta told TOI, “Apart from the forces’ personnel, we provide free training, food and accommodation to civilians. More than 40 people from across the country are training with us. After inclusion of CRPF personnel , this number will cross 100. Previously, we had signed an MoU with BSF also.”“BSF was the first paramilitary force to get associated with us. So far, we have held four national-level training camps. Around 800 persons with disability were trained in 26 sports by para-coaches, physiotherapists and prosthetists,” Mehta said.The para-athletes from AMF have won 88 medals at international championships such as Para-Badminton Championship in Peru, 5th Asian Para Cycling Championship, World Cycling, Irish Para-Badminton Championship and 6th Asian Para-Cycling Championship.

Title: Telangana: Iskcon, Sangeet junctions to get wider
Content:
The junction widening is set to solve the problem of traffic congestion in Secunderabad

SECUNDERABAD: In order to ease traffic congestion here, the GHMC has decided to improve two junctions. The proposal for the project will be placed before a standing committee on March 19.

“The proposal will be approved,” said a GHMC official. The junction opposite International Society for Krishna Consciousness, popularly known as Maredpally junction, and Sangeet junction are set to be improved.

As many as 10 properties will have to be acquired for the junction improvement. For every one square yard of land acquired, the GHMC has decided to give property owners nine square feet of built space. The move is aimed towards saving funds as no monetary compensation will be provided.

“If we acquire 100 square yards of land we are giving the property owners 900 square feet of built up space as compensation,” said GHMC Director (Planning) K Srinivasa Rao.

The offer is different for Transferable Development Rights(TDR) certificate. “In case of TDR, we will give property owners four times built of up area. As of today, the estimate to improve the two junctions has come up to Rs 12 crore,” said Rao.

As per GHMC records, the maximum proportion of the expense if going to land acquisition, which is summing up to Rs 10 crore. Widening of roads, installation of circular junction boxes and beautification work are a part of the project. GHMC standing committee on Thursday approved the proposal to widen the road from Methodist Colony and Begumpet to Begumpet Railyway Station (parallel to railway track). The road falls under GHMC Secunderabad zone.

Once the two junctions are improved and the road is widened, traffic congestion at Sangeet junction, Mettuguda and traffic from Secunderabad to Begumpet will be reduced. After improving the two junctions, GHMC has also proposed to develop the Begumpet junction. But a central government building needs to be acquired to execute the junction improvement in that area.

Title: To mark annexation, Tibetans hold protest in Nainital
Content:
Representative image

NAINITAL: The Tibetan community in Nainital on Thursday protested the Chinese annexation of Tibet on March 12, 1959, when the Chinese bombed Lhasa and killed thousands of Tibetans.

The day also marks the anniversary of the Tibetan women’s protest against the Chinese.

The protesters also prayed to the Dalai Lama and alleged that “the Chinese troops will never be able to win the hearts of the people and that the region will be free one day.” The national general secretary of the women’s wing of Indo-Tibetan Cooperation Forum, Preeti Saagar , also visited Nainital to lend her support to the protest.

She said, “Several women had resisted the Chinese aggression in Tibet in 1959. Since then, the Tibetans living at several locations across the country have been organising protests on this day. The silent protest in Nainital is also a part of that and therefore people have gathered here to protest the Chinese occupation of Tibet.”

The Tibetan and Bhotia markets of Nainital also remained closed on Thursday to pay respect to the martyrs. The Tibetan community condemned the occupation and also demanded the United Nations (UN) to initiate talks between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama.

“The UN should take note of the human rights violations in Tibet and also work to grant religious freedom which has been severely curtailed under the Chinese. Steps should also be taken to initiate talks between His Holiness the Dalai Lama and the Chinese government,” the protesters said.

Title: Fresh snowfall blocks traffic on Gangotri, Yamunotri highways
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

UTTARKASHI: Several roads, including Gangotri and Yamunotri national highways remained blocked on Thursday due to overnight rain and snowfall in Uttarkashi district , leaving nearly two dozen villages disconnected from district headquarter for many hours.

Meanwhile, as soon as the weather cleared, the administration started road repair work.

Sources said that traffic movement at Gangotri and Yamunotri national highways got interrupted at Sukki Top and Hanumanchatti regions late on Wednesday, due to fresh spell of snowfall. Moreover, landslides triggered by heavy rains blocked Arakot-Chiwan, Silkyara-Bangaun and Adni-Rauntal link roads, causing much harassment to local villagers and tourists alike.

Meanwhile, the national highway authority restored traffic movement on Yamunotri highway on Thursday after the weather cleared. Besides, Border Roads Organisation (BRO) also restored traffic movement on Gangotri highway from Sukki Top to Dharali village. However, the highway was still blocked ahead of Dharali village.

Devendra Patwal, district disaster management officer told TOI, “We have restored traffic in most of the roads, whereas remaining routes will be cleared soon. Taking note of meteorological department's forecast, we have kept all concerned departments on alert.”

Title: Congress may move SC over ‘abduction’ of its MLAs, ‘assault’ on netas in Bengaluru
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: The state Congress on Thursday alleged that two ministers of the Kamal Nath government were assaulted and arrested by Bangalore police when they went to the resort where 19 MLAs have been lodged, allegedly by BJP. Congress may move Supreme Court since it has become an “inter-state and even national issue”.

With the clock ticking down to the arrival of Jyotiraditya Scindia in Bhopal, senior Congress leaders Digvijaya Singh and Vivek Tankha held a press meet where they showed dramatic videos of ministers Jitu Patwari and Lakhan Singh Yadav being shoved around in Bengaluru.

The two ministers had gone to the resort along with Narayan Choudhary, father of MLA Manoj Choudhary who is one of the 19 legislators cooped up in the resort. Patwari is a relative of Manoj Choudhary. Digvijaya and Tankha showed videos of how Patwari, Lakhan and Narayan Choudhary were allegedly manhandled by police, bodily lifted into a police bus and taken away. Choudhary is seen in the videos in a pair of swimming shorts and with a towel around his neck.

“This is a case of abduction and forced captivity,” Tankha, an eminent lawyer, said. “You abduct and take our MLAs to a different region, and hold them hostage. They cannot even contact their families as their mobile phones have been taken away. They are not there out of free will. A BJP delegation, led by senior leaders takes resignations from MLAs on Holi and returns to Bhopal to submit them to the Speaker. No one knows under what circumstances these resignations were taken from our MLAs,” Tankha said.

Tankha alleged that the ministers were assaulted and arrested. “After speaking to his father, Manoj wanted to return. To release people held captive is the duty of every citizen. Our ministers were trying to do what police should have done. They were assaulted and arrested because a father wanted to bring his son home. This is condemnable,” he argued.

“We demand that Bangalore police immediately take punitive action against those officers, and release our ministers and MLAs. Otherwise, we may have to move Supreme Court. We could have gone to high court but this is an issue between two states. This has become a national issue now — how MLAs from Madhya Pradesh have been abducted, held captive, are being pressurized and their relatives being beaten,” Tankha said.

“We are consulting Kapil Sibal (former Union minister and Supreme Court lawyer) and, maybe, will move Supreme Court and tell how the country’s democracy is in danger. What BJP is doing is a criminal act and an unbiased probe should be conducted by the apex court because BJP-led Centre will not be interested,” he said.

Regarding the resignations of 22 Congress MLAs submitted by former BJP minister Bhupendra Singh to Speaker NP Prajapati on March 10, Tankha said, “Under Constitution and the law, a Speaker, whether of Congress or BJP, has only one option — to investigate these resignations. Notices have been sent so that the MLAs may present themselves and discuss with the Speaker. Two years ago, when Jagan Mohan Reddy’s MPs faced a similar situation, then Lok Sabha Speaker Sumitra Mahajan conducted an inquiry for two months.”

Speaker NP Prajapati issued notices to six ministers on Wednesday. Prajapati said seven MLAs have been issued notices on Thursday.

Title: Bhopal residents share feedback on new masterplan draft
Content:
Bhopal eyes Masterplan 2031

BHOPAL: Suggestions and complaints are coming thick and fast after the administration sought residents’ advice on the high-tech masterplan draft. The advanced technology and data mapping help users take a closer view of the digital plan, consequently leading them to share their suggestions.

After the much-awaited Draft Bhopal development plan 2031 was released post 25 year-gap, the administration had invited feedback till April 4.

“Offline or manual comments regarding the master plan are being received. However, more people are responding online. Also, there is a detailed description to opt for online comment,” said a senior district administration official.

Built with extensive GPS technology, the plan can view even 0.5 sq meter of detail. Each khasra has been highlighted after development work was undertaken by Bhopal Municipal Corporation (BMC) GPS wing. It took the department over three years. Each of 4 lakh plus properties can be viewed in two dimension on the map.

The website mptownplan.gov.in received thousands of hits, after the draft plan for Bhopal’s future development was released on March 5. It may take the authorities 60 days to submit the final document gazette.

Few objections related to permitting development in eco-sesitive zones.

The urban development officials claim that this is first development plan in India based on extensive GPS technology.

The plan allows for revenue generation through premium FAR and saving through TDR generation. New plan would enhance mixed use development in areas like MP Nagar, New Market, Karond and Misrod. A heritage and green cover conservation has also been proposed.

Last Bhopal masterplan of 1995 was valid till 2005. The city development plant is also based on transit oriented development (TOD), whereby areas along BRTS, Metro rail development would benefit from additional Floor Area Ratio (FAR).

Title: Fresh food, special medical teams in GMCH isolation ward
Content: Nagpur: With more than 15 Covid-19 suspected patients admitted, the 32-bed isolation ward of the GMCH saw the highest number of admissions on Thursday since it was set up a few days ago.The hospital authorities are taking special care of the suspected patients to avoid spreading of the infection among doctors treating them.GMCH medical superintendent Dr Avinash Gawande said that they have constituted two teams of doctors and nurses who alternate duties in the isolation ward.“No staff or doctor other than the members of these teams can work in isolation ward,” he said.The hospital kitchen is also cooking additional food for the suspects. GMCH has also started three help desks for visitors who have travel history, symptoms and wanted to get themselves tested.After the number of patients admitted in this ward increased suddenly by 14 on Thursday, the kitchen department had to work extra to prepare nutritious food for the admitted suspects.The entire family of the US-returned man who tested positive was admitted to GMCH on Thursday.Authorities have provided them all the facilities. While there is a gross shortage of sanitizers and masks in medical stores across the city, the GMCH has enough stock of these essential goods. This could be credited to the advanced purchase plan by the GMCH dean Dr Sajal Mitra. The hospital also has enough stock of medicines.At IGGMCH , a 250bed isolation ward has been set up. The laboratory facility at the hospital is functioning 24X7 now. The samples of 14 people in close contact of the Covid-19 positive patient were being tested throughout Thursday.Swab samples of the nine suspects from Yavatmal reached at Mayo Hospital on Thursday evening and testing was under way. The lab is also testing samples coming from Telangana, Chhattisgarh and parts of Madhya Pradesh on a daily basis. The isolation ward in the IGGMCH currently has one ‘positive’ patient.The administration has decided to convert MLA hostel into a quarantine building soon. All patients having travel history to seven most affected countries will be kept under isolation here, if need be.

Title: Tamil Nadu: 12th century idols dumped in pit at hilltop temple near Madurai
Content:
A ruined idol dumped with garbage at the temple

CHENNAI: Ancient sculptures of Lord Vinayaka and Nandi have been abandoned in a dump yard near a temple atop Siddharmalai in Madurai district . The ruined sculptures, according to heritage experts, date to late 12th century AD.

Maintained by the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), the site is known for its ancient Tamil-Brahmi inscriptions and Jain beds inside the cavern.

The Pandya Siva temple atop the hill in Nilakkottai village, 40km from Madurai, is maintained by a committee formed by people from nearby villages. The temple attracts devotees from neighbouring hamlets. “But the committee has not given importance to these ancient sculptures. They don’t know their value. The sculptures have been lying abandoned for a long time,” said Madurai-based heritage activist K Rajkumar.

The sculptures of Nandi with a ruined nose and Vinayaka without a trunk lie in a pit where garbage from the temple is dumped . When Rajkumar informed the committee members, one member told him, “They are broken, why do we need them. We should now think about the ideal colours with which to paint the temple.” He was referring to the recent temple renovation being carried out without expert advice.

ASI: Not aware, will look into it

TN archaeology department deputy director R Sivanandam said, “We are not aware of this. We will look into the matter and take appropriate action to preserve the sculptures found abandoned on the premises of the temple.”

The Pandya-era temple was renovated during the Nayak period, but use of paint during the restoration a couple of years ago destroyed the ancient Tamil inscriptions at the base. “The temple looks like a modern structure today. Many ancient Tamil inscriptions have been lost and those at the base have been covered with a thick coat of paint. The committee seems clueless about the value of inscriptions and sculptures,” said retired history professor M M Bhoopathi. Trekking to the top of Siddharmalai is an arduous 40-minute climb before the cavern containing Jain beds and Tamil-Brahmi inscriptions is reached. The Siva temple is perched on top of the hill with a breathtaking view of the Vaigai. The ASI has done little to prevent vandalism.
