Subsequently, the contract to capture, sterilise and return the animals to their respective spots will be awarded to the particular NGO. Authorities said that neutering drive will resume at the earliest since the district administration has involved them in reviving the drive.

“We have sought the NGO to furnish work plan and employees available with them to resume the sterilisation drive. We will provide fund and infrastructure to support the drive to alleviate the sufferings of residents,” an official with the corporation said. The civic body said they sterilised 900 dogs out of 1,400 dogs actually planned in 2019.

The animal husbandry department was requested to furnish the statistics of stray dogs in the city. The population is around 20,000. “Ever since we removed public garbage bins, the population of stray dogs has not increased rapidly,” the official added. Since Trichy Corporation is technically ill-equipped to oversee the neutering process, animal husbandry department is requested to supervise the weekly progress of sterilisation drive.

Title: New date to apply for desi liquor shop licences in 2 dists
Content:
Jaipur: Excise department on Thursday conducted lottery to select applications for retail liquor shops and award them licences. A top official of the department said that the selected applicants will be required to furnish all the details of the shop and deposit the licences fees and the process will take three to four days.

He said the overall response was very good and the department will seek application for Sriganganagar and Hanuman districts where there were no applications for 89 country liquor shops.

“Unlike in the past few years when applications were sought for six to seven times, we will require just another date for Sriganganagar and Hanumangarh. The date would be most likely March 16,” said the official.

He said that response from districts like Ajmer is very encouraging given the fact that the country’s economy is not doing well and investor sentiment is at lower levels.

But some retailers said that applicants from outside the state were more and they wanted the government should have given preference to the local businessman.

The number of shops this year has remained same that included 1000 for IMFL and 5543 for country liquor.

The department has got application money of Rs 860 crore. Although it is less than the Rs 1007 crore received by the department last year, the official said that whenever the lottery system is conducted for a second consecutive year, the revenues go down.

“That’s why comparing the figures for 2017-18 is appropriate. In that year, the application revenue was Rs 837 crore which is less than the revenue of Rs 860 crore for 2020-21,”he added.

Title: Articles made of reptile skins seized, 1 held
Content:
Panaji: In a recent raid, products made from the skin of wild reptiles were found being sold at a night market in Anjuna. The weekly night market features stalls run by foreign nationals in Goa selling clothes and handmade trinkets for a living.

The Wildlife Crime Control Western Bureau (WCCB) seized luxury articles like belts, wallets, jackets, bags and shoes, made from leathers of pythons, monitor lizards and crocodiles that were being sold by a Philippines national. A case was registered by the range forest office, (RFO) Panaji, under the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972.

The accused was identified as Allan Tizon Jaraba and produced before the Mapusa JMFC after arrest, sources said. “It’s a shame that items made from the skin of species protected under Schedule 1 of the Wildlife Protection Act are sold so openly by foreigners in Goa and that the authorities either are unaware of or don’t want to take action. We need to stop sale of such , to stop poaching and prevent the destruction of wildlife,” said president, People For Animals, Norma Alvares.

Title: Perambalur cop’s voice clip on police inaction goes viral
Content:
Trichy: A voice note circulated by a Perambalur head police constable on WhatsApp, lamenting that his immediate superiors were hesitant in initiating legal action against a youth who tried to rough him up during night surveillance, has gone viral.

The head constable identified himself as Muthukumar attached to Perambalur armed reserve police. He was on night surveillance on March 8 at Duraimangalam where he noticed a youth conversing with a girl. As Muthukumar accompanied by home guards questioned the youth, the latter has called his friends to the location. The youth, who identified himself as an influential man, allegedly was drunk and refused to cooperate and abused them.

When Muthukumar complained the incident to his immediate superior to initiate action against the youth, the senior official allegedly refused to accept the complaint. Upset over the incident, Muthukumar through a voice message in WhatsApp appealed to the high command and lamented the humiliation he faced and subsequent inaction from his immediate seniors.

“Despite the abuse, I stayed calm. It is getting difficult to do our duties, DIG Trichy range should take action against the youth who abused me,” Muthukumar said in his voice note. The head constable in his voice note claimed that the accused man who abused him was an advocate. When contacted, Perambalur SP Nisha Parthiban said, “We have registered a case and are investigating.”

Title: 3-year-old dies in Ajmer mishap
Content: A three-year-old boy was killed when two cars collided head on at Nasirabad Road in Ajmer on late Wednesday night. Police have arrested the driver who was drunk. According to police, one Bherulal, along with family was returning home after watching a movie. While taking a turn near Panchwati Colony, another car hit his vehicle.

Title: Students, vigilance staff clash in MSU
Content:
Panjabi suffered minor injuries on his hand and was taken to SSG Hospital

Vadodara: Students and vigilance staff of the MS University (MSU) got into a scuffle at the head office on Thursday morning. The students were demonstrating at the head office over the delay in declaration of results of commerce and other faculties’ exams.

The group led by general secretary of the MSU Students’ Union, Rakesh Panjabi, at one point tried to enter the head office building which led to the scuffle. On one hand students tried to enter, on the other, the vigilance staff and security guards tried to push them away. In the melee, several students including Panjabi were pushed away.

“All we wanted was to either meet the vice-chancellor or registrar or the deputy registrar, but since none of them were coming out, we requested the vigilance staff to allow us to enter the building and meet them,” said Panjabi.

“When they were pushing us away, I requested them that I am the general secretary and the senate member so at least I should be allowed in, but a couple of security guards pushed me away,” he added. Panjabi suffered minor injuries on his hand and was taken to SSG Hospital.

The students claimed that the exams of the odd semester ended on December 15, but even after three months the results had not been declared by the university. “Mid-semester exams of the even semester have been conducted and the final exams will begin in the first week of April. Yet we don’t know our performance of the previous semester,” said a student.

Panjabi said that the results of all the semesters of BCom were being awaited, and the results of some semesters of engineering and technology faculty and arts faculty were still to be declared. “On Friday too we will continue with our protests,” he said.

“We have included additional human resource in completing the process. But assessments as such take time because it is a manual process and commerce faculty has over 15,000 students,” said MSU’s officiating registrar K M Chudasama. He added that by next week the issue would be resolved.

Title: Truck drivers warned against rash driving
Content:
Madurai: A day after garbage truck belonging to the Madurai Corporation was involved in a road accident, in which a teenager was killed, commissioner S Visakan held a meeting with civic body officials and truck drivers on Thursday.

Visakan said that he has been getting complaints of rash and negligent driving against a few vehicle operators from the public. He asked them to be cautious and careful on roads. Even a single life should not be lost on the road due to negligence by the drivers. They should also wear uniform and refrain from using mobile phone. If anyone is found guilty of rash driving, he will be sacked from the job, he warned.

Traffic police officers and assistant executive engineering from corporation engineering wing Sevvel also took part in the meeting. The 19-year-old was run over by a corporation garbage truck at Villapuram, when he fell on the road due to an erratic autorickshaw driver. The traffic police registered a case against the truck driver and an unidentified auto rickshaw driver. tnn

Title: UP man held with country-made pistol, cartridges
Content:
Vadodara: The special operations group (SOG) has arrested a 23-year-old man for being in possesion of a country-made pistol. The cops had received information that Moin Khan Pathan, a resident of Gorwa, had a pistol following which they kept an eye in his locality.

On Thursday, the cops nabbed Pathan near Pandya bridge when he was on his way to Fatehgunj. The pistol worth Rs 20,000 and five live cartridges were seized from Pathan, who hails from Uttar Pradesh.

Pathan told the cops that he had purchased the pistol from a man named Panda in Kasganj district of Uttar Pradesh.

“We are now trying to ascertain if Pathan wanted to sell the pistol and cartridges or he wanted to use it for some crime,” the police said. An offence has been registered against Pathan under the Arms Act at Fatehgunj police station.

Title: Finally, BDU approves BIM’s degree certificates it held back
Content:
Trichy: After refusing to approve the degree certificates of students from Bharathidasan Institute of Management (BIM) for a month citing clarification on modification made to its bylaws, Bharathidasan University (BDU) finally issued the certificates on Thursday.

While there were talks of a postponing the convocation planned in BIM, all the 117 students will be finally getting their degrees on Saturday. BIM was started in 1984 as a school of excellence and registered as a society in partnership with Bharat Heavy Electrical Limited (BHEL). Set up on the BHEL campus, it made changes to the bylaws, which virtually cut off BDU’s role in BIM.

“While it was governed by a council of which the BDU vice-chancellor was a member, his membership was removed following changes to the bylaws in 2011,” said a senior faculty member of BDU.

However, the degree has been issued by BDU every year since its inception. According to highly placed sources, this year BDU had written to the state government saying it will not sign degrees this year as BIM had not complied with the norms by not allowing academic and financial audit.

According to the original bylaws, BDU has serious role in the academic activity which the BIM under the directorship of Karuthiah Pandian refuses to acknowledge. BDU registrar G Gopinath told TOI that there was a communication gap between BIM and BDU. “BIM has modified some of its bylaws and we wanted clarification. The university has requested the higher education department to give directions on accepting the modified bylaws,” he said.

This being an internal communication and students should not be affected, they had issued the degree certificate of all the 117 students to BIM, he said. In 2011, it made some changes that may not be adhering to the university standards. While it was also not approved by the syndicate, they had sought clarification, he added.

Title: Parents of kids with rare diseases join hands to form awareness network
Content:
Kolkata: Dilip Singh and wife Prity were heart-broken when their son was detected with a rare genetic disorder for which there was no cure. That was about three and a half years ago. The couple later not only picked up pieces to give the best care to their eight-year-old son but also formed a network of parents, whose children are grappling with rare diseases. Giving them constant boost is the Organisation for Rare Diseases India ( ORDI ).

“My wife gave up her financial sector job and I chose a job profile that is less demanding so that we could take care of our son. Luckily, we can afford his medication. But there are many parents who cannot. That’s why we need to have a well-defined policy on rare diseases,” said Singh, a bank employee.

Singh’s son suffers from Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy ( DMD ), a condition in which there is progressive weakness and loss of skeletal and heart muscles. The treatment is done only to lessen the symptoms.

“Doctors told me that my daughter will not survive beyond a month. Though everyday is a battle, she is now going to be a year-old. I wish doctors were more informed and had guided us in a better way,” said Ultadanga resident Subhro Das. The state employee’s first child suffers from Edward’s syndrome, a condition in which an extra chromosome disrupts the normal pattern of development in the baby that can be life threatening even before birth.

“Parents like us do not know where to go. And that’s why we formed the network with help of ORDI,” said Pinaki Talukdar, whose son suffers from DMD. Everything was fine with Talukdar’s son till the age of five. Today at 12, he depends on wheelchair for movement and a bi-pap for breathing assistance. To raise awareness, ORDI has come up with Racefor7 , a multi-city run/walk in 20 cities, including Kolkata. “The state too has taken up a proactive approach by forming a task force,” said Dipanjana Datta, state coordinator for ORDI.

Title: Bike thief pushes cop, flees custody
Content:
Margao: Gaby Fernandes, 25, a resident of Ambeudak, Sanvordem, who was arrested by the Cuncolim police in a case of theft of a two-wheeler, escaped from police custody when he was brought to Hospicio, Margao, for a routine medical check-up on Wednesday night.

Police sources said the accused had several cases of theft booked against him and the police had been on the lookout for him. Based on an arrest warrant issued against him, the Curchorem police had arrested him five days ago. On Wednesday, the Cuncolim police took him into custody on a transfer warrant, for interrogation. As a procedural requirement, he was taken for a medical examination at Hospicio, from where the thief gave the police escort the slip .

Police sources said the accused seized the opportunity to escape when one of the two police escorts had gone to the washroom . He pushed the other policeman and fled, sources said.

South Goa SP Arvind Gawas said the two police constables, Sarvesh Naik and Raju Talpikar, have been suspended, and a departmental inquiry ordered into the case. An offence under sections 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of duty) and 224 (resistance or obstruction to lawful apprehension) of the IPC has been registered against Fernandes.

Title: Drowned teen’s body surfaces after 40 hours
Content:
Ponda: The body of Sunny Mathur, 18, a native of Jharkhand who drowned on Tuesday afternoon in the Okamb Bandhara at Codar village on River Khandepar, surfaced on Thursday morning, after 40 hours of the drowning.

The boy went missing in the water on Tuesday afternoon and was not located despite the efforts by the Ponda police and fire and emergency services staff, said Ponda PI Mohan Gaude. Police said a group of around seven migrant youth residing at Adcolna, Banastarim. had ventured into the water after celebrating Holi.

After enjoying a swim for sometime, his friends found that Sunny was missing.

A case of unnatural death has been registered and the body has been handed over to Mathur’s family.

Title: Shops, hosps fined for polluting Vaigai
Content:
Madurai: Even as Madurai corporation is taking efforts to beautify Vaigai river as part of Smart City programme, dumping of waste into the river by residents and shops continues to be a major challenge to it. On Thursday, corporation officials collected fine to the tune of Rs 29,500 from shops and hospitals dumping waste into the river.

Vaigai River Front Development project is a Rs 81.41 crore plan aimed at developing the entire stretch of the river in the city, from Raja Mill Road to Kuruvikkaran Salai for a distance of 3.1 km. Once completed, it is envisaged to provide residents a much-wanted recreation spot with parks, seating facility, walking tracks and play areas for children. Retaining walls are also being constructed along the banks. While this work is in progress, corporation officials are also taking steps to prevent the dumping of solid waste into the river and also trying to arrest the flow of sewage into it. Surprise checks are conducted along the banks on a regular basis. On Thursday, a team of officials inspected various parts of the city. The banks of the river were also inspected and 11 shops and a couple of hospitals found to be dumping waste into the river imposed fines on the spot.

They also inspected shops near the Sri Meenakshi Sundareswarar temple as well as fruit, vegetable and flower markets. A total of 355 shops were inspected and 29 of them fined Rs 18,900 for possessing banned plastic bags. In all, 65 kilogram of plastics were also seized from them.

Title: ‘Basic rights should be taught in schools’
Content:
Trichy: Litigants Welfare Association (LWA), Trichy, wrote to the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC) seeking direction to school syllabus committee of Tamil Nadu for including the basic rights and responsibilities of Indian citizens as part of their curriculum.

While the state government had acknowledged the request made by the association two years back, president of the association, M Sekaran, sought NHRC intervention for the implementation of the two-year-old demand. We had appealed to include the basic and primary law education in school curriculum for Class IX -XII, said Sekaran.

“They should know the constitutional rights, duties, responsibilities and law related to consumer protection, food safety, human rights and right to Information,” he said. The basic civil and criminal laws will educate them about crimes and how to prevent criminal offenses. They will learn about how to tackle if they face problems and what are the helpline systems available under law, said Sekaran. tnn

Title: Polls to six new municipal bodies on April 5
Content:
JAIPUR: Elections to the posts of 560 ward members in the six newly formed municipal corporations in Jaipur, Kota and Jodhpur will be held on April 5, the state election commission (SEC) announced on Thursday. The counting of votes will take place on April 7. Meanwhile, the elected ward members will elect the mayors on April 16 and the counting of votes will be held on the same day.

The election to the post of deputy mayors will be held on April 17. The model code of conduct (MCC) comes into force in these municipal areas with immediate effect and will continue till April 17. The polls will be conducted with EVMs (Electronic Voting Machines) for all posts in the six corporations.

The six newly formed Nagar Nigams are — Jaipur Heritage and Jaipur Greater (Jaipur), Jodhpur North and Jodhpur South (Jodhpur), Kota North and Kota South (Kota).

Over 35.97 lakh voters will exercise their franchise during the elections to the six municipal corporations, informed state election commissioner P S Mehra. Of these, 18.76 lakh voters are male and 17.21 lakh are female voters. There are 41 third gender voters in these civic bodies. There will be 3,241 polling stations for the elections to the municipal corporations.

The voters can seek any election-related information, about their ward numbers and polling stations by SMSing on 7065051222. One should type - SEC VOTER_Epic No - and SMS it to the number.

“The commission has made available a software to the district election officers for the randomization of poll officials for the formation of polling and counting parties. The polling and counting parties will be formed through this software. The polling parties will be provided training in two levels. The shifting of the EVMs can also be tracked online through this software,” said Mehra.

He said permission has to be sought from the election officers for the use of loudspeakers and there is restriction on its use from 10.00pm to 6.00am.

“This poll expenditure limit for the election to the post of members has been fixed at Rs 2.50 lakh. The expenditure limit on the use of vehicles, loudspeakers, cut-outs, hoardings, posters and banners has been increased for the elections. Earlier, the expenditure limit fixed by the commission in 2014 was Rs 80,000. The details of expenditure are required to be submitted to the district election officers within 15 days of declaration of results,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: IIM-Ahmedabad cancels convocation
Content: AHMEDABAD: India’s premier B-school IIM Ahmedabad (IIM-A) on Thursday announced the cancellation of its annual convocation. The official press release cited the advisory issued by the Union ministry of health and family welfare and the World Health Organization for the move.‘In view of the advisories issued by the ministry of health and family welfare and the World Health Organization, to avoid large gatherings since the eruption of the COVID-19 coronavirus outbreak, we have decided to defer the annual convocation scheduled for March 21, 2020,’ read the release.‘The decision has been taken to preclude any risks to students and their extended families and friends as well as to the faculty and employees of the institute.’IIM-A officials said a total of 498 students of PGP, PGP-FABM, PGPX and FPM courses were to get the degrees at the convocation. “An announcement regarding dates for receiving degrees will be made soon, students can have their pictures clicked while receiving the degree. But it will be spaced out over several days, so that probable spread can be prevented.Respective course office would arrange for the disbursing of gold medals and academic honours as well,” said a senior official.IIM-A has provided hand sanitizers outside dorms and classrooms and has engaged the student health club ‘Panacea’ to organize awareness events with faculty members, students and families on campus, said officials. Sources said the institute is keeping close watch on exchange students coming from and going to destinations abroad.The B-school is the first to cancel major academic events in the city while several academic conferences and workshops by various city and state-based universities are under a shadow.63 samples negativeAs on Thursday afternoon, Gujarat laboratories had tested 65 samples. In all, 63 have tested negative and the results for two are pending, state health department officials said. The officials said that they are receiving more than 500 calls daily on the fever helpline of which about 200 relate to COVID-19. As on Thursday, 2,611 travellers have been screened at airports of whom 1,217 have completed the 14-day observation period. On Thursday, 250 more travellers were screened, said health department officials. Civil Hospital said no new case was registered till Thursday evening.

Title: MGVCL staff, police attacked during inspection at Savli village
Content:
Vadodara: Staff of Madhya Gujarat Vij Company Ltd (MGVCL) and police were attacked at by some villagers of Tundav in Vadodara district during inspection on Thursday.

Twenty-one persons were booked at Bhadarwa police station for rioting, causing hurt, hurting a public servant to prevent him from performing duties and criminal intimidation.

According to MGVCL officials, 10 teams were formed as instructed by Gujarat Urja Vikas Nigam Ltd to conduct an inspection at Tundav village in Savli taluka on Thursday morning. During inspection, seven illegal electric connections were found due to which the electric metres and wires were snapped and seized. At one of the houses when the officials were removing the metre, the owner of the house Deepak Bhalavat threatened an MGVCL official S J Makwana. Makwana was told to not remove the metre or else he will have to face consequences.

Soon the crowd was swelling seeing which MGVCL officials were quickly preparing to leave the village. However, Bhalavat and his father gathered villagers and instigated them to attack the staff. Meanwhile, a police constable Dharmesh Thakorbhai who was along with MGVCL staff tried to convince the villagers to not break the law. However, they did not heed to his advice and started pelting stones.

Police said that windshields of six vehicles of MGVCL were damaged and Thakorbhai suffered injuries on his shoulder due to stone pelting. The cop was treated at government health centre in Bhadarwa.

On the basis of complaint by a deputy engineer of MGVCL, Bhalavat, his father Dilip and 19 other villagers were booked. One of the accused identified as Allarakha Rathod was arrested on Thursday evening.

Title: CAA protest at Jinnah Thidal continues
Content:
Madurai: The protest called by members of Muslim community at Jinnah Thidal, Mahaboobpalayam in Madurai continued for the 28th day. A large number of women took part in the protest, which is been carried out day and night. This protest was started in the aftermath of the mild lathicharge on Anti-CAA proteters in Chennai last month.

The Shaheen Bagh style protest has been taking place peacefully. The protesters have been raising slogans against Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). Leaders from various political parties, who have been coming to the city, are visiting the protesters to lend their support. They also make speeches explaining issues with CAA and NRC.

A police officer said that adequate police protection is being provided at the protest venue. They are not being disturbed by the police nor have they created any law and order issue till now, police official said. tnn

Title: Zero tolerance on child porn: Govt notifies new Pocso rules
Content:
NEW DELHI: The government has notified the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Rules 2020, enabling implementation of recent amendments to the Act that made punishment provisions more stringent and for the first time defined child pornography and provided for crackdown for possession of pornographic material involving children. The Pocso rules became effective from March 9.

The rules specify that state governments must formulate a child protection policy based on the principle of zero-tolerance to violence against children, which shall be adopted by all institutions, organisations, or any other agency working with children. The provision comes on the back of recent cases of child sexual abuse in child care institutions, including in Muzaffarpur in Bihar and Deoria in UP.

Laying out the detailed modalities for reporting of pornographic material involving a child, the rules state that "any person who has received any pornographic material involving a child or any information regarding such pornographic material being stored, possessed, distributed, circulated, transmitted, facilitated, propagated or displayed, or is likely to be distributed, facilitated or transmitted in any manner shall report the contents to the special juvenile police unit (SJPU) or police, or the cyber-crime portal".

The rules also specify that such persons will also hand over all necessary material, including the source from which such material may have originated, to the authorities.

The report will have to include details of the device in which such pornographic content was noticed and the suspected device from which such content was received including the platform on which the content was displayed. This provision is significant as it makes accountable those platforms on which child pornography is circulated.

The rules also call upon the Centre and state governments to create widespread awareness about the procedures of making such reports from time to time.

It also lay down that state government will have to prepare age-appropriate educational material and curriculum for children, informing them about various aspects of personal safety, including measures to protect their physical and virtual identity.

It has also been stipulated that any institution housing children or coming in regular contact with children including schools, crechesor any other facility must ensure a police verification and background check of every staff member on periodic basis.

Title: Temp drops by 3 degrees as cool northerly wind blows
Content:
A motorcyclist cruises down Jangli Maharaj Road near College of Engineering ground on Thursday

PUNE: The minimum temperature in the city plunged to the season's second lowest at 14.4°C in Shivajinagar on Thursday after the re-emergence of the northerly wind flow.

The lowest night temperature in March when the pre-monsoon season began this year was 13.7°C recorded in Shivajinagar on March 4.

A senior India Meteorological Department (IMD) scientist told TOI that the northerly wind flow has begun in the lower atmospheric level and is likely to continue till March 15. Night temperatures are thus likely to hover between 14°C and 15°C till Saturday in Pune.

“Even day temperatures in the city are on the lower side because we have the cold, northerly wind component entering Pune during the day time along with partly cloudy skies. Both factors have caused a significant dip in day temperatures which have plunged below normal by over 4 degrees celsius,” he said.

On Thursday, the day temperature in Shivajinagar was 31°C, around 4.4°C below the normal while it was 31.7°C in Lohegaon, 4.3 degrees below the normal. Lohegaon’s minimum temperature early on Thursday was 16.5°C .

Nashik, Shivajinagar and Mahabaleshwar recorded the lowest minimum temperatures in Maharashtra on Thursday. The lowest was in Nashik at 14.2°C, while Mahabaleshwar’s minimum was the same as Shivajinagar’s.

The IMD on Thursday said maximum temperatures have been appreciably below normal (-3.1°C to -5.0°C) at a few places over West Madhya Pradesh, Madhya Maharashtra, Marathawada , Chhattisgarh and Telangana, among others.

Almost all locations in Maharashtra are recording below normal day temperatures, the highest negative departures being witnessed in Jalgaon, Pune, Nashik, Osmanabad , Aurangabad and Chandrapur .

Title: Senior citizen cheated of Rs 30,000
Content:
Nashik: A senior citizen was cheated of Rs 29,999 by an unidentified caller on the pretext of re-starting his online wallet system.

According to cyber police station, the complainant — 65-year-old Girish Deshpande , a resident of Vrundavan Nagar — got a call from the conman who told him that his online wallet account has been suspended.

“In order to restart the wallet, the caller told Deshpande to update the ‘Know Your Client’ (KYC) details. The conman then asked the complainant to share his debit card details,” a police officer said.

“The incident occurred between March 5 and March 6. The caller also sought the one-time password (OTP) from Deshpande. After the complainant shared the OTP, the money was debited from his bank account,” he added.

Deshpande got to know about the con on Wednesday when he went checked his account balance. Later, he went to the cybercrime police station and lodged a complaint.

“We are seeking details of the unidentified caller and working on priority to nab him,” the officer said.

Title: Youth told to keep off drug-alcohol mix and ganja
Content:
Trichy: Asking students to keep off drugs, A Venkadesh Babu, assistant commissioner, Central Bureau of Narcotics, Chennai, said a new trend of mixing alcohol with a prescription drug is picking up among youngsters.

“While this gives an overwhelming level of intoxication, it is equally harmful,” he said while addressing students at St Joseph’s College Trichy on Thursday. Delivering a talk on “Drugs and Addictions”, he said alcoholics often increase their alcohol intake over a period as they find the intoxication insufficient. This could perhaps be a reason for such trend picking up as the level of intoxication is overwhelming when sedatives or pain medication is mixed with alcohol. But it can slow the heart rate leading to death,” he said.

Saying that Indians are psychologically addicted to prescription than drugs, he said people even deem a doctor unfit if he or she refers for tests than giving medicines. But deaths caused by legal drugs (prescription drugs) are more in number than those caused by drugs the world over. He said these drugs are poison if taken beyond a limit consistently.

Citing his previous interactions with college students, he said there is an advocacy especially among students that cannabis can be taken as it’s a natural product and there are no harmful effects. “One of the students asked why cannabis are not legal in the country unlike western countries, but I told him that ganja cannot be good for healthy living. There is misconception among youngsters over its usage,” he said.

“Over three-decade-long research finding reveals that ganja abuse will lead to intellectual and physical disability apart from affecting IQ level up to 8 points. Hallucinations and dependency are other ill-effects,” he said. He asked students to stay connected with parents and friends which will keep them away from evils.

Title: Seafarer held for raping teen girl at Ambaulim
Content:
Margao: Maina-Curtorim police on Thursday arrested a 23-year-old resident of Moll, Sao Jose de Areal, on charges of abducting and raping a 13-year-old girl on Wednesday afternoon. The police managed to nab the accused during the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday.

Police said the accused was a seaman and had come to Goa recently. On Wednesday afternoon, while the survivor was walking home from school, he offered her a lift on his motorcycle. As he was an acquaintance, the survivor didn’t suspect anything amiss and accepted his offer. However, instead of dropping her home, police said he took her to a hillock in distant Ambaulim, near Quepem, and raped her.

As the girl had failed to return home from school, a missing person’s report was filed at the Maina-Curtorim police station and a case of kidnapping registered .

“A massive search operation was conducted around the place where the girl was last seen. Late Wednesday evening, the survivor was found in an unconscious state on the hillock by locals of Ambaulim and had injuries on her body. While she was shifted to hospital, movements of all suspects in the area were checked. Several suspects were rounded up and finally the accused was nabbed from his house. He later confessed to the crime,” South Goa SP Arvind Gawas told reporters.

The accused, Gawas said, assaulted her and even banged her head on the ground after she tried to resist his advances. As the victim became unconscious, he abandoned her and fled the scene.

The man was arrested under provisions of the Indian Penal Code, Goa Children’s Act and Protection of Children against Sexual Offences Act and remanded in 10 days’ police custody.

Title: Stalemate over work on solar dome continues
Content:
Vadodara: There seems to be no certainty regarding resumption of work on the solar dome, one of the showcase projects of the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) coming up on the Akota-Dandiabazaar road. Work on the project was stopped on January 27 after the large bamboo scaffolding erected there collapsed injuring one labour.

Ever since the incident took place, the VMC and the agency that have taken up work are involved in hectic discussions over the issue of stopping traffic on the road for resuming work there. Till the January 27 incident, traffic was stopped only on one lane on the road under the dome while work was conducted by erecting scaffolding on the remaining portion.

According to VMC officials, the complete closure of work has been sought by the contractor to ensure that the work on fixing aluminium composite panels on the ceiling of the dome is completed in time. On the other end, VMC officials are wary that closing the road completely would throw traffic out of gear and create chaos on the Old Padra Road where work on the longest flyover in the state has already led to traffic woes.

Officials added that they were already holding meetings with the traffic branch of the city police to find alternate routes and regulate traffic if it was absolutely necessary to close the traffic. Sources said that technology to conduct work using cranes and other means was available, but this was a costly affair and not viable.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Get in touch with Indians stuck in Iran, Delhi high court tells Centre
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi high court on Thursday ordered the central government to ensure that the Indian embassy in Iran gets in touch with stranded Indian students, in the wake of coronavirus outbreak. It said instead of “merely issuing advisories”, the government must “do a little more” to evacuate over 3,000 Indian nationals, including pilgrims, fishermen and students, stranded in Iran.On its part, Centre said that mass evacuation was not possible as Iran had banned all commercial flights from February 26. Secondly, the Centre said, those stranded had to be tested for the fast spreading virus before they could be brought back to the country.The government admitted there was no local support on the ground from Iranian authorities and it took several rounds of negotiations before Indian scientists were allowed to set up a lab there to draw samples from Indian citizens.The Iranian government only recently allowed an Indian Air Force aircraft to evacuate 58 nationals, including 25 women and two children, the central government stated.Assuring the court that the local embassy was in contact with Indian nationals in Iran and advisories had been issued to them on following the health protocols issued by WHO, the government said that embassy officials were travelling to all the locations where Indians were stranded to assure them of all possible assistance for their safe and early return.The court, however, remarked that merely issuing advisories was not going to help. “You know where students are. You have to contact them. Not doing so won’t be tolerated. Get in touch with them and give a report by March 17,” it noted.

Title: ‘Covid-19 more contagious, less deadly than past zoonotic viruses’
Content: AHMEDABAD: The novel coronavirus disease (Covid-19) is not our first brush with a zoonotic (pathogen spread from animals to humans) coronavirus, but is more contagious and fortunately less deadly, said Dr Surabhi Madan, infectious diseases consultant, at a public lecture on Covid-19 at Science City on Thursday.“There have been six or seven widely known coronaviruses, including the 2003 SARS strain and 2012’s MERS virus. Four cause mild diseases, including 15% of upper respiratory infections (URIs). Covid-19 is different. It is more contagious and less deadly than SARS and MERS, the number of cases were in the few thousands and mortality rates were 10-11% for SARS and 37% for MERS. As of now, Covid-19 has more than a lakh known cases across the globe and mortality rates of 2% to 4%, depending on the country,” said Dr Madan.She added that the virus is thought to spread through droplets and there is no evidence to show it can spread through the air. “It is thus advised that one should keep a distance of about six feet from an infected person. About 99% of cases manifest in two to 14 days of infection,” she said.The World Health Organization (WHO) has already declared Covid-19 a pandemic, due to its global spread. This strain has not previously been seen in humans. The WHO website says that several known coronaviruses circulating in animals have not yet infected humans.Dr Madan advised the audience not to panic and blindly following information from social media. “Prevention is better than cure, disinfect your hands frequently. There is no need to wear masks if you are not a medical professional or are not infected,” she said.

Title: Rajini no MGR to succeed in politics: Cong
Content:
Thanjavur: Tamil Nadu Congress Committee president K S Alagiri has said that actor Rajinikanth is not M G Ramachandran to succeed in politics. Commenting on the actor’s announcement about launching a party, Alagiri said he doesn’t share the expectations of Rajini fans that he would come into active politics. “His fans still believe that Rajinikanth will launch a party and subsequently plunge into electoral politics in the forthcoming assembly elections in the state. But I am not convinced that he will do that,” he added.

Replying to questions at Thirupananthal near Kumbakonam after attending a marriage here on Thursday, Alagiri said Rajnikanth is a good actor but not M G Ramachandran. So, his efforts will not succeed. However, the Congress would not oppose him if he would like to enter politics, he added. On the CAA, NRC and NPR, the Congress president promised to protect minorities. “We can assure that the Congress party and its allied secular parties are the only hope of minorities in the country. As long as Congress is there, nobody will send even a single minority out of the country. Both Prime Minister Narendra Modi and home minister Amit Shah are just making threats”, he added.

Title: 2 construction labourers killed in wall collapse
Content:
Madurai: Two construction labourers were killed in Ramanathapuram town after a wall collapsed on them on Thursday. The incident took place while the labourers were resting during the lunch break.

The deceased were identified as M Balasubramanian, 60, from Kothan Street and A Palsamy, 65, from Omsakthi Nagar. The two were involved in construction work of a building in Sigil Rajaveethi in Ramanathapuram town. An old building was demolished in order to construct a new one. However, a wall in the building was yet to be razed down. The duo was sitting next to the wall when it suddenly collapsed on them. Though workers rushed to the spot to rescue the duo, both of them were found dead under the debris. On being alerted, a police team reached the spot and recovered the bodies. The bodies were shifted to Ramanathapuram government hospital for autopsy. Based on a complaint a case was registered with Bazaar police station and an inquiry was carried out.TNN

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: Visa curbs impose heavy costs
Content: AHMEDABAD: Several countries have imposed travel restrictions in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. India followed suit on Wednesday by suspending all tourist visas from March 13 to April 15. The move has triggered anxiety among travellers, who are booking tickets at the last minute to fly back home.“My relatives had come to Ahmedabad from the US to shop for an upcoming wedding and were to return on March 20,” said Sanjay Patel, an Ahmedabad businessman. “However, with the Indian government imposing restrictions on travel, they are worried about their departure and therefore have advanced their tickets to March 13.”Tour operators said that a number of travellers had to pay extra to book tickets at the last minute while others who were scheduled to visit India had to bear cancellation charges.Travel restrictions imposed by other countries have also caused problems for Indians who are unable to return. “My parents are in Doha for the past three months and were scheduled to return on March 14,” said Shebaz Katar, who works with a logistics company in Doha, Qatar. “However, with the government here imposing travel restrictions on about 14 countries including India, we had to cancel their tickets.” Hoteliers in Ahmedabad have begun receiving cancellations.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Hotels lay off employees as occupancy falls to 20%
Content: JAIPUR: Growing fears of coronavirus and visa suspension for travel to India have dwelt a heavy blow to the hotel industry, which is witnessing dramatic fall in occupancies. With businesses coming to a standstill, some hotels have started laying off staff.Many hoteliers TOI spoke to said that occupancies that stood at 65-70% on March 1, have come down to 22-30%. Baring a few weddings that had been booked much earlier, all other events including corporate meetings, conferences, and exhibitions have been cancelled.They said that the domestic visitors, who account for a large pie of the total business, have also stopped travelling, resulting in a sharp decline in hotel occupancies.“The worst fears are coming true. The situation is not far from being panic. The dramatic decline in occupancies shows that. Even people are increasingly avoiding to dine out. The industry is in pretty bad shape now,” said a hotelier, preferring anonymity.With demand drying up, some standalone hotels have started laying off employees, while some leading hotel chains said there is no retrenchment of staff who are on pay roll as of now.“It’s difficult for standalone hotels to manage the situation if they do not bring down operating costs. That includes letting some people go till the situation improves. While big chain hotels have not gone for job cuts as yet, they are not hiring temporary staff,” said a general manager of the hotel.Manpower expenses as percentage of total operating costs have been rising in the past few years. He said, “It used to be around 18% of the total operating cost but now the expenses have gone up to 24%. So, it is natural that hotels will reduce manpower count to manage their finances.”Tour operators and travel agents in Jaipur said that their business has come to a standstill and now it would be difficult to manage unless they undertake deep cost cutting measures.“So far, the tour operators and travel agents have not sacked any people. But in coming weeks that will happen. If there is no income, how can they pay their staff,” said Sanjay Kaushik of Rajputana Holidaymakers Pvt Ltd.Great Indian Travel Bazaar (GITB), one of the last events that was not cancelled or postponed till now, is likely to follow suit. GITB, a leading business networking platform for inbound tourism, is attended by large number of foreign buyers and the event was scheduled to be held from April 19-21. But with visa suspension in place, this will also fall prey to the spread of Covid-19.

Title: Schools Closed in Jaipur: Many private schools in Jaipur declare holiday
Content: JAIPUR: Many private schools in the city have declared holiday until further notice in the wake of the spread of Covid-19.According to school managements, the move to shut the schools is a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of virus.Jayshree Periwal International School on Thursday announced that the school will remain closed starting Friday, until further notice. After an 87-year-old man from Jaipur was tested positive for coronavirus, there were rumours that his grandchildren are studying in Jayshree Periwal International School. The school clarified on Friday that none of his grandchildren are studying there.Maharaja Sawai Man Singh Vidyalaya had already announced closure since last week. The Delhi Public School will have its last exam on Friday for classes 6 to 8 after which the school will be closed. “All our exams are over except one after which the school is on a break. Our new session will anyway start from April first week. However, we usually start our new session for class 10 and 12 from March, which we have specially called off due to the outbreak of covid-19,” said Sangeeta Kain, the school principal.Similarly, Maharani Gayatri Devi School declared off for classes 1 and 2 since last week and the rest of the school is going on a break till April 7 and further decision will be taken later. Archana Mankotia, principal of the school, said, “Board exams are on and the hence the school is open. Students are allowed wearing masks and sanitizers are provided to them. We are taking all the necessary precautions.”Authorities of Subodh Public School, Jaipur, said their annual exams are going on after which the school will be closed as per schedule, said Sanjay Parashar, public relations officer of the school.Schools across Jaipur have said that if any order is issued by the district administration to shut the schools, they will abide by it.

Title: Authorities scramble to curb price of masks
Content:
Madurai: Even as the state and Union ministry of health and family welfare insist that there is no need as of now for healthy individuals to use surgical masks to protect oneself against Covid-19, the sale, cost and demand for face masks have shot up across the state, including Madurai.

“Manufacturers are getting far more orders than usual and they have had to step up production. I can assure you that there is no mask shortage for doctors and health workers. However, they will not be able to match this unusually high demand from the public,” said K Manoharan, president, Tamil Nadu Chemists and Druggists Association. He also said that the association has asked manufacturers to double check actual requirement before catering to unusually high bulk orders even from hospitals. “For work purposes, I have to visit hospitals sometimes and keep some masks in hand. During the past few weeks, I went to a couple of pharmacies and found that they sold masks for up to Rs 30 apiece, which cost below Rs 10 before,” said a salesperson from Anna Nagar.

Pharmacists and pharmaceutical associations have urged customers, including public, doctors, hospitals and clinics to buy responsibly to avoid causing a shortage of masks to those who really need it. They said the cost of mask has actually more than doubled not just because of demand and supply but also because of the increased manufacturing costs. “We are trying to strictly regulate and are insisting on a uniform affordable price for surgical masks to around Rs 14-21 depending on the type and quality. We are taking measures to ensure masks shortage is prevented and is affordable,” said C Manohar, founder-secretary, Madurai Mavatta Marunthu Vanigargal Sangam.

Drugs Control Administration, Tamil Nadu is actively monitoring sale of masks, and have asked public to come forward in case of complaints of overpricing or quality issues. A medical representative said, “I’ve seen some manufacturers almost shut down production of masks because there was hardly any profit but now they are taking advantage of the high demand. Some may pass off low quality mask as higher quality one at a higher cost” .

Title: DMK, ruling party cross swords over public exams for Class V, VIII
Content:
Chennai: The state government may have scrapped its move to hold public exams for Class V and Class VIII but the issue became a point of debate between the opposition DMK and ruling AIADMK during the demand for grants for school education and higher education departments in the assembly on Thursday.

While former minister and DMK MLA K Ponmudi gave credit to his party which “forced the government to back off” from conducting the exams, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami said it had to be scrapped because of the defamatory campaigns of the opposition.

Continuing his speech, Ponmudi said if the exams were conducted there would be more dropouts and rural students would be affected. To this, chief minister said the rural students needed to be prepared for competitive exams on a par with urban students.

The DMK member also brought to the attention of the minister the increase in school dropouts in Classes IX and X in the state as per the data submitted in Parliament by the HRD minister. To this, school education minister K A Sengottaiyan said there were many inconsistencies in the data prepared by the Union government.

Another DMK MLA J L Eswarappan said the revised textbooks, for Class 1XII for instance, were heavier and teachers were not able to complete the syllabus. As per the existing calendar, teachers were short of 31 days for volume 1 and 34 days for volume 2.

Minister Sengottaiyan accepted that the books were heavier. “The text books were revised based on the inputs from the experts committee. We have formed a committee to review the textbooks. Whatever the shortfalls in the present books will be rectified the next year,” he said.

“Like giving formula one car to a Maruti car driver, the state government has handed over the revised textbooks to the teachers without training them. Teachers are not able to understand the lessons and students are not aware of even the basic topics,” the DMK MLA said.

The chief minister interrupted and said education could be provided based on current standards. “You are opposing Class V and VIII board exams and not allowing students to improve their standards. We are seeking your cooperation to improve the standard of education and the government is open to suggestions,” he informed the house.

When the DMK member pointed out that not one among 19,666 students trained at the government sponsored coaching centres was able to get MBBS seat last year, Sengottaiyan said private school students were spending more money for NEET coaching. “We will shortlist 3,000 students for 35 days’ residential coaching. We are confident that at least 100 students from government schools would get medical seats this year.”

Title: Two minor bonded labourers rescued from cattle owner
Content:
Tiruvarur: Two minor boys, who were working as bonded labourers, have been rescued near Valangaiman in Tiruvarur district on March 10. The boys from Sivaganga district, who were siblings, had been herding around 200 goats belonging to Koori Murugan, 33, of Odaikulam Kadaladi in Ramanathapuram district.

Murugan had hired the boys, aged 13 and 12 years, for Rs 45,000 and Rs 35,000 respectively, revenue officials said. The boys’ parents were constructing a house. As they had no money to continue the construction work, they sent the boys to herd the goats of Murugan after receiving money from him. The couple have four boys and two daughters.

The herd owner took the boys to Orathanadu in Thanjavur district. Three months ago, the boys were taken to Aravathur village near Valangaiman in Tiruvarur district. A villager called Childline 1098 to inform officials about the boys working as bonded labourers. Childline officials alerted Tiruvarur revenue divisional officer (RDO) S Jayaprithaa.

As per the instructions of the RDO, a team comprising Valangaiman tahsildar, district child protection officer, revenue inspector, Aravathur VAO and labour officials was formed to rescue the boys.

“We monitored the boys for a day and rescued them on Tuesday night when they returned to their camp. After interrogation with the boys, we took them to the RDO on Wednesday”, district child protection officer P Selvaraj said.

The RDO told TOI that the siblings had been given release certificates and Rs 20,000 each. Based on a complaint lodged by revenue inspector S Saravanan, the Valangaiman police registered a case against Murugan and arrested him.

The boys would be enrolled in a school in Sivaganga district, officials said.

Title: Travel agents worried over TCS
Content:
Vadodara: Travel agents from the state are a harried lot these days. Already reeling under poor business due to coronavirus scare, the union government proposal of tax collected at source (TCS) has only added to their woes.

TCS that will be applicable for all the foreign travellers from April 1 this year.

“Our business is already suffering due to coronavirus scare. Those travelling abroad are now cancelling their plans and flight tickets too are getting costlier. In the coming months, the foreign bookings will shrink further,” said Bimal Mehta, former chairman of All India Domestic Tour Operators of India, Gujarat chapter.

“Due to TCS, the customers will have to pay an additional 5% on their travel cost apart from the5% GST. This will inflate their travel budget. The government has said that the 5% TCS will be refunded to the traveller when he or she files IT returns,” Mehta told TOI.

“But that is probably only for those who opt for older rebate scheme,” he added.

“TCS will not just affect the foreign travelling bookings but also increase lot of work for travel agents as we will have to take PAN card of the client and file all compliances with the government. It is additional work and smaller agencies don’t have such mechanism to deal with such compliances,” said Reena Gami, a Vadodara-based travel agent.

Mehta, who is a travel agent based in Ahmedabad, said added that the federation of travel agents associations have presented their case to the government. Travel agents across the country too have taken to twitter and are running a trend #savetravelindustry appealing the government to defer TCS till Coronavirus scare subsides.

Title: Kolkata police help for 3 Higher Secondary examinees on Day 1
Content:
Sub-inspector K C Debnath with Musmida Khatun’s admit card

KOLKATA: Police came to the rescue of at least three examinees who had either forgotten their admit cards or landed in wrong examination centres on the first day of Higher Secondary examinations. Like the Madhyamik examinations, cops deputed more men on roads who helped students reach their examination centres without any trouble.

Musmida Khatun, a student of Ultadanga United High School, reached her examination centre, Banipith Girls High School located on Canal West Road, leaving behind the admit card at her Udayanpally home in Salt Lake’s Mahisbathan.

K C Debnath, sub-inspector of Maniktala PS, who was on duty at the centre, noticed the girl standing anxiously outside the school. He alerted the OC about the matter immediately.

“Prompt initiative was taken by Debnath to ensure Khatun’s entry into the examination centre. He also made arrangements to get her admit card from home and handed it over to the exam invigilator,” said DC (ESD) Ajoy Prasad.

In the other incident, Amit Sengupta, additional OC of Beliaghata police, found HS examinee Salma Khatoon crying in front of Kamala Vidya Mandir School, barely 20 minutes before the examination. The student of Baitulmal High School told him that she had reached there by mistake while her examination centre was Desbandhu Girls Vidyapith at Narkeldanga. Sengupta took the help of Rakhi Das, a civic volunteer, and sent the girl to the centre in his own vehicle.

In the third incident, a student reached Dum Dum’s Kumar Ashutosh Institution (Auxiliary) instead of Ashutosh Institution (Main). Cops took him to the actual examination centre on a bike.

During the Madhyamik, there were seven instances where cops helped candidates get their admit cards.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Shortage of hand sanitiser in SPPU, affiliated colleges
Content: PUNE: Savitribai Phule Pune University and its affiliated colleges were found wanting in terms of measures to prevent the spread of Covid-19.The varsity students claimed that there was no provision for hand sanitisers or liquid soaps though the washrooms and other places were cleaned regularly. The same problem was highlighted by students of affiliated colleges.The University Grants Commission (UGC) has instructed all institutes to regularly disinfect door knobs and other public areas besides providing hand wash/sanitisers within the campus.Dayanand Shinde, a postgraduate student of Savitribai Phule Pune University (SPPU), said, “There is no soap or liquid soap in the washrooms. Hand sanitisers are not available despite the UGC’s instructions. Many people from outside visit the university. So, hand sanitiser should be made available even in library and laboratory.”Prafulla Pawar, the SPPU registrar, said, “We have provided soaps in all areas, let it be handwashing facilities or washrooms. There is a scarcity of hand sanitisers. We had tried to purchase sanitisers in bulk, but stocks are not available. If students say that soaps are not available in any of the washrooms, the administration will look into it.”He said, “We held a meeting on Wednesday with 250 staffers from the housekeeping department to train them in dos and don’ts. We also provided them with disinfectants. We have issued circulars to the affiliated colleges to strictly follow the UGC guidelines.”Dilip Sheth, the principal of Sir Parashurambhau College, said they were cleaning the washrooms on the college and hostel premises on a regular basis, but they refrained from keeping soap citing it as a mass germ carrier.“We shall form a policy in the next two-three days. At present, awareness among students is the key priority for us,” he said.When asked if hand sanitisers were available in the washrooms, Sheth replied in the negative.Devidas Golhar, the principal of Marathwada Mitramandal’s College of Commerce, said they were planning to procure masks for students, but there was a shortage. “We have provided liquid soap across staff rooms as well as students’ washrooms. Social gatherings have been cancelled,” he said.Ajinkya Adake, a student from the department of communication and journalism, SPPU, said the awareness about coronavirus was on the rise. “There is a possibility of unnecessary panic among citizens and students. Everybody seems to be sporting masks when there is no need for healthy individuals to wear one,” he said.

Title: Pune: Cops search for truck driver, cleaner in rape case
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The Alandi police on Wednesday launched a search for the driver and cleaner of a truck for allegedly raping a 29-year-old woman after offering her lift late on Tuesday night.

The woman in her complaint stated that the truck driver had promised to drop her at Perne Phata. But, she claimed, the driver and the cleaner raped her inside the cabin of the moving truck. The duo abandoned her near Talegaon Dabhade along Pune-Mumbai highway in the early hours of Wednesday and drove away, the complaint stated.

The woman approached police with the help of a housing society’s watchman and lodged a complaint. The case was transferred to the Alandi police for further probe after an FIR was registered with Shirgaon police.

An officer from the Alandi police said according to the woman’s statement, she left home after a quarrel on Tuesday night and decided to go to the house of one of her relatives. “While waiting for a transport at Alandi around 11pm, a truck driver stopped and told her that he would drop her till Perne Phata,” he said.

After the woman boarded the truck, the driver drove towards Pimpri Chinchwad instead of going to Perne Phata. “When the woman asked the driver why he was going in that direction, he threatened and beat her up. He then raped her inside the truck’s cabin. The truck’s cleaner, too, raped her,” the officer said.

He said the suspects travelled with the woman in the Pimpri Chinchwad area till the early hours of Wednesday. “Around 4am, they abandoned the woman near Talegaon Dabhade and fled,” he said.

The police have registered the offence under sections 376D (gang rape), 366 (kidnapping or inducing woman to compel her marriage), 341 (wrongful restraint) and 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) of the Indian Penal Code . “We have fanned teams to trace the duo,” the officer said.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Pune: Contractor in net for axing 27 trees at MSRTC depot
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: A private contractor (73) appointed to cut the branches of trees on the MSRTC depot premises on Shankarsheth Road was arrested on Wednesday on the charge of completely chopping down 27 trees.

The incident occurred between February 20 and 29.

The private contractor, Ravindra Sawale, will remain in police custody remand till Friday.

An officer from the Swargate police said Sawale was called for questioning and was arrested after he admitted to his involvement in getting the trees chopped.

“The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) had sought permission from the Pune Municipal Corporation ’s tree authority to cut the branches of the trees on the depot’s premises, three months ago. The branches were posing danger to passers-by,” senior police inspector Bramhanand Naikawadi from the Swargate police station told TOI.

“The PMC gave permission to MSRTC officials to cut the branches of the old trees. But, they could not be cut within the time limit because of a dearth of workers. The MSRTC then got the time limit extended from the PMC and the contractor started the work,” Naikawadi said.

“The MSRTC officials had explained to the contractor that the branches were in dangerous condition and needed to be cut. The contractor and his staff illegally chopped 27 trees and transported the logs,” Naikawadi said.

He added that they had seized logs of eight trees from Sawale. “A police team has been fanned for arresting the labour contractor,” he said.

The trees included Ashoka, Gulmohar, Almond, among others.

An MSRTC official Vijay Krishna Redekar (51) of Wadgaon Budruk had registered an FIR against the contractor and his staff on March 7, under the relevant sections of the Indian Penal Code and Forest Act.

Title: Rajya Sabha polls: Congress MLA moves Gujarat high court to secure voting right
Content:
Gujarat high court

AHMEDABAD: Congress MLA Natha Patel on Thursday moved the Gujarat high court to save his voting right for the March 26 Rajya Sabha polls in the state for four seats.

In his petition, Patel claimed his voting right might be taken away at the behest of the ruling BJP ahead of the Rajya Sabha polls. Patel’s petition came up for hearing before a division bench comprising Justices J B Pardiwala and Bhargav Karia, but the judges recused themselves, saying “not before me”. Now, it is expected that HC Chief Justice Vikram Nath will allot a new court on Friday to hear the plea.

The MLA from Dhanera in Banaskantha district became apprehensive about his voting right after a local BJP leader, Mukesh Thakkar, recently filed an application before the collector, claiming Patel had concealed “many things” while filing his affidavit for the 2017 assembly election. Thakkar, in his application, prayed that Patel be disqualified as an MLA under section 125 of the Representation of the People Act.

Upon getting the application some time back, Banaskantha collector Sandip Sagale ordered the local police as well as the returning officer of Dhanera to initiate an investigation and take necessary steps, said the petition.

Patel claimed the BJP is trying to reduce Congress votes to stop the opposition party from winning a second seat in the Rajya Sabha elections. The plea urged the court to issue a “writ of prohibition” against the collector’s past orders, claiming he does not have such powers to initiate an inquiry. According to the current equations in the house, the BJP and the Congress will get two seats each as 37 votes are required to win one seat. agencies

Title: DMK leader wants street dogs culled, minister says there’s no need
Content:
Deputy leader of opposition S Durai Murugan said the dogs must be ‘put to sleep’ to ensure safety of people

CHENNAI: Deputy leader of opposition S Durai Murugan created a flutter in the assembly on Thursday by demanding that street dogs be culled as they pose danger to people. With hundreds of dogs on streets across the state, people were not able to even walk freely, he said.

“If there were 10 to 20 dogs in an area earlier, now there are more than 100. In some areas, there are more than 200 street dogs. There could be rabid ones among them. To ensure safety of people, they need to be put to sleep,” said Durai Murugan.

Leader of the opposition M K Stalin and his senior colleagues seemed surprised over Durai Murugan’s demand. Many laughed at the idea. State health minister C Vijaya Baskar responded saying street dog population was under control. “Unlike the past when we all were threatened with 14 injections around our stomach if we were bitten by a dog, now there are better treatment options. Vaccines are available and all hospitals across the state are equipped to treat people with dog bites,” said the minister.

He said animal husbandry ministry was spaying street dogs to ensure birth control. “We are taking efforts to keep street dog population under control. There have been no human casualty owing to dog bite in recent times. People need not be unduly worried,” minister said.

Tambaram MLA S R Raja said Peerkankaranai government hospital did not have medicines for dog bites and wanted the minister to provide medicines in all hospitals on a war footing. Raja also demanded upgrading of the hospital with more doctors, nurses and equipment.

Title: CBI searches fireworks units in Sivakasi
Content:
Madurai: A team of CBI officials conducted searches in fireworks units in Sivakasi on Thursday based on a direction from the Supreme Court, to check if they were using banned chemicals for production. There are more than 1,000 fireworks industries in and around Sivakasi in which over 5 lakh workers are employed directly and indirectly.

Following charges of environmental pollution by the units, production was banned and later the industries were allowed to manufacture ‘green fireworks’ which were developed by CSIR-NEERI which emit less smoke and do not contain banned chemicals such as lithium, antimony, mercury, arsenic and lead.

A petition filed in Supreme Court on March 3 stated that banned chemicals were being used by manufacturers in Sivakasi. Following this, the apex court directed the CBI to inspect the industries. The team of CBI officials, including two ADSPs, a DSP and 14 CBI officials, went in seven groups and conducted the searches. Many of the units declared a holiday due to the search. The CBI will submit its report to the court.

Title: Congress nominates Solanki, Gohil for RS
Content:
Gandhinagar: The Congress on Thursday announced the names of the party’s national spokesman Shaktisinh Gohil and former Gujarat Pradesh Congress Committee chief Bharatsinh Solanki as its Rajya Sabha candidates for two seats from Gujarat.

Solanki’s name was included late in the evening, after reports that the party would nominate former chairman of the Indian Premier League (IPL) Rajeev Shukla from Gujarat drew strong opposition from Solanki’s camp.

With a view of the political crisis in Madhya Pradesh, with the defection of Jyotiraditya Scindia to the BJP, Gohil offered to withdraw his name to silence dissent that could have triggered a rebellion ahead of the high-stakes RS election on March 26. The party leadership chose to withdraw Shukla’s name instead and replaced him with Solanki.

Rajeev Shukla later tweeted thanking the Congress for offering the RS nomination from Gujarat. “... But currently, I am focussing on organizational work so requested her (Sonia Gandhi) to nominate some other person,” Shukla tweeted.

"Senior MLAs from Gujarat reiterated they would not accept any outsider candidate marring chances of local leaders like Bharatsinh Solanki and Arjun Modhwadi," said a top Congress leader. “... I come from Gandhi’s Gujarat and my dharma is to fight Godse worshipping central government that does not believe in justice, equality and democracy,” Gohil tweeted.

Earlier in the day, drama erupted as news spread that the party leadership had proposed Gohil and Shukla as its RS candidates.

Senior Congress MLAs such as Baldevji Thakor, C J Chavda, Pravin Maru and 20 MLAs made a representation to Gujarat unit president Amit Chavda, rooting for Solanki. They expressed their displeasure over the phone to senior leader Ahmed Patel, about the party giving preference to ‘outsider’ candidates like Shukla over local leaders like Solanki.

Baldevji Thakor, said, “We expressed our anguish over Rajiv Shukla’s proposed nomination. He is a national leader but we need to give prominence to local leaders having a mass base.”

BJP likely to field third candidate

Gandhinagar: After the formal nomination of two senior Congress leaders — former Gujarat Congress president Bharatsinh Solanki and former leader of opposition Shaktisinh Gohil — as the party’s Rajya Sabha candidates, the BJP decided it would put up a fight and field a third candidate, despite being certain of winning only two seats. BJP had held three of these four seats, but due to its fewer MLAs in the 2017 assembly elections, it is six votes short of securing the third seat. It is now hoping to get support from three MLAs of other parties support and ‘poach’ MLAs from the Congress.

Title: Water supply to southern, eastern parts to be affected
Content:
Vadodara: Water supply to parts of the eastern and southern parts of the city will be partially hit due to work on one of the filtration plants at the Nimeta water treatment facility. Water supply to the affected areas will be curtailed for about a week.

While other work on the water Nimeta water treatment plants had been completed by the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC), the replacement of valves in plant number three at the facility was pending. The civic body is looking to replace 28 valves in various parts of the plant at a cost of around Rs 18lakh.

Work on the replacement of the valves will begin on Friday and is expected to continue for about a week. The VMC, however, has not announced a deadline for completion of work in a public notice announcing the water cut.

The water cut, sources said, may be only for about five minutes a day. But the affected areas will also be getting water with low pressure. A population of around seven lakh people is likely to be affected.

Water supply to areas under the network of Manjalpur, Kapurai, Tarsali, Jambuva, Makarpura GIDC (new), Nalanda, Panigate and Gajrawadi tanks will be affected due to the work at Nimeta. Apart from these localities under the network of Danteshwar, Makarpura, Somatalav, Sankheda Dashalad and Mahanagar booster tanks will also be affected.

The Nimeta water filtration facility has been marred in a major controversy after it came to light that there were several lacunae in its maintenance. This had led to supply of turbid and yellow coloured water to the southern and eastern parts of the city for several months last year.

The civic body had suspended senior engineers as well as slapped notices to contractors regarding the state of affairs. It had come to light that the design of the plant was faulty and there were serious lapses in its maintenance too. Work had to be taken up on a war footing to fix things at the plant and restart the water supply.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Delhi hospitals saving medical fraternity from exposure
Content: NEW DELHI: Safdarjung Hospital has cancelled all functions, including seminars, workshops and conferences, in the wake of Covid-19 outbreak in the country.Similar steps are being taken by all leading medical colleges and hospitals in the city, first, to reduce the risk of spread of infection in medical community and secondly to focus on scaling up manpower and infrastructure needs for isolation and treatment of persons affected by the novel coronavirus in India.While Thursday recorded 74 Covid-19 cases in India, one death was also reported. To contain the spread of the disease, government has said that public events be cancelled. Many states have also ordered shutting down schools, colleges and cinema halls, including in the city.Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Thursday asked countrymen not to panic and asserted that the government was fully vigilant. Apart from directing Union ministers not to travel abroad in the upcoming days, PM Modi also urged people to avoid non-essential travel, saying: “We can break the chain of spread and ensure safety of all by avoiding large gatherings.”Disinfecting all public places, including government and private offices, shopping malls, has been made compulsory, chief minister Arvind Kejriwal said. Health officials said that India’s efforts to deal with coronavirus are in consonance with WHO and its focus is on preventive approach.Till now, health officials said, 11,14,025 people have been screened at 30 designated airports in the country.

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: GPS mapping of vulnerable areas
Content: PUNE: The district administration will use the Global Positioning System (GPS) to map coronavirus vulnerable zones, Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram said on Thursday.The exercise will be carried out as a part of the protocol issued by the central and state government health authorities. “As a part of the containment plan, vulnerable zones have been identified in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad, which will be mapped with the help of GPS,” the collector told TOI.As per the health department’s guidelines, after confirmation of a Covid-19 case in the urban areas, health officials cover the 3km and 5km radius around it. This stands at 3km and 7km radius from the confirmed case’s lodging in the rural areas. During their visit, the officials tell the residents to restrict “unnecessary movement”.Divisional commissioner Deepak Mhaisekar confirmed that the exercise was a part of the preventive measure plan.Both Ram and Mhaisekar reiterated that people should avoid giving out infected patients’ information on social media. Incidentally, a relative of one of the Covid-19 patients had written to the divisional commissioner on Wednesday, alleging that information about the infected patient was making the rounds on social media, creating hardships for the family. “The family is facing social boycott-like situation and this should not happen,’’ Mhaisekar said.The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has been asked to keep a thorough check on hoarding and pricing of masks and sanitisers. Mhaisekar said N95 masks were not needed for a general public. “All key officials from all departments have been contacted to ensure that there is proper monitoring of suspected cases,” he added.

Title: All remaining trips of Palace on Wheels cancelled
Content:
JAIPUR: Visa suspension for travel to India has taken its toll on Palace on Wheels (POW) with the royal luxury train deciding to cancel all its journeys in the on-going season from now onwards. An official in RTDC said that the March 11 journey will be last trip of the season.

The fear of corona virus has triggered large-scale cancellations and impacted its bookings, and on March 8, TOI had reported that the luxury train run by RTDC along with Indian railways has cancelled three trips of the season that ends in April 29.

The train runs once in every week from Delhi during the tourist season (September to April) and currently seven more trips are left. “About 80% of the passengers in the train are people from outside the country, and the visa suspension means that we cannot run the train this season,” said the official.

Mostly travel agents book the cabins in the train paying in advance. Since passengers are cancelling, the agents want the government to at least shift the trips to next year, as in that case they will not have to book losses. “Rajasthan government can take a call on that. As of now, there is no decision on that and the prevailing refund rules are followed,” said the official.

The tariffs for the 7 nights and 8 days trip range from Rs 2.73- 7.56 lakhs, inclusive of everything that includes food, sightseeing, safari, etc. After starting from Delhi, POW takes tourists to Jaipur, Sawai Madhopur (Ranthambore), Chittaurgarh, Udaipur, Jaisalmer, Jodhpur, Bharatpur, and Agra before returning to the national capital.
