The police will help the health department in locating the passengers and sensitize them on the need for self-quarantine.All Janamaithri police have been asked to propagate the awareness declared by the health department to prevent the spreading of the virus and also about the precautionary measures that have to be taken.All policemen on traffic duty have been asked compulsorily to wear masks and wash their hands at regular intervals. All district police chiefs have been asked to get directly involved in the awareness campaign against Covid-19 in their respective areas. tnn

Title: Centre lifts stock limits on onion wholesalers, retailers
Content:
Nashik: The Centre has finally lifted the stock limits on wholesale and retail onion traders following a rise in the volume of onions arriving in the wholesale markets.

The farmers and traders had been asking the Centre to remove the stock limit for the past two months.

In September, the Centre had imposed stock limits of 500 quintal for wholesalers and 100 quintal for retailers . Thereafter, around one-and-a-half-months ago, the Centre had reduced the stock limit to 250 quintal for wholesalers and 50 quintal for retailers.

Meanwhile, the average wholesale onion price at the Lasalgaon APMC, the country’s largest wholesale onion market, was increased by Rs 150 per quintal to settle at Rs 1,900 per quintal on Thursday — against Rs 1,750 per quintal on Wednesday — following reports of the stock limit withdrawal.

The minimum and maximum wholesale onion prices at the Lasalgaon APMC were recorded at Rs 1,000 and Rs 1,900 per quintal, respectively, on Thursday. Around 15,000 quintal of onions were auctioned at the wholesale market.

“Imposing stock limits on onion traders had affected the purchase of onions. But the Centre has taken a positive decision of withdrawing stock limit following an increase in the arrival of onions in the wholesale markets. This may help the declining wholesale onion prices,” said Suvarna Jagtap, the chairperson of Lasalgaon APMC.

“This is a positive decision, but the Centre took its time. It should have withdrawn the stock limit two months back. The Centre also issued a notification on lifting the ban on onion export, but it is effective from March 15,” said onion farmer Nivrutti Nyaharkar.

The average wholesale onion prices are expected to increase marginally on Monday, which will be the first day of business after lifting of the export ban, said APMC officials.

Title: Police arrest 127 people to check communal flare-up
Content:
Coimbatore: The city Police have arrested 127 members of several Hindu and Muslim outfits to keep communal flare-ups in check.

Police have also strengthened night patrolling, city police commissioner Sumit Sharan said. “Several anti-CAA and pro-CAA agitations were held in the city in the last few days. Wherever violence was reported, we registered FIRs and are in the process of making arrests,” he told reporters here on Thursday.

“Two people were arrested for throwing a crude bomb at a mosque in Ganapathy. One person arrested for hate speech has been remanded in judicial custody,” the officer said.

“I appeal to all organizations to maintain peace and harmony in Coimbatore. They should not hold any kind of demonstration for one week. The additional director general of police is camping in the city and conducting meetings with both the parties,” Sharan said.

The city police on Wednesday had arrested S Noor Mohammed, a resident of Kurichi, in connection with the attack on district secretary of Hindu Munnani M Anand last week. The accused was produced before the judicial magistrate and lodged in the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Four deputy commissioners of police man the four sub-divisions in the city. While L Balaji Saravanan (law & order) is in charge of the south sub-division, E S Uma (crime) looks after the west sub-division. R Mutharasu (traffic) and S Selvakumar (headquarters) oversee the east and central sub-divisions respectively. The city has 15 law & order police stations. An assistant commissioner each has been deputed for each police sstation to maintain law & order.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Italy-returned man triggers alarm in Chennai
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: An Indian national who has been roaming around Chennai after visiting Covid-19-hit Italy sent health officials into a tizzy on Thursday. The 27-year-old, who arrived in New Delhi from Milan on March 4, was taken to the Rajiv Gandhi Government General Hospital (RGGGH) on Thursday, but doctors there let him go as he did not show flu-like symptoms. Hours later, after realising he had a travel history to Milan, they tracked him down to a hotel in the city.

The man was about to board an Air India flight to Port Blair at Chennai airport

on Thursday when he complained to the airline staff that he was feeling feverish. “The staff did not want to take a risk and sent him to the general hospital in an ambulance,” said an airport official. Officials said they did not know why the man, who should have been on 28-day home quarantine, was roaming around the city. “When he said he was feeling unwell, we decided he should be treated first,” said a senior airport official.

Unlike the international terminal, the domestic facility does not have a team to screen passengers for Covid-19.

Doctors were not aware man had travelled to Italy

The man was sent to RGGH where doctors and paramedics did a basic screening. “By the time he reached the hospital, he had no fever. The doctors did not know the passenger had travelled to Italy and so he was asked to go. We are enquiring how the breach in quarantine protocol happened not once but twice,” a senior health official said.

The man then checked into a city hotel. However, by evening when the directorate of public health realised the slip, they tracked him down to the hotel. At the time of filing the report, an ambulance was sent to ferry him to Government Stanley Medical College hospital.

Title: Anti-CAA stir: Clock Tower protester dies
Content:
Shamshunissa

LUCKNOW: Another Clock Tower protester died on Thursday after suffering from double pneumonia she developed after getting drenched in the rain last week. The deceased was identified as 64-year-old Shamshunissa .

She was the third woman protester to have died due to health complications since the protest began at Clock Tower on Janary 17.

A resident of Moazammnagar in Chowk, Shamshunissa, a widow, is survived by her six sons who work as daily wagers in the city. Her son Laik said that his mother had taken ill after getting drenched in rain at the protest site on March 6 and was admitted to a hospital in Golaganj on March 7. Special prayers were held for her at the Clock Tower on Friday.

Title: Budget is far from reality: Bhatti
Content:
Hyderabad: Congress leader Mallu Bhatti Vikramarka said the budget was far from reality and questioned the rationale behind enhancing the budget from Rs 1.42 lakh crore to Rs 1.82 lakh crore.

During a debate on the budget in the assembly on Wednesday, Vikramarka said the budget was enhanced despite the government admitting impact of economic slowdown on the state.

He said the government earmarked Rs 10,000 crore for Hyderabad and urban agglomeration, but there was no mention about how it would want to spend the amount on flyovers, roads or any other projects. He said Musi rejuvenation and riverfront was completely neglected by the government. He further said the government should make efforts to protect Himayatsagar and Osmansagar under GO 111.

He said the government, instead of regulating liquor sales, was promoting the sales going by the estimated excise revenue of Rs 16,000 crore next year. “The government should not forget Disha incident in Hyderabad and Samatha incident in Adilabad. In both incidents, the culprits were under the influence of liquor,” he pointed out. He took objection when some ministers said contents of his speech were not related to the budget.

TRS MLA Gandra Venkataramana Reddy termed the budget ‘progressive’ and said Rythu Bandhu should be renamed as ‘KCR Rythu Bandhu’ scheme.

Title: Maoist remanded in custody till Mar 26
Content:
Coimbatore: Maoist Srimathi , who was arrested on Wednesday , has been remanded in judicial custody till March 26.

Coimbatore district Q branch police had arrested Srimathi 23, daughter of Chinna of Karnataka, from Anaikatti while she was travelling in a bus early Wednesday morning. She is an underground cadre of the People Liberation Guerrilla Army (PLGA), an armed wing of CPI (Maoist), police sources said.

“Preliminary investigation revealed that her husband Aravind was killed by Thunderbolts police at Manjakandi in Kerala last year. Srimathi also suffered a bullet injury to her leg. She is wanted in several cases in Karnataka,” a police officer said.

Police seized a handbag from her that contained Maoist literature, a mobile phone, memory card and a SIM card. They have booked her under sections 505 of the Indian Penal Code and 20, 30 of the Unlawful Activities (Prevention) Act, 1967.

Srimathi was on Thursday produced before principal district judge R Sakthivel. She was later taken to the special prison for women located inside the Coimbatore Central Prison.

Title: NMC officials in trouble for leaving cash in Yes Bank
Content:
Nashik: Municipal commissioner Radhakrishna Game has served notices to the chief accounts and finance officer (CAFO) and six other officials of the Nashik Municipal Corporation’s finance department for not withdrawing cash from Yes Bank despite his instructions given in October 2019.

Last year, in view of the reports on Yes Bank and its condition in the stock market, Game had instructed the NMC’s CAFO and the chief accounts officer of the smart city company to ensure that there is not a lot of cash left the their accounts in the Yes Bank.

While the smart city company withdrew most of its cash, the NMC account officials did not. As a result, around Rs 296.93 crore is still stuck in the Yes Bank after the RBI put restrictions on it.

“I had instructed the CAFO and chief accounts officer of the smart city. The smart city withdrew most of its cash, but NMC’s CAFO did not,” said Game. He added that the notices have been given to the CAFO and other NMC officials. “Responsibilities are to be assigned to these officials for their negligence,” he added.

Total funds of Rs 296.93 crore of NMC and around Rs 14.71 crore of the Nashik Municipal Smart City Development Corporation Ltd (NMSCDCL) are stuck in Yes Bank as the RBI has placed the bank under a moratorium, capping maximum withdrawals at Rs 50,000 per account for a month. The restrictions on the Yes Bank will be in place until April 3 this year.

This has forced the NMC to stop its online services to pay various taxes like property and water taxes. The NMC had tied up with Yes Bank and all online payments of taxes were deposited in its account with the financial institution.

Of Rs 296.93 crore, Rs 174 crore are the funds to be given to the state government under additional premium FSI. The remaining funds are of property, water and miscellaneous taxes.

NMC commissioner said the CAFO has justified that he had sought guidelines from the state government about the accounts, but it did not send the guidelines. “We will fix the responsibilities on all the officials from finance department for the NMC’s money being stuck in a private bank,” Game said.

According to NMSCDCL officials, the Rs 14.71 crore that it has in its Yes Bank account is mainly used for disbursement of salaries of its staff and meet its other establishments costs. Earlier, NMSCDCL had withdrawn its Rs 450 crore and transferred the same to other nationalised and private banks.

Title: Greens demand closure of Wayanad tourism centres
Content: Kozhikode: While major tourist centres across the state have been shut down as part of Covid-19 precautionary measures , the eight tourism destinations in Wayanad under District Tourism Promotion Council DTPC ) are functioning as usual.DTPC authorities said the decision not to close the destinations was taken as there was no Covid-19 case reported in Wayanad. “However, we are assessing the situation on a daily basis,” DTPC secretary B Anand said.DTPC authorities said there has been a decline in the number of tourists visiting the destinations.Meanwhile, greens are not enthused by the decision. Wayanad Prakrithi Samrakshana Samithi president N Badusha said it is illogical to allow tourist places to remain open when the government has ordered closure of all eco-tourism centres and ordered steps to prevent mass gathering of people. tnn

Title: No parking, jaywalking on these 18 stretches in Delhi
Content: NEW DELHI: To check snarls on 18 major stretches of the city, the traffic police have planned to turn them into no-tolerance zones. Neither parking will be allowed on these stretches, nor jaywalking. After trials on these 18 stretches (see box) for a fortnight, another set of 18 roads that will be made congestion-free will be selected.Traffic cops said a study had recently revealed that mixed land-use and improper parking were the main reasons behind the snarls. The problems will be addressed during the 15-day drive, which started on Wednesday.Most of the 18 stretches selected are within 2-3 km in length. To decongest these, the cops would be turning portions of the stretches into one-ways at different times of the day, depending on the traffic volume. Additional personnel will be deployed to prevent unnecessary stoppages by commercial vehicles and on-road parking will not be allowed. A dedicated pedestrian crossing zone will also be created on these stretches.Police have formed a task force comprising personnel from the accident research cell, road safety cell and signalling cell to monitor the success of the new plan.During the trial period, teams of eight to 15 cops will be deployed for traffic management. “These stretches were picked after assessing the traffic volume and average speed during the peak hours. Most of these roads are either parts of the ring road or arterial roads,” said a senior traffic police officer.Stretches like the one between Savitri Cinema Hall and Chirag Dilli witness an average traffic speed of about 20 kmph during the peak hours due to the congestion.An officer stressed that multiple metro station outlets that lead to parking of commercial vehicles for last-mile connectivity were also resulting in congestion at several places. The cops have requested the metro authorities to create dedicated halt-and-go lanes for these vehicles, which should be away from the main arterial roads.“Our aim is to eventually turn these stretches into complete congestion-free zones within the next few months. If required, some design changes may also be made,” said a police officer.Senior traffic police officers told TOI that a similar plan in areas like ITO and DDU Marg last year had evoked a positive response. “We have so far selected three stretches from each of the six traffic zones that were found to be most congested. This includes areas like Connaught Place as well,” said N S Bundela, joint commissioner (traffic).

Title: Men harass DU student, call her ‘coronavirus’
Content:
Representative image

NEW DELHI: A 22-year-old Delhi University student from northeast India was allegedly harassed by two people, who not only threw a balloon at her, but also called her ‘coronavirus’.

The woman in her compliant to the police stated that she resides in Jawahar Nagar with her friend. Police said the incident occurred on Friday when two youths on a two-wheeler threw a balloon at her and called her coronavirus. Based on her complaint, a case was registered at Roop Nagar police station.

“We are trying to identify the route of the accused youths through CCTV footage. The victim is yet to contact the investigating officer of the case,” said a senior police officer.

While the students’ identity has not been revealed, many northeast cells and northeast students have started calling out racial slurs against them on social media. “Stop calling people from northeast ‘coronavirus’, it is not okay,” said one such post shared by many students. TOI had reported on February 11 that students of Kirori Mal College had also complained of being attacked with racial slurs with one student writing a letter to the principal saying that she was called ‘coronavirus’ by a fellow student.

Title: Lucknow: Dulhan ki baraat dances for change, equality
Content:
The bride with her father Rajesh Kumar during her wedding procession

LUCKNOW: Sitting on a sparkling chariot, dressed in wedding finery and surrounded by relatives and friends dancing to dhol beats. If you are imagining a wedding procession led by a groom on an adorned horse, you are mistaken.In a shift from the age-old norm of a man bringing a baraat to his bride’s place, the city on Thursday witnessed a unique ‘ dulhan ki baraat ’ led by 22-year-old bride Rachna Vidyarthi. After almost an hour of dancing by her ‘baraatis’, Rachna reached the wedding venue where her groom’s baraat arrived from the other side. The ritual of ‘jaimala’ was performed at the gate. Once inside, the couple stepped on the stage together. In another novel step, the bride then proposed to the groom. The waiting family members cheered as the groom said ‘yes’.As unbelievable as it may sound, this is what happened at the wedding ceremony of the Daliganj resident who wished to challenge patriarchy and send out a message that women are no less than men. Executing the idea initiated by her father, Rachna said she felt driven to break the convention where a boy considers it his birthright to take out the wedding procession. “I realized that this change will empower many future brides and eradicate evils, including that of dowry,” said the bride, who has recently completed her masters in sociology and aspires to be a teacher.Her father Rajesh Kumar Vidyarthi, who first shared the idea with Rachna and her to-be husband Rupesh Choudhary, a banker, said the couple was more than willing to become agents of change.“In every community, it is expected that the bride’s family has to bow down in front of the groom’s family and accept their demands. As a parent, I never wanted that for my daughter. My daughter and to-be son-in-law were happy to send the strong message that there is no difference between boys and girls,” said Vidyarthi, an advocate.Rachna added that the idea was also encouraged by her fiance’s family.“We have chosen to spread the message of equality. There is nothing to be ashamed of,” she added.

Title: SBI heist: 3 more men arrested
Content:
Coimbatore: After nabbing two people in connection with the SBI branch heist at Kallipalayam near Palladam on February 24, police have arrested three more people .

Police identified them as B Ramanajappa, 44, of Tumkur in Karnataka, E Ramakrishna Achariyar, 35, of Anantpur in Andhra Pradesh and Mohammed Ishrar Khan from Rajasthan.

The Tirupur police have obtained prisoner transit warrant from the judicial magistrate court at Palladam to bring Ramanajappa and Achariyar to the district for detailed investigation. A police team that left Rajasthan on Thursday evening is expected to reach Tirupur along with Khan on Saturday. Police have recovered 650 grams of gold ornaments from the arrested people.

Title: Beyond the sound bite: Community radio broadcasts 50,000 voices for change
Content:
Coimbatore: Fifty thousand ideas to change society , from all walks of life — that is what members of the PSG Community Radio in the city have been doing for the past five months.

They have ‘collected’ voices of 50,000 people from the city and neighbouring districts, which they have been broadcasting for the project ‘Vision India 2030 – Radio Hub Coimbatore’.

Members of the radio said they asked people to speak about their idea to change the society. “We went around areas such as Peelamedu, R S Puram, Race Course, Codissia and other prominent areas. We spoke to people from various communities and walks of life. We asked them to introduce themselves and asked them what change they wished to see in the city,” said S Manimaran, a final year student of PSG College of Technology who is the executive head for the project.

He said they collected the voices from last October 15 to this January end. “Each voice is around 2minutes to 3minutes long. We have so far broadcasted around 8,000 voices. We would have to broadcast till mid-year to complete broadcasting all the voices,” he said.

This was the first phase of their bigger project to collect 1lakh voices, he said. “We would start the next phase from June, the start of the next academic year,” he said.

Also, to put the idea of change into practice, as part of the project, they collected around 100 students and conducted a cleaning drive near Tidel Park, he said. “We have chosen the theme ‘Vision India 2030’ to honour the memory of former president APJ Abdul Kalam. We want to show that students haven’t forgotten his dream and we would carry it forward,” he said.

The station has also selected 108 people from among the 50,000 – to mark its broadcast frequency 107.8MHz – who have given the best ideas for change and would bring them to the station from the 20th to 24th of this month and hold interviews with them.

Station director B Chandrasekaran said being a community radio, they have taken up this project to bring in a sense of community participation in bringing about change. Last year, the community radio broadcasted programmes non-stop for 107.8hours to set a record. “That was an attempt to set a record. This is to usher in a change,” he said.

Title: Kolkata: Parent-nod rider to relax curfew rule at Presidency hostel
Content:
Students stage protest on the Rajarhat campus on Thursday

KOLKATA: Presidency University authorities have told the students that they will lift the 10pm curfew at the girls’ hostel in Salt Lake if such a move is endorsed by their parents. The authorities arrived at the decision after a meeting between vice-chancellor Anuradha Lohia and a section of students who have been demonstrating for over a month on the College Street campus.

“The girls at the Salt Lake hostel have been demanding relaxation in the curfew hours, which is 10pm at present. It is a matter of safety and security of the students, for which we are responsible. But since they are so adamant, we have told them to get it endorsed by their parents and we shall relax the timing,” an official said.

Last month, all the boarders had defied the curfew by staying out of the hostel after 10pm. They also protested against the alleged ‘high-handed attitude’ of the hostel authorities, high charges for guests and inadequate water coolers. “The meeting was fruitful. We discussed all the issues,” Lohia said.

Students at the meeting were shown documents pertaining to the repairs of the remaining blocks of the Eden Hindu Hostel. The demonstrators were told to directly speak with the government over the completion of the work. The university authorities agreed to install more water coolers at the Salt Lake hostel as demanded by the boarders.

“We showed them all the files and fund allocations for Hindu Hostel and told them that the university authorities can do very little. The students can approach the government directly. The day-to-day affairs of the hostel has been outsourced. So, the university has nothing to do with the discontinuation of services of some of the staffers,” said the official.

The boys agitating over delay in the reopening of three blocks at Hindu hostel and discontinuation of services of some staffers. “None of our issues were resolved in the meeting. There was even no assurance by the authorities to look into the matter. They were non-committal and refused to consider any of our requests,” said a student who was present in the meeting.

“We will discuss the matter with other students and decide the future course of action,” he said.

Title: Delhi: GB nominees in row say they are social workers
Content:
Delhi University

NEW DELHI: What links a salon owner, guest teacher, property consultant and an electrician with Delhi University? They were all nominated by Delhi government to the governing bodies of some DU colleges and are now the bone of contention between the government and the institution. DU’s rejection of their names has held up the formation of the GBs, in turn leading the state government to withhold funding to the colleges.

Delhi government again forwarded these name recently after their rejection last September on the ground that they didn’t “meet the university’s criteria for GB membership”. Chances are they will be rejected once again at the Executive Council (EC) meeting that DU has summoned on Friday to clear the governing bodies.

The rejections and the ensuing delay in the formation of GBs have left 12 Delhi government-funded colleges in financial distress with no money to pay the salaries of the teaching and non-teaching staff for two months now.

A Delhi Government official claimed that DU hadn’t responded to the nominations yet. “We forwarded the list of people we wanted on the GBs, but the university has not said anything," the official said. However, EC member V S Negi contented that DU had asked the state government to reconsider some of the names last October. “There were many names in the list that DU teachers weren’t happy about,” he said.

When TOI contacted the people whose names were in dispute, they claimed to be “social workers” and, therefore, eligible to become GB members. The university asserted, in turn, that the EC members could not confirm the NGOs these nominees were associated with, leading to their rejection.

Harun Salmani, a School of Open Learning graduate nominated to the Acharya Narendra Dev College GB, runs a unisex salon in Indraprastha Extension and denied any connection with the Aam Aadmi Party. He, however, couldn’t say why his name was suggested for the GB other than to conjecture it was perhaps because he was a social worker.

Delhi government proposed the name of Dharmendra Kumar as GB member for Bhaskaracharya College of Applied Sciences. The CV sent to DU as part of the process stated that Kumar was an electrician with eight years’ experience. Kumar, another SOL graduate, stated, “I was nominated because I have been working with RWAs as a social worker.” He added, “I have no connection with higher education, but if someone wants to work for the good of colleges, why stop them?”

Nominated for the post at Aditi Mahavidyalaya, Nitin Bhot, a property consultant with a BA degree from IGNOU, also declared himself a social worker. “Since the time I was in DU, I have remained in touch with college students and am always ready to help them,” he said.

The EC, in its resolution number 51 in 2012, had decided that anyone nominated to a GB of a college funded/maintained by Delhi government had to be either “a person of eminence with a demonstrated interest in the area of education or those who have made significant contribution towards the promotion or administration of higher education, person of eminence in sports, culture or the arts or person of eminence in the sphere of development of education institutions.”

According to Negi, “Many of Delhi government’s nominations to the GBs don't fall in the three categories laid down by the EC. Sujit Kumar, professor of commerce at BR Ambedkar College, who hasn’t got his salary for two months, added, “You need people connected with education. Social workers can be nominated, but they should be associated with education.”

Title: ‘Principles of Shivaji Maharaj eternal, should be followed’
Content:
Sumant Tekade delivers a talk on ‘Shabdanchya Palikadle Shivrai’ to mark Shivaji Maharaj jayanti at Scientific... Read More

Nagpur: People need to perceive the eternal inspiration given by Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj through his principles, way of life and actions. His principles should be emulated in today’s world, said thinker Sumant Tekade on Wednesday.

He was delivering a lecture on ‘Shabdanchya Palikadle Shivrai’, organized to commemorate Shivaji jayanti according to ‘tithi’ at Scientific Society Hall, Laxmi Nagar. The event, titled ‘Shivjayanti Utsav’, was organized by Chhatrapati Seva Pratishthan. Officiating pro vice-chancellor of Nagpur University Vinayak Deshpande presided. Organization secretary Sanjay Deshkar was present.

Tekade said “Shivaji Maharaj instilled in his army the spirit of fighting back. With the motto of destroying the opponent’s capacity to fight, Shivaji proved to be a leading figure in guerrilla warfare. Indians were able to endure agonizing torture inflicted upon them by the Portuguese.”

Highlighting his mother Jijabai’s way of parenting, Tekade said, “It was a tradition to mould children from a young age. Jijabai fostered in Shivaji the qualities of a warrior from a tender age. We have forgotten to practice this custom in the present world.”

He spoke about the time Shivaji devoted to inculcate knowledge, skills and attitude. “Youngsters complain of dearth of job opportunities in Nagpur. They should give enough time from their busy schedule to develop personality. Even if one starts at a lower level in a specific line of work, the goal must be to reach the top with hard work and passion,” he added.

“Novels and cinemas are not a testimonial to history. They are just forms of entertainment and fun as the media allows freedom of expression and fictionalization of certain events. History can be called an account written by contemporary people during a particular time. Context and references are relevant information pertaining to a specific subject,” he said.

One should read pertinent books to connect with historical facts, he said.

He also spoke about how swarajya should be a medium to uplift the last man.

At the outset, Atul Guru, an expert on Shivaji’s forts, and activist Datta Shirke were felicitated by Deshpande for their efforts to propagate ideals of the Chhatrapati.

Title: Centre releases comic book on Covid-19 for kids 9-12 yrs
Content: Kochi: The central government has released a comic series for Covid-19 awareness ‘ Kids , Vaayu & Corona: Who wins the fights?’ to spread awareness among children in the age group of 9-12 years.The book is by the faculty of PGIMER-Chandigarh and Panjab university-Chandigarh to help children get answers to their queries on coronavirus. The book is authored by Dr Ravindra Khaiwal, additional professor, environment of health, PGIMER, and Dr Suman Mor, chairperson, department of environment studies, Panjab university, and with technical support from National Centre For Disease Control (NCDC).Vaayu is a global citizen who lives at the foothills of Himalayas and a superhero who works for better health and environment. He has been called to fight the global threat of coronavirus and to protect children from sudden panic and fear. The comic aims to reach out to children in age group of 9-12 years. Coronavirus has become cause for concern and parents should talk to the children and resolve their queries so that they do not panic.It starts off with kids watching TV about coronavirus. The father promises to explain it in the evening but the kids are curious and they call Vaayu for help.Vaayu, who appears as a superhero, explains about what viruses are, and that it could spread through touch, float and move through air. “That is why doctors and teachers always advise to cover your mouth when you sneeze or cough,” Vaayu says.Of course, one wonders if kids in that age group understand words like mortality. Then Vaayu goes on to explain hand-wash techniques to the children. It advices kids to greet people with a handshake and instead with As-salaam-alaikum, namastey, hello, or sat sri akal ji. One does not need to wear mask if they don’t have cold or respiratory symptoms. There are pictorial representations of 1m distance while sneezing or coughing and other instructions.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: SIT files FIR against IPS officer on graft charges
Content:
IPS officer Ajay Pal Sharma

LUCKNOW: Sixteen days after the three-member Special Investigation Team (SIT) submitted its report before the government on allegations of rampant corruption levelled by former Gautam Budh Nagar police chief Vaibhav Krishna against five IPS officers, it lodged an FIR against one of them.

Director General of SIT, RP Singh, said that on the directions of the government, an FIR under the charges of criminal breach of trust, criminal conspiracy and causing disappearance of evidence has been registered against IPS officer Ajay Pal Sharma .

“We have formed a team and would be probing into all the allegations against the IPS officer,” he said. He added that for the initiation of inquiry, the FIR registered by a woman at Lucknow’s Hazratganj police station has been taken into account,” said the DG. On March 8, a woman claiming to be Sharma’s ‘wife’, had lodged an FIR with Hazratganj police station alleging that the officer had multiple affairs and in order to conceal it he had framed her in a fraud case and got her arrested on August 10, 2019.

However, IPS Sharma had told TOI that the charges were baseless and that the woman was also not her wife.

On January 9, 2020, a three-member SIT comprising then interim state police chief HC Awasthy, who was also heading the vigilance department, IG STF Amitabh Yash, and Jal Nigam MD Vikas Gothalwal was formed on the directions of the CM to probe the allegations of graft levelled by Krishna against five fellow IPS officers, Ajay Pal Sharma, Sudhir Kumar Singh, Ganesh Saha, Rajiv Narain Mishra and Himanshu Kumar, .

Krishna had filed a complaint in August against the five officers to the department of home and also marked it to the DGP on August 23, 2019.

While this probe was on, on January 1, this year, explicit videos and chats of Krishna went viral. The Noida SSP had then described videos as “morphed” and part of “organised attempt” to malign him. Krishna had alleged that five IPS officers he had named were behind leak.

He also linked the leaks to the “confidential” report he had sent to the government. He also filed an FIR against unknown persons for morphing and sharing videos. The videos were sent for forensic examination in Gujarat and no tampering was found. Then an SIT was formed and probe started.

The SIT had recommended government action against two IPS officers along with vigilance probe. The other three were accused of misconduct.

Title: 2,395 litres of water for 1kg of paddy: Min
Content:
Hyderabad: Agriculture minister Singireddy Niranjan Reddy said 2,395 litres of water is used in Telangana to cultivate one kg of paddy.

Answering a question in the legislative council, the minister said water requirement (as per world standards) for producing one kg of rice is 2,300 litres. “In India, the requirement ranges from 1,786 litres to 3,683 litres,” he said.

The minister, however, said there was no truth in the claims that 5,000 litres of water is being used for production of one kg rice in Telangana.

He said that in the low-land field methods using borewells, water was saved up to 30% in stretches of erstwhile Karimnagar, Nizamabad, Warangal, Khammam, Nalgonda, Mahbubnagar, Rangareddy and Medak districts. “Efforts are on to involve international institutes and take up cultivation of paddy with less water usage,” he said.

He said Telangana Sona and Batukamma varieties are less dependent on water. “Research is also being conducted to get new varieties of paddy seed,” he added.

Title: ‘26 major bridges sanctioned in T’
Content: Hyderabad: A total of 26 major bridges have been sanctioned in Telangana since the formation of the state. “Out of these 26 bridges, 16 have been completed. A total of Rs 586 crore have been spend on them,” said roads and buildings minister Prashanth Reddy. TNN

Title: Hindu Munnani rally passes off peacefully
Content:
Coimbatore: The rally organised by the Hindu Munnani , which had close to 2 ,000 members from BJP and several Hindu outfits, passed off peacefully in the city despite provocative speeches by some of the participants on Thursday evening.

The rally was led by Hindu Munnani state president Kadeswara Subramanian and BJP leader C P Radhakrishnan. It commenced from Anna Statue, passed through Huzur Road and culminated near the district collectorate office where a meeting was held. Heavy police force was deployed all through the procession. Speakers at the event launched an unbridled attack on the members of another community accusing them of attacking Hindu functionaries.

Some of the speakers warned that there would be consequences if the attacks on their leaders continued. One speaker called for boycotting the commercial establishments run by another community. “This is what we have decided in Tirupur,” said the Hindu Makkal Kootamaippu leader from Mangalam in Tirupur, where there was an unrest during a pro–CAA meeting which was opposed by a section of the locals.

“We are patient because we are concerned about the peace and harmony of the city,’’ declared another leader.

If the prime target of the Hindu outfit members during the speeches was members of another community, the city police also came under equally scathing attack. They alleged that police had failed to prevent the attacks and take stringent action against the perpetrators. “There is a clear intelligence failure on the part of police. We have been informing police about the threats to our leaders. But police have failed to act,’’ said a Hindu outfit functionary. While police were acting tough when it comes to Hindu outfit members, they were lenient with Muslim outfits, he alleged.

“Let the city police allow the National Investigation Agency to take over the probe,’’ demanded another.

BJP leader C P Radhakrishnan blamed the DMK for the current volatile situation in Coimbatore, alleging that DMK’s backing for anti–CAA protestors was the root cause of the violent attacks happening now.

All along the procession, participants raised slogans demanding action against the assailants who attacked Hindu outfit members. Finally, they submitted a petition to the district administration largely accusing the city police.

Title: AAP appoints Dinesh Mohaniya as state in-charge of party in U’khand
Content: Dehradun: The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) has appointed Dinesh Mohaniya as the state in-charge of the party for Uttarakhand. Mohaniya is the incumbent MLA of New Delhi’s Sangam Vihar constituency. The 42-year-old politician has been representing the seat since 2013 .Mohaniya who was in Dehradun on Thursday told TOI that his focus will be on increasing the support base of the party in the hill state.“My current focus is on improving the organisational structure of the party in Uttarakhand. There are around 10,800 booths in the state and we will make sure that each booth is covered by our party workers,” he said. He added,“We have presented an excellent model to the entire country through our works in the last five years in the national capital. Our party has done exceptional work in the education and health sector in particular. AAP is the first party in the history of Indian politics to ask votes based on the work they have done. We want to assure the people of Uttarakhand that if they give us a chance, we will replicate the same Delhi model here as well.”The MLA who is also vice-chairman of the Delhi Jal Board (DJB) said that neither BJP nor Congress has done anything for the people of Uttarakhand in the past 20 years.“Both BJP and Congress have done nothing significant for the state. In fact, the policies of the ruling BJP have affected the state very badly. Also, there is no point voting for the Congress as their leaders eventually join the BJP due to which there is a decline in their core support,” Mohaniya said.He added that although he hadn’t been to most of the districts of the state yet, he had “found that AAP is quite popular in Uttarakhand.”“My party has given me the responsibility of the state as I have an organisational experience and have been part of the party since the time of Anna Aandolan movement. I will be spending most of my time in Uttarakhand from now, as we have a lot of work to do,” said Mohaniya.

Title: With flights to Hyd, Chennai, frequent flyers on cloud nine
Content:
Coimbatore: Air India has introduced a new flight to Hyderabad and an additional flight to Chennai, much to the joy of both business and leisure travellers,

The new flight to Hyderabad will leave Coimbatore at 12.35pm from March 29 and land at 2.05pm. It will depart from Hyderabad at 2.40pm and land here at 4.10pm.

The additional flight to Chennai will depart from Coimbatore at 4.50pm and land in Chennai at 5.50pm. The flight to the city will be a mid-morning flight, departing from Chennai at 11.05am and reaching Coimbatore at 12.05pm.

While tickets to Chennai start at Rs 2,350, those to Hyderabad are available for Rs 2,550 as part of the promotional offer, said Air India station manager Girija Ramesh. “It includes a baggage allowance of 25 kilograms and free meals on board.”

The new flights are expected to benefit frequent fliers between Coimbatore and Chennai, especially central government employees who are often allowed to claim official travel and leave travel allowance on Air India flights.

Air India currently has only one flight between the two cities, that too in the afternoon—departing from Chennai at 1.20pm and reaching Coimbatore at 2.20pm and again leaving Coimbatore at 3.05pm and landing in Chennai at 4.20pm. “The new flight, which reaches Chennai at 5.50pm, will reduce the waiting time for passengers to catch connections to countries like Dubai and Muscat in the late evening and night,” said Ramesh.

Frequent fliers to Hyderabad are also expected to benefit from the new flight, because only Indigo operates flights between the two cities. The three flights are early morning, afternoon and evening flights. “The new Air India flight, which departs at 12.35pm, is expected to give us an early afternoon option. By the time we land and reach hotels, it usually becomes 3.45pm or so, which is still more convenient than reaching the city at 6pm, with 2pm being the check-in time in most hotels,” said Sangeeta M, a clothes exhibitor.

Title: Saudi travel ban triggers scramble for tickets
Content:
Kozhikode: The decision by Saudi Arabia to temporarily ban travel of citizens and residents to and from a number of countries including India, EU and 11 nations, on Thursday, triggered a scramble among NRKs who had come home on leave to secure tickets in Saudi-bound flights for their journey back

The order issued by the Saudi government in the early hours of Thursday states that the temporary air-travel ban will come into effect after 72 hours and that Saudi citizens and residency visa holders are allowed to enter the kingdom within that period.

“Many passengers preponed their return to Saudi and a lot of people are asking for tickets, but the flights for Friday and Saturday are fully booked,” an airline official with Saudi Arabian Airlines said.

A one-way ticket to Dammam from Karipur airport which was available for Rs 18,000 till a week ago increased to Rs 40,000, according to travel agency sources in Saudi. Airlines operating in the sector have given preference to Malayali expatriates having Iqama (Saudi residence permit) which expires within a few days.

Saudi has, however, excluded health practitioners working in the country and hailing from India and Philippines as well as flights for evacuation apart for shipping and trade trips.

Saudi Arabia had last week imposed temporary ban for Umrah visa holders and tourist visa holders to enter the kingdom as part of Covid-19 precautionary measures.

Meanwhile, Indian consulate in Saudi has arranged a 24-hour helpline for stranded umrah pilgrims at 00966-5544 04023. Indian mission will assist them in returning home.

Also, Saudi Arabia had this week temporarily banned flights from nine countries, including United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Bahrain, which had affected many expats who had booked connection flights to Saudi via other Gulf-based carriers.

With Saudi also imposing ban on travellers from India, the number of Gulf countries which have travel restrictions in place for Indian expats have risen to three, the others being Qatar and Kuwait.

Title: West Bengal: Bangladeshi barge sinks after collision with port vessel
Content:
TimesView Every effort should be made to assess the possible impact, if any, of the incident on the marine bio-diversity of the region.

KOLKATA: A Bangladeshi barge , with fly ash on board, sank in the Hooghly near Pujali in South 24 Parganas on Thursday morning after colliding with a vessel of the Syama Prasad Mukherjee Port Trust (SPMPT).The port vessel — DV Rabindra — was on its way to Diamond Harbour when the Bangladeshi barge entered the navigation channel without warning. The collision left both vessels damaged. While the DV Rabindra managed to sail away towards Diamond Harbour, the master of the barge — MV Mamatamoyee Maa— attempted to sail the vessel towards the shore. But it sank close to Akra due to the bore tide. All 13 crew members were rescued.“Around 10.30am, the DV Rabindra master spotted the barge in the channel. Barges in the Indo-Bangladesh Protocol Route are supposed to stay away from the navigation channel. The DV Rabindra was on an urgent buoy repairing work, but tried to take evasive action. The master also asked MV Mamatamoyee Maa to pull away, but it didn’t. SPMPT chairman Vinit Kumar has ordered an inquiry,” a senior port official said.Manirul Islam, pilot of the MV Mamatamoyee, admitted that his vessel was not supposed to be in the navigation channel.“I realized that there was something wrong and was trying to call the pilot of another barge ahead of us over the wireless when the collision occurred,” he said.

Title: A journey of eight decades ends as Roxy screens its last show
Content: KOLKATA: After eight decades, it is curtains down for Roxy Cinema that had opened with Ashok Kumar ’s “Naya Sansar” in 1941.A week after a notice was issued by the first land acquisition collector, Kolkata, to the former lease owner of the theatre, asking for vacation of the premises within seven days, movies stopped screening at one of the iconic single-screen theatres in the city. Marking an end to an 11-year-old legal battle, the empty theatre on Thursday saw workers making arrangements to hand over the property to Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC).The lease for Bengal Properties had expired in 2006. Litigation started in 2009. In between, the hall was shut for two days in 2011. Thereafter, it remained open while the former lease owner was locked in a legal battle with KMC. On Thursday, mayor Firhad Hakim said, “The lease period had got over. The court has given an order in favour of KMC. They will hand over the property to us.”Sunit Singh of Bengal Properties, the former lease owner of Roxy Cinema said: “We tried our best and exhausted all our options. Now, there is no point dragging this issue. There were few cases that went against us. We got the notice last week. Due to the weekend and Holi holidays, we could not meet the KMC officials. We will be handing over the property and have requested the mayor to absorb the staff. He said he would look into the matter. The KMC has shown some interest in acquiring the AC machine and seats. If they get a fair value of it, they might take it. If not, they will give us time to remove it.”As one walked inside the theatre, it was hard to miss copies of the order that was pasted on the wall. “The division bench of the Calcutta High Court had issued an order against us in 2016. The order had stated that we should be evicted from the premises. Subsequently, the land acquisition officer filed an eviction suit against us. That order came on March 6. We didn’t want to contest that anymore,” Singh added.Posters on Friday’s release — Irrfan Khan ’s Angrezi Medium — hung all over the walls. It is another story that the film will not get a release at Roxy any more. Manager Swapan Chakravarty, who has been around since 1997, was working on a war footing to complete the handover procedures. On his table was a packet of popcorn that hadn’t been disposed. Rows of unused tickets in pink, green and yellow stared at him from a wooden cabinet. This certainly was not the future that the maker of this theatre had foreseen when it had opened sometime around 1908-09 as an opera house named Empire Theatre .The last film to have been screened was ‘Bhoot Part One: The Haunted Ship’. Only 27 people had attended the 6pm show at this theatre with a seating capacity of 730. Crestfallen, Swapan and gatekeeper Asad Bahm hadn’t even gone to watch the movie. “We just didn’t have the heart. On Wednesday, 36 and 40 people watched the 12.30pm and 3pm shows of ‘Brahma Janen Gopon Kommoti’,” he said.But things were different when the theatre had opened in 1941. There are stories of Netaji having come over to Roxy to watch another Ashok Kumar-starrer — “Kismat”. Roxy had set a national record for running ‘Kismat’ for three consecutive years. A nostalgic Chakravarty shared memories of watching ‘Maachis’ that had run for 16 weeks. Said he, “During those days one would see four shows of the same movie daily. People would get into brawl over tickets and even crib over why tickets were being sold in black. Since 2010, each theatre started screening two to three movies daily. That too couldn’t draw viewers. People have just lost the urge to watch movies in single screen theatres. As workers, we are now worried about our future.”

Title: 60-yr-old Hyd man denied pay dues by Saudi employer
Content:
Hyderabad: A Hyderabad man working in Saudi Arabia is reportedly being denied his salary dues despite a local court order to his employer, Safa Company. Shaik Chand Basha, a resident of Kishan Bagh in the city, has been working for the company since 1993.

Basha’s wife Kouser Begum, in a letter to Union external affairs minister S Jaishankar, urged the Consulate General of India (CGI), Jeddah, to help her husband get his dues and return home.

In response to MBT leader Amjed Ullah Khan bringing it to the notice of CGI Jeddah the problem of Basha, the CGI said it was aware of the case. “Indians working in Safa Company do not want to go back without their pending salaries and other benefits. The company has collapsed financially and the assets liquidation case is going on in the court. The case may take some time to resolve,” CGI Jeddah said.

Kouser Begum said her husband Basha, holding Saudi Arabia ID card no. 4650002808 and permit no. 2086043684, was working as a steel fixer in the company in Jeddah. Since 1993, the employer provided vacation for regulation and the last time Basha had come to India was in January 2016. After vacation, he returned Saudi Arabia and resumed duty.

The 60-year-old man filed an application with the company for final exit and wanted all his service benefits be cleared up to 2017. However, it did not happen. Basha approached a local court, which passed a final judgement on July 21, 2019, directing the company to pay him 63,520 riyals and settle the issue.

“Despite this, his arrears have not been released and he is also being harassed by the company so that he will leave Saudi Arabia without getting his dues,” Kouser Begum said in the letter to the Union minister. She said his health was also failing and he also had cataract in the eye.

Title: Match in empty UP's Ekana stadium: Coronavirus stumps cricket fans
Content: LUCKNOW: A wave of disappointment is sweeping through the world of willow fans with UP Cricket Association (UPCA) confirming on Thursday that the second ODI between India and South Africa, scheduled at Ekana stadium this Sunday, would be held behind closed doors amid the novel coronavirus pandemic. In other words, without audience at the stands.The decision has stumped Sauveer Raman, a diehard cricket buff, who bought four tickets to watch the match with his friends. “I waited eagerly for two months to see Rohit Sharma bat and now, I have been clean bowled by Covid-19 (the disease caused by the virus),” said the 22-year-old who works in Jaipur, was in Lucknow to celebrate Holi and extended his leave only for the match.Like Sauveer, thousands of fans are heartbroken. While some had booked tickets online, most others had braved long queues at stadium counters to get theirs. More than 32,000 tickets had been sold by Thursday afternoon against the stadium capacity of 50,000. Besides Lucknow, fans from Kanpur and Sitapur too have bought tickets for the big day. They cursed coronavirus in unison for shattering their long-cherished dream of cheering live for the Men in Blue. “We have been assured that the tickets will be refunded, but who cares about money. We are willing to pay extra if we are allowed to watch the ODI from the stands,” said Himanshu Gupta, a postgraduate student and among the first to buy tickets. Gaurav Khanna, a resident of Vibhuti Khand, couldn’t stop wondering how he would explain the situation to his kids, aged eight and 12. “They were so excited. They bought new autograph books and blue tees. I am scared to disappoint them,” the father said.Indiranagar Sector-10 resident Rahul Dhawan had a suggestion for UPCA under these unprecedented circumstances. “The authorities should allow fans entry after thermal scanning. Not only us, Team India will be disappointed too in the absence of a cheering home crowd,” he reasoned. Virat Kohli fan Jatin Srivastava had purchased a VIP ticket. “I wanted to see Virat bat up close. When will I ever get an opportunity to watch him in an ODI live?
