Title: Using cops to vacate assigned lands is a mockery of the system, says HC
Content:
Vijayawada: The AP high court on Thursday said the state government was “making a mockery of the system” by deploying police to evict people from the assigned lands.

Despite the interim orders passed by the high court, police were deployed to evict people, the court said adding, “If the situation continued like this we will write orders to the Union home ministry to take corrective steps”.

The high court bench was headed by Chief Justice J K Maheswari, Justice A V Sesha Sai and Justice M Satyanarayana Murthy. The court took cognizance of the representation given by Kula Vivakshanirmulana Porata Samiti (KVPS) as suo moto public interest litigation (PIL). It asked why the assigned lands are being taken from beneficiaries. The high court also heard the petition moved challenging the land pooling scheme being implemented in Visakhapatnam to take assigned lands.

Advocate general S Sriram explained that the assigned lands are being taken as per the provisions of the law and compensation is being paid to the affected people.

He said the state government has the power to take the assigned lands for public purpose. Turning down the argument of the advocate general, the high court observed that the government cannot spend public money to compensate the people evicted from the assigned lands to assign them to someone else. If any need arises in future will the government again pay compensation and take the assigned lands from the beneficiaries and allot to someone else questioned the high court.

Pointing out cutting of trees, the high court asked the advocate general under which provisions the trees are being cut down. Does the government know that cutting down trees without following guidelines is an offence, the bench questioned.

The AG said that no trees were cut down in the assigned lands and only those in the government lands were cut. The bench said cutting trees even in government lands is an offence and there are many Supreme Court judgments on the issue.

The high court bench also took serious objection over destroying crops with earth movers to take over the lands even if they are encroachers.

“The revenue officials are changing the land records illegally. Register cases against the officials who altered land records under Sections 467 and 468. Is there a rule of law in state or not,” the bench said. Reserving the orders over the issue, the high court asked the AG to submit the land records pertaining to those taken in Visakhapatnam under land pooling scheme.

Turning down the request of the AG not to give interim orders as the preparations are being made to allot house sites, the court observed that the government cannot distribute land when the model code of conduct is in force even though the process was initiated before the announcement of elections.

Title: Agitators may move to court against new protest ground
Content: Dehradun: Though the protesting ground has been shifted from Parade Ground to Ekta Vihar, Adhoiwala, the protesters are showing reluctance to move to the newly designated site.“We had a meeting with all other protesters. We all have all decided to write a letter to the human rights commission and highlight this dictatorial step taken by the Uttarakhand government. Also, we are likely to file a PIL regarding this matter,” said Pradeep Kukreti, one of the protesters.

Title: Rajinikanth: Actor Rajinikanth plays Baba, disappoints fans
Content:
Rajinikanth

CHENNAI: They were not lines from a prepared script, but the emotions that played out at a Chennai hotel on Thursday were intense: expectation, trepidation, disappointment, hope. As actor Rajinikanth spoke to journalists, spelling out a plan that seemed both lofty and daring, thousands of fans, who were tuned in to the live telecast, must have watched aghast, many in a state of disbelief.

Taking a sudden deviation from the much-anticipated political road map, actor Rajinikanth has opted out of the CM race. This could be an exercise either to shore up his image or a tantalizing teaser, months ahead of a big state election. Fans would like to believe that Rajini was testing the waters to see whether public sentiments towards his political launch was just lukewarm or searing hot.

Hoping to ignite an awakening, Rajini said, “Antha eruzhuchchi theriyettum, appo naan varen…” (Let there be a wave, then I will come). These words may have given hope to thousands of his followers, who have been playing the waiting game for more than two decades now.

But the words were preceded by Rajini’s assessment of the strength of his opponents that seemed tinged with fear and awe.

“We are facing two giants (the DMK and the AIADMK) with massive strength, money and muscle power … Can we defeat them both? Can I use my fans as sacrificial goats?” said the actor.

His admission about his state of health was even more revealing. Such candour may deter fans, but his advisors are hopeful. They believe that it might just work. They say the actor envisions a revolutionary, systemic, political cultural change and not just a change of government by targeting the CM chair. He is shrewd enough to realise that it would take more than a large fan following or a thirst for change to usher in a ‘revolution’ or a political wave that helped MGR, Jayalalithaa and Karunanidhi win elections in the past.

“Rajini perhaps wants to position himself above Telugu Desam founder N T Rama Rao, AIADMK founder M G Ramachandran, former DMK chief M Karunanidhi and former AIADMK leader J Jayalalithaa … much above electoral power, parties, and the political system,” said perception strategist Jhon Arockiasamy.

Observers point out that the Thursday revelation was an indication of the ‘spiritual’ Rajini trying to rise above the aspiring ‘political’ Rajini. They say he wouldn’t want to emerge as a political leader by exploiting his stardom, but be a people’s leader by ushering in ground-breaking systemic changes.

A close associate of the actor believes Rajini has a deeper plan. “It is the DMK which has better potential to win the election. In the coming months, he will identify the party and its leader M K Stalin as his arch-rival.” Now there is no powerful trigger to set off a political surge for or against his opponents.

While the actor has given his fans a preview of his political call-sheet, the real pitch is yet to be unveiled. The crucial question here is will his dual-leadership formula work for him in the tough poll arena next year.

Title: RBI cautions state against moving funds from pvt banks
Content:
Bhubaneswar: The Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) on Thursday advised the state government against moving deposits from private banks to public sector banks in the wake of the Yes Bank crisis, since doing so may have “stability implications” on the “banking and financial sector.”

Stating that “apprehension on safety of deposits in private sector banks is highly misplaced,” N S Vishwanathan, deputy governor of RBI, in a letter to chief secretary Asit Kumar Tripathy, wrote, “The RBI has adequate powers to regulate and supervise the private sector banks and by using these powers it has ensured that the depositors’ money is entirely safe.” An official source said the RBI has written similar letters to other state governments.

The RBI letter comes close on the heels of the government seeking to transfer Rs 545 crore deposited in Yes Bank accounts by Puri Jagannath Temple to a public sector bank. While Odisha’s finance minister Niranjan Pujari on March 7 wrote a letter to Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman seeking her intervention for release of the funds, the temple administration wrote to RBI the same day to transfer the amount to its UCO bank account. The BJD MPs also took up the matter with Sitharaman.

Deposit of temple funds in Yes Bank has snowballed into a major controversy with the opposition BJP and Congress seeking a probe into it.

Quoting media reports, the RBI letter stated, “Some states have advised government bodies and entities under their jurisdiction to transfer funds held with private sector banks. It is pertinent to mention that the resolution of weak private sector banks in the past has been done in a manner that the depositors are not put to loss. It is precisely with a view to refraining depositors’ confidence in private sector banks and mitigating hardships, that after the imposition of moratorium on Yes Bank, the RBI had drawn up a draft scheme without any delay and we are making every effort to expedite the finalization of the scheme.”

Advising against such funds transfer, the RBI wrote that such “reactive decision will not be in the interest of stability of financial system in general and banking system in particular.”

In October last year, the RBI had forced the Odisha government to withdraw a letter cautioning various departments against depositing government money in banks in view of apprehensions regarding the fiscal health of some of them. The RBI on October 25 last year had forced the government to withdraw its letter — written by finance secretary Ashok Meena on October 21, 2019 — saying the state finance department should not issue such letters and it is for the RBI to review the financial health of banks.

Title: CM’s scheme to now provide milk to school students
Content:
Dehradun: CM Trivendra Singh Rawat on Thursday launched the ‘Mukhyamantri Amrit Aanchal Yojana’. The scheme, a joint initiative of the Uttarakhand Co-operative Dairy Federation and the state department of school education , aims to provide students from classes 1 to 8 with nutritious milk once a week under the mid-day meal scheme. “Under the Mukhyamantri Aanchal Amrit Yojana, 1,72,000 children of anganwadi schools are being provided with milk four days a week. Now, 6,90,000 children from 17,045 schools will also be provided milk once a week.” The CM said that the scheme will be further enhanced. He added that there is no dearth of talented children in Uttarakhand, and the state government will ensure that they are well looked-after.

During the event, books in Garhwali and Kumaoni languages were released for students of classes 1 to 5. Dictionaries for Garhwali, Kumaoni and Jaunsari languages were also released.

Title: After Pune, Thane collector invokes Disaster Management Act 2005 amid coronavirus scare
Content: THANE: After Pune, Thane collector Rajesh Narvekar invoked the Disaster Management Act 2005 late on Wednesday to tackle the Covid-19 situation in the district. Narvekar said the Act empowers him to form a dedicated team of officials from revenue and health departments, FDA, police and local self-governing bodies, among others, who will coordinate and take prompt action in case positive cases are detected here.Officials said the Act enables them to empanel private hospitals and get them to share their resources and infrastructure to quarantine patients. A senior medical official said they are following up with healthy people who have travelled abroad in recent past. On Thursday, Narvekar said the administration has warned pharmacists against hoarding medical kits and alerted FDA to conduct checks to ensure essential items are not overcharged.Narvekar warned of stern penal action against those found spreading Covid-19-related rumours on social media that could spark panic. He has called for frequent fumigation and disinfection of bus stands, train stations, malls, hotels, banks and ATMs.Fifty-six Thane travellers who recently returned from abroad have been advised home quarantine, as is routine procedure. Narvekar said the residents, including a woman from a gated community in Manpada who had travelled in a cab whose driver tested positive in Pune, have not shown any symptoms.

Title: Uttra Pradesh: Letter with minister’s forged sign hails former KGMU vice-chancellor, FIR lodged
Content:
King George’s Medical University (File photo)

LUCKNOW: A letter of ‘appreciation’ bearing the name of the state medical education minister was found to be fake. The letter gave a ‘clean chit’ to former vice-chancellor of King George’s Medical University (KGMU) Prof Ravi Kant and also praised him for his services.

Chhotelal, the personal secretary to minister Suresh Kumar Khanna , who also holds charge of finance and parliamentary affairs, on Thursday lodged an FIR at Hazratganj police station against an unidentified man for forging the signature of the minister on the letter. The forged document, dated January 24, 2020, states that Prof Kant, who is at present director of All India Institute of Medical Sciences, Rishikesh, is being awarded an appreciation letter for his exemplary contribution in medical education and health. It also states that no case or judicial inquiry is pending against him. The letter also has a ‘receiving’ from Prof Kant’s office on January 24.

The complainant said that the letter was brought to the notice of the minister recently and after examining the document, it was found that neither the letterhead was of the minister, nor the signature on it. The letter had Khanna’s party symbol lotus as logo, which is never used on the official letterhead of a minister.

Prof Kant, who served KGMU from 2014-2017, said that he was in Ahmedabad on January 24 and his office never received any such letter. “I have never seen any such letter,” he told TOI, adding, “It appears to be a conspiracy against me”.

Hazratganj SHO Santosh Kumar Singh said, “A case of forgery and cheating has been registered. We are tracing the origin of the letter.”

Title: PFI-Delhi’s president, secretary held for funding riots
Content:
Popular Front of India’s Parvez Ahmed (left) and Mohammad Iliyas were arrested after police caught PFI member ... Read More

NEW DELHI: Escalating the crackdown on controversial Islamist outfit Popular Frontpfiof India (PFI), Delhi Police’s Special Cell has arrested its Delhi unit president, Parvez Ahmed, and secretary, Mohammad Iliyas, for allegedly funding the riots and fanning violence during anti-CAA protests in the city.

Earlier, police had arrested Danish Khan, a secretary of PFI.

The arrested men — Ahmed and Iliyas — were already under investigation by the Enforcement Directorate which is studying PFI’s financial transactions as part of a probe into the role of the outfit in anti-CAA protests.

The ED claims to have seized a tablet device from Parvez which purportedly has records of a chain of conversations about anti-CAA protests at Shaheen Bagh and violence at JNU between him and a member of Parliament.

The agencies have also established a suspicious pattern of deposits into and withdrawal of money from PFI’s accounts.

Iliyas was first to be arrested from Jafrabad on Wednesday, while Parvez was picked up from Parliament Street in the evening where a protest against the arrest of Danish was planned.

Sources said that the cops made Iliyas call up Parvez to the “protest site” and arrested him upon arrival.

The Special Cell claims to have clinching evidence about PFI spreading fake propaganda and fanning violence during the anti-CAA protests.

Danish, who was arrested earlier, handled the outfit’s intelligence wing and was spotted at all major protests in the city. “His interrogation has given clues regarding the outfit’s ‘information war,’” an officer said.

The FIR, in the case was filed by the Crime Branch, but since the larger conspiracy regarding the Delhi riots is being probed by the Special Cell, the matter has been transferred to them, said a senior official.

PFI has, however, called the move a conspiracy against it. “Whatever happens in India, the agencies put their blame on us. Never in the past have such allegations been proved. Even this time, we will come out clean,” the outfit stated.



In Video: Delhi: PFI President, Secretary arrested by special cell

Title: Suicide averted, but what were the rescue personnel thinking?
Content:
Chennai: Tragedy was avoided but a farce unfolded at Alandur on Wednesday when a 42-year-old woman threatened to jump off the terrace of her house and fire and rescue personnel stuck their hands out of a window holding a piece of cloth (see photo) hoping to catch her as she fell. Luckily for everyone, the woman heeded the pleas of her daughter and clambered back to safety.

The incident, however, raises questions about the training given to fire and rescue personnel. It’s one thing for several people to hold a piece of cloth at the four corners to catch someone jumping down. But to expect to catch a fullgrown woman in some cloth held out of a window by two pairs of hands begs the question: what were they thinking?

The woman who lives on Karpagar Vinayagar Koil street in Alandur was upset with her husband because he refused to transfer in her name his share of ancestral property that he had got recently. They had an argument on Tuesday and on Wednesday, soon after her husband went to work, the woman went to the third floor terrace of their apartment and stood near water tank threatening to jump off.

Her 19-year-old daughter tried to pacify the woman but in vain. Neighbours efforts too proved futile. They alerted the St Thomas Mount Police and a fire and rescue team arrived. And that’s when a bright spark decided to stick a bedsheet out of the window.

Using a bedsheet to hold a victim is highly risky, admitted a senior fire officer. During training they trained to hold the victim using a net, he added.

After about 45 minutes of pleading and cajoling by her daughter while the firemen milled around, the woman gave up her suicide bid.

Title: NMC installs 50 hoardings, banners to create awareness
Content:
Nashik: The Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC) has installed as many as 50 hoardings and banners in different parts of the city to create awareness among residents about coronavirus (Covid-19) and precautions that need be taken to stop the spread of infection.

Civic chief Radhakrishna Game said the civic body has already prepared a plan for admissions of patients in case of urgency in both isolation and quarantine wards.

“We are focusing on precaution, isolation and quarantine ahead of the outbreak of coronavirus. There is no need to panic, and people just need to take precaution and preventive measures,” he said.

A civic official said that of the 50 hoardings 18 — three each in six divisions — have been installed at major locations. “The remaining 32 banners have been put up at primary health centres and civic hospitals,” he said,

The hoardings and banners urge people to wash their hands with soap or sanitizers frequently, use handkerchief in case of could and cough, take nutritious meal, drink enough water and take adequate rest.

The hoardings also advise people to refrain from shaking hands, avoid contact with suspects, not to spit in public places, among others.

“As we do not have adequate number of physicians, we have urged the association of physicians to provide doctors in case of urgency. The association has promised the NMC to provide all kind of help,” the official said.

“We have over 25 residential quarters adjacent to NMC’s Bytco hospital for fire brigade department and those can be used in case of urgency,” he added.

The NMC has also made a WhatsApp group of over 250 private hospitals so that they can inform the civic body about patients on a daily basis.

The civic body has also warned of action against private hospitals if they hide information about patients coming from abroad.

Title: Mysuru: Farmer growing cannabis in KRS backwaters held
Content:
Representative image

MYSURU: Couples meeting in secret in the backwaters of KRS near Belagola, some 15km from the city, may have caught a whiff of something heady in the air. But for all public purposes, Siddaraju was growing kosher plants on his land and he and his son, Manjunath, ran a tea stall in Belagola village in Mandya.

Earlier this week, though, the city crime branch received a tip and nabbed 60-year-old Siddaraju who was on his way to Mysuru. Then, they landed up at his tea stall and caught his son as well. What they found on father and son left their jaws hanging – 24 kilos of cannabis aka marijuana , which could have easily fetched them over Rs 1 lakh.

Siddaraju told police he had been growing hemp for more than 30 years now in the backwaters and along with his son, sold the stuff in Mandya and Mysuru city. A growing clientele of youngsters, fake swamis and city dealers spread the word of a father-son duo ferrying homegrown marijuana and business grew over the decades. Siddaraju said 50g of the fix fetched between Rs 150-Rs 200 at the very least.

It is perhaps the biggest ever disclosure of illegal cannabis business in the recent past in Mysuru.

An officer admitted that the incident showed marijuana cultivation and addiction was growing in Mysuru right under the authorities’ noses. Police are investigating whether Siddaraju had other aides or accomplices. Deputy commissioner of police (law and order) AN Prakash Gowda told TOI that officers have been directed to conduct raids at suspected points.

For now, though, it seems Siddaraju ran a tight ship. He grew cannabis among other plants and thick bushes and since the areas is desolate, his secret was safe for three decades. Police said even his son did not know where the cannabis was grown and had only been trusted to sell the stuff.

Police said Manjunath had been arrested for selling ganja sometime back and was in judicial custody for a while but Siddaraju has escaped the police radar so far. CCB ACP V Mariappa and inspectors A Mallesha, Vivekananda HR and Kiran Kumar C, who are part of the investigation team, have intensified investigations to uncover the duo’s network.

While Siddaraju preferred to sell in Mysuru because it was close to home, police said cannabis was being smuggled into Mysuru from Shivamogga as well. A part of Mandi Mohalla has remained a haven for drug peddling despite frequent raids by cops and excise authorities. In 2019, a woman was arrested for selling marijuana after one of her relatives was detained by cops and spilled the beans.

Title: My 5-year-old boy is crazy for a girl and it is embarrassing
Content: My 5 year old son is obsessed with a girl in his class. He does not want to talk to anyone and cribs when she talks to someone . Now the girl's parents have started complaining about his behaviour. Is this normal for such a small kid ?Answer by Dr Rachna Singh: Hello. Thank you for writing to us. I understand your situation and your concern regarding your child.First and foremost it is very much evident that your son has formed quite an attachment with this girl. Having said that it is not necessary that this is indicative of any attraction in a romantic or sexual way. He probably likes her a lot as a friend and wants her attention all the time. That explains why he cribs when he sees her talking and getting close to other children in his class. He probably is becoming possessive of her since he sees her as a best friend. This is a very normal trait in children of this age.I suggest you to gently talk to him about his classes and then take the conversation ahead to his friends in the class. This will give you a glimpse of how he feels about his peers and a lot more . You can then talk to your child about friendships in general and explain why it's important to have a good social circle, and the importance of having more friends versus one sole best friend.I would also encourage you to create certain distractions for him. Try to take him to the park or other places of activities such as sports, recreational activities etc. Introduce him to new kids of similar age and help him so that he can get along with other kids and make more friends. It will also be a different space for him to grow.I would suggest you to talk to the girl's parents about this friendship. You can explain it to them as well, that it is normal for children to experiment with different kinds of things, and probably this kind of friendship is one such step of experimentation and nothing to be worried about. Rather, both sides of parents should work as a team towards handling it. I also suggest you that, you should talk to his teachers as well and ask them about his behaviour in class and explore about other children’s behaviour towards him.Lastly, even though I am sure you love your child a lot, express a lot of love and affection towards him, which will further make him feel secure in his relationships.I hope this helps . If you want to discuss things further, feel free to to contact us.Dr Rachna Khanna Singh is HOD - Holistic Medicine & Psychology (Counselling) - Artemis Hospital, Gurgaon, Director - The Mind & Wellness Clinic, New Delhi and Director - NGO ServeSammantimes.parenting@gmail.com

Title: MP minister held trying to meet rebels in Bengaluru
Content: BENGALURU/BHOPAL: High drama prevailed at a resort on the outskirts of Bengaluru on Thursday when Madhya Pradesh minister Jitu Patwari attempted to enter the premises where 23 rebel Congress MLAs who have resigned their vidhan sabha membership are holed up. Following a mild scuffle, police arrested Patwari under IPC section 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharging her/his duty) and later released him on station bail.In a bid to persuade the rebels to return to the Congress fold, Patwari and Lakhan Singh Yadav, another MP minister, had arrived in Bengaluru. They were accompanied by the father of one of the MLAs — Manoj Choudhary.In a video of the incident which was widely shared, Patwari is seen attempting to enter the resort, while policemen are preventing him. It also showed the minister in a heated argument with police. At a press conference in Bhopal, senior Congress members Digvijaya Singh and Vivek Tankha showed a dramatic video in which Patwari, Yadav and Choudhary are shoved around by unidentified people.“This is a case of abduction and forced captivity,” Tankha said, adding, “You abduct and take our MLAs to a different region, and hold them hostage. They cannot even contact their families as their mobile phones have been taken away. They are not there out of free will. A BJP delegation led by senior leaders takes resignations from MLAs on Holi and returns to Bhopal to submit them to the Speaker. No one knows under what circumstances these resignations were taken from our MLAs.”Tankha demanded that the Congress MLAs be “released” immediately. “We are consulting Kapil Sibal (former Union minister and Supreme Court lawyer) and, maybe, we will move Supreme Court and tell how the country’s democracy is in danger. What BJP is doing is a criminal act and an unbiased probe should be conducted by the apex court because BJP-led Centre will not be interested,” he said.However, cops said the MLAs from MP had recently written to the Karnataka DGP seeking police protection. Nineteen Congress MLAs who are loyalists of Jyotiraditya Scindia had said in the letter that they had come to Karnataka “voluntarily” on “important work”, police said.Bengaluru city police commissioner Bhaskar Rao told TOI that the MLAs had given a written requisition saying “some politicians” from their home state were flying down to meet them and they don’t want to meet anyone. “So we set up a police force outside the place. Jitu Patwari not only tried to forcibly enter the place, but also manhandled police trying to stop him,” Rao said. Karnataka Congress condemned the police action and demanded an apology from CM BS Yediyurappa.State Congress described Patwari’s arrest as “goonda behaviour of Karnataka BJP government” and demanded that the MLAs be “released” immediately. “Chief minister BS Yediyurappa has to apologise for the mistake,” state Congress tweeted.Later in the evening, Patwari and newly appointed KPCC president DK Shivakumar held a press briefing claiming that Bengaluru police was acting on behalf of the ruling party and not even allowing family members meet “kidnapped” legislators from MP. “It is possible that a few people are trying to put a psychological pressure by putting forth the image of Jyotiraditya Scindia. But why are you (MLAs) trying to sacrifice the people’s mandate? I urge my family of Congress legislators to not fall into this trap of BJP,” said Patwari.Shivakumar said he was not involved “in any way” with the MP crisis and was only helping his “friends, leaders and colleagues” from Congress.

Title: Coronavirus in Ghaziabad: Second coronavirus case in Ghaziabad, patient’s son also tests positive
Content: GHAZIABAD: A 27-year-old man, whose father had tested positive for coronavirus last week, has also been found to be infected. This is the second confirmed case of Covid-19 in Ghaziabad.The man’s father, a 57-year-old businessman from Raj Nagar Extension, had returned from Tehran, Iran, on February 23. After the latter tested positive, the son was living with his mother in home isolation in a highrise for about 10 days, said health officials. His swab sample was collected on March 5 and the test results from National Institute of Virology (NIV) Pune confirmed it to be a case of coronavirus. He has been shifted to an isolation ward of MMG District Hospital, where his condition will be monitored by a team of doctors.Chief medical officer N K Gupta said, “Although the son and his mother were living in home isolation in the same flat, they were wearing masks and keeping distance from each other. The woman had earlier tested negative for the virus, but after his son has been found to be positive, we might have to take her samples again. We are discussing the matter with the headquarters in Lucknow.”“Both the man and his mother are asymptomatic. The condition of the father has improved a lot. Several people, including milkmen and three employees, who had come in the chain of contact with the businessman were tested and their results were found to be negative,” the CMO added.The businessman had first been taken to Ram Manohar Lohia hospital in Delhi and later shifted to Safdarjung hospital when his condition improved. The health department has decided to re-sanitise the residential society where the businessman’s family resides, said Gupta.As of now, around 275 people in Ghaziabad have been screened and 70 are under surveillance, officials said. Samples of 32 people have been taken, of which 29 have been found to be negative. The report of one person is awaited.

Title: Covid-19: Govt may end Lok Sabha session before schedule
Content: NEW DELHI: With the government discussing ways to contain the spread of coronavirus in the country, BJD MP Pinaki Misra appealed to Speaker Om Birla on Thursday to facilitate thermal imaging cameras in the Parliament complex as well.The government has issued advisories against non-essential gatherings of large groups in any part of the country. Lauding the government for the measures taken to assist contain the virus, Misra said some members of Iran’s Parliament have tested positive for coronavirus. “Please fix thermal imaging in Parliament,” he said.While schools and cinema halls were asked to shut as a precautionary measure in light of the spread of Covid-19, sources said the government was considering whether Lok Sabha could be adjourned around March 20, ahead of its scheduled close on April 3. With Lok Sabha expected to discuss and pass the Finance Bill next week, key legislations that need to be considered by the House will be passed.Among other important legislations, Lok Sabha has already passed the Direct Tax Vivaad se Vishwas Bill, 2020, and the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (Second Amendment) Bill in the first week of the budget session after recess. Rajya Sabha passed the IBC bill on Thursday.Birla sought the House’s opinion on letting Lok Sabha function through the weekend and said he would allow it if there was consensus. After vehement opposition by a large number of MPs, however, Birla said the House would sit till late hours to discuss the demand for grants of various key ministries.

Title: Battle-ready: YSRC comes out with list of 40 candidates for GVMC polls
Content:
Visakhapatnam: YSRC released its first list of 40 candidates for the GVMC elections on Thursday. Of the 40 candidates, 6 names are from the Visakhapatnam North assembly constituency, 10 candidates from Visakhapatnam East, 6 from Visakhapatnam West.

Candidates were also announced for 8 wards in Visakhapatnam south, 5 each from Pendurthi and Gajuwaka constituencies. 23 of the 40 candidates are from the backward class (BC) category and three are from the scheduled caste (SC) category. 15 of the 40 candidates are women. The list was announced by former MLC Dadi Veerabhadra Rao.

Not everyone among the YSRC cadre was happy with the list. Heated arguments ensued in the midst of the announcement. Paradesi Naidu, of ward number 15 who was anticipating a ticket for his wife but who was not given the same said, “We have a population of 4,500 of my community in the ward. The party will definitely lose the seat if they continue with the candidate,” referring to the person who has been given the ticket for the said ward.

Title: Rebel trouble ahead of YSRC, TDP
Content:
Visakhapatnam: YSRC and TDP are likely to face rebel menace during the GVMC elections.

In every ward, YSRC will have more than one aspirant. “Community, local relations, money and muscle power are at play in local elections. In any election, the ruling party will have an edge,” said a senior YSRC leader.

In 2007, more than 30 rebels from both the Congress and TDP ranks contested as independents. Of the 72 wards, 10 independents won. Congress won 27 and TDP 32 seats. But Congress won the mayor’s post with the support of 10 independents.

TDP and YSRC are facing the threat of rebels in 15 out of 98 wards. The rebels will be mostly in wards in the city’s outskirts and industrial areas, besides a few in the city. “Many leaders who worked for the party in the last nine years may not get the seats. Parties tend to look at money factor and not the services to the party,” said a senior TDP leader.

In a ward, there would be around 15,000 votes and on an average 11,000 to 13,000 votes would be polled. In a triangular fight, the one who gets more than 5,000 votes, would be the winner. Rebels can cut into the main parties’ vote share and hence the worry in the camps of YSRC and TDP.

Title: Coronavirus Mumbai News: Rs 2 lakh fake sanitisers seized in Mumbai
Content: MUMBAI: FDA carried out raids between Wednesday and Thursday on companies making fake sanitisers that offered no real germ-killing properties. The teams found that several herbal products have flooded the market.In one case, FDA seized a stock of fake sanitisers worth over Rs 2 lakh from a Kandivli distributor, Riddhi Siddhi. On investigation, the drug regulatory body found that the sanitisers were manufactured by a Bhiwandi company that had surrendered its licence two years back."We found that the company was making sanitisers illegally and selling it to distributors and chemists. They have violated the Drugs and Cosmetics Act and will be penalised accordingly, but since they have cooperated with police, an FIR may not be lodged," said D R Gahane, FDA assistant commissioner (drugs).He said the sanitisers were sold under the names of Biotol Cosmetics and Wiz. "They were complete fakes and the companies were not making them," he added.The FDA teams also came across another Vakola firm, Sanskar Ayurved, that was manufacturing fake products. Sold under the name of Safe Hands, the product claimed it was anti-bacterial. The bottle also carried a helpline number which did not work.

Title: Ahmedabad: Blind man behind bars for five vehicle thefts
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: Ahmed Shaikh (32), a resident of Rakhial, has been behind bars for more than two months in connection with five two-wheeler thefts. His medical reports certify him as being 100% blind. He has moved high court to quash all five FIRs citing that he is 100% blind and could not have been involved in such incidents.

In December 2019, Shaikh was booked for stealing two-wheelers from parts of the city. Ramol, Isanpur and Naroda police registered one FIR each against him, and Vatva police booked him in two theft cases. He was arrested in the cases, one after the other, on statements by other accused, showing him to be part of the alleged gang of vehicle thieves.

As soon as he was arrested and brought before the court in various cases, his advocate M A Sangram presented medical certificates issued by the Blind People's Association in 2009 and by Civil Hospital in 2017. He opposed Shaikh's remand proceedings and judicial custody, but the metropolitan courts were inclined to send him to jail in the second week of January.

This is not the first time Shaikh was arrested by city police in a criminal case. He was booked in two cases of vehicle theft in 2017 by Bapunagar police. He was acquitted along with a common co-accused, Aslam Chhotu, in one of the cases, whereas he still faces trial in the other case.

Cops challenge Shaikh’s claim of being blind citing CCTV footage

Interestingly, in the case in which Ahmed Shaikh was acquitted, police had strongly challenged his claims of being completely blind. The cops told the court that a CCTV camera in Bapunagar captured Shaikh riding a two-wheeler. Sangram put up a lame argument that it was the handiwork of his co-accused. However, the complainant in this case was in no mood to prolong the case because his vehicle had been found and returned to him.

As he had not received relief in these cases, Shaikh moved the Gujarat high court last month, seeking quashing of all FIRs. His advocate in the HC, Anurag Rathod, contended that Shaikh could not have taken part in the thefts because he is 100% blind. He needs assistance in his day-to-day activities as well. He was arraigned in the theft cases merely on the basis of statements by the co-accused, which have no value as evidence in the absence of independent evidence against him.

After hearing the quashing plea, Justice S H Vora sought a reply from the state government as to how Shaikh was involved in the offence. A further hearing is posted for March 24.

Title: ‘Jagan to decide on mayor post’
Content:
Visakhapatnam: YSRC general secretary V Vijayasai on Thursday said that chief minister Y S Jaganmohan Reddy would decide posts of mayor and ZP chairperson after results. He dismissed reports that the elections to local bodies are referendum on the performance of the YSRC government. He said the media should not trot out ‘referendum’ to every issue.

After hoisting the party flag at the YSRC office on the 10th Formation Day of the party in the city on Thursday, Vijayasai Reddy said that the government has taken the decision to make Vizag executive capital based on people’s wish.

He said the government is distributing house sites to 1.72 lakh eligible people in the city. He alleged that former chief minister N Chandrababu Naidu is worried that TDP would face a drubbing in local bodies’ election and resorting to violence.

Tourism minister M Srinivasa Rao said the party is sending two leaders from BC communities to Rajya Sabha to affirm the government’s commitment to ensure the welfare of the BCs.

Title: Coronavirus: Medical team from India to test students stranded in Rome
Content: VISAKHAPATNAM: With Air India not letting the stranded Indian students in Italy board their flight without a certificate that says they’re COVID-19 negative, hundreds of students in the airports at Rome and Milan have been left in the lurch.On Thursday, the Indian government announced that it would be sending a medical team to Italy to solve the medical certificate issue. The team will collect samples at the Indian Embassy in Rome and will return to India for the final result. However, amidst this confusion and a lockdown in Italy, the students’ hopes of immediately returning to their homeland were dashed as Air India flights were cancelled till March 31.Air India, which barred hundreds of students with confirmed tickets from boarding their flight on Wednesday morning, has cancelled all its flights till March 31 and the airlines has asked passengers to take their ticket refund and cancellation charges have been waived. The students could not provide mandatory ‘medically fit’ certificates from designated government institutes as hospitals were too busy catering to patients and had no time to issue fit certificates.As the students’ situation came to light through media reports and social networking sites, the Indian government announced sending a medical team to Italy. The external affairs minister Dr S Jaishankar had announced, “We are sending a medical team to Italy to the check the Indians stranded there and bring them back at the earliest.”A self-declaration form will be given at the time of sample collection in the Embassy. Test samples collected by the Indian medical team at Rome will be sent to India and it will take approximately one week for the results to be received. Those testing negative will be allowed to travel to India but will be in mandatory quarantine of 14 days in the government specified facilities in India upon arrival.As on March 9, Italy—the worst Coronavirus-hit country after China—had reported over 9,172 cases and 463 deaths. In less than 72 hours, by March 12, the number of cases have gone up to 12,462 and death toll rose to 827.Over 10,000 Indian students are pursuing higher studies at various Italian universities. After travel restrictions were announced in Italy, hundreds of students found themselves stranded in the country. Through social media, the students kept requesting the Indian government to do the needful and are also being briefed by the Embassy about any updates.

Title: DK Shivakumar’s elevation ignites hopes of Congress’ revival in North Karnataka
Content:
File photo of DK Shivakumar

HUBBALLI: The Congress high command ’s decision to appoint the party’s trusted troubleshooter and former minister DK Shivakumar as the president of the Karnataka Pradesh Congress Committee ( KPCC ) has ignited hope among the party’s functionaries and workers in North Karnataka of ending the BJP’s dominance in the region.

For some time now, Congress has been struggling to make a dent in the BJP’s prospects in North Karnataka, a failure that party insiders attribute to the lack of a strong local leader, coupled with the absence of a popular member who can appeal to the masses.

It is not that there are no Congress members in the region – HK Patil , SR Patil, MB Patil , IG Sanadi, Vinay Kulkarni and KB Koliwad, to name but a few – but in most cases, their popularity is confined to their respective districts, and none of them has a footprint across the vast North Karnataka. This glaring lack has had a telling impact on the Congress’ fortunes at the hustings, where it has been faring poorly in both the assembly and parliamentary elections.

The elation that has greeted Shivakumar’s elevation in North Karnataka is not without cause. The former minister’s organisational strengths have earned him a grudging respect even among his opponents, and despite hailing from the Old Mysore region, Shivakumar has proven his mettle in North Karnataka, where he remains a popular leader. He spearheaded the campaign for VS Ugrappa in the 2018 by-election to the Ballari Lok Sabha seat, wherein the senior Congress member was pitted against B Sreeramulu’s sister J Shantha. Ugrappa posted a thumping victory, besting the BJP candidate by a margin of over two lakh votes. “Later, when MLA CS Shivalli’s death necessitated a byelection in Kundagol, Shivakumar pitched tent in the constituency for more than two weeks and ensured a decisive won for the Congress,” said a senior Congress functionary.

But it is not going to be a daunting task for Shivakumar to assert his strength in a region where the Lingayats constitute the majority. As a Vokkaliga strongman, Shivakumar, in addition to bringing the other senior members in the region including MB Patil, who was a strong contender for the KPCC top post, on the same page, will have to win over the Lingayats, who have traditionally been staunch supporters of the BJP in the recent past.

The political landscape in Belagavi is another landmine, where Shivakumar will have to tread very carefully. With Ramesh Jarkiholi crossing over to the BJP, the Congress’ position in the border district has further weakened, and the new KPCC chief will have to come up with a carefully thought-out strategy to ensure the party regains its dominance in Belagavi.

Youth Congress leader Shakeer Sanadi admitted to party workers feeling upbeat over Shivakumnar’s elevation. “Given his popularity as a trouble shooter, and reputation as strategist, we hope that, through his dynamic leadership, Shivakumar will bring all the leaders together and come up with a strategy to defeat the BJP in the next election,” he said.

Title: Mangaluru: Hunger strike observed to commemorate salt satyagraha
Content:
Hunger strike observed to commemorate salt satyagraha

MANGALURU: We the People of India, an organisation of like-minded people, held a daylong hunger strike demanding the withdrawal of NPR on the occasion of the 90th anniversary of Mahatma Gandhi’s Salt Satyagraha near the deputy commissioner’s office here on Thursday.

Former MLA J R Lobo said an attempt is being made to divide people on the basis of religion in the nation. He expressed concern over the increasing prices of essential commodities and lack of employment. “The economy has been affected badly due to the economic slowdown. Industries and agriculture and other sectors are in a state of stagnation, and the development of the nation is at stake,” he said.

Shanthi Prathishtana managing director Mohammed Kunhi said if Mahatma Gandhi could make India independent through satyagraha, the same mode of protest will also help people to reject the central government’s citizenship laws. “Hindus and Muslim in India have been living in harmony after Independence. However, the central government is now making attempts to divide people. Protests are being held at various places across India against NPR, NRC and CAA and it should continue till the fascist ideologies are rooted out from the nation,” he added.

The nation has witnessed the worst economic crisis, he said, and called upon people cutting across all religions to unite against fascist ideologies.

Former mayor K Ashraf, corporators Abdul Latheef, Abdul Rouf, CITU Shramikara Sangha president Willy Wilson, social activist Vidya Dinker, writer A K Kukkila, DYFI district president B K Imthiyaz, SDPI district president Ataulla Jokatte and UNIWEF president Rafiuddin Kudroli were present.
